1;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/sep/16/ursula-von-der-leyen-says-polands-lgbt-free-zones-have-no-place-in-eu";2020-09-16;"Ursula von der Leyen says Poland's 'LGBT-free zones' have no place in EU";"In her first ‘state of union’ speech
column2: European commission president delivers criticism of Polish ruling party

column1: The head of the European commission
column2: Ursula von der Leyen
column3: has said Poland’s “LGBT free zones” are “humanity-free zones” that have no place in the European Union in her strongest criticism yet of Poland’s ruling Law and Justice party.

column1: In a wide-ranging 77-minute speech spanning from coronavirus to the climate emergency
column2: Von der Leyen pledged to build “a union of equality” and criticised European member states that watered down EU foreign policy messages on human rights.

column1: She made plain her disapproval of Poland’s rightwing nationalist government
column2: which has often hit out at “LGBT ideology”
column3: while a number of Polish towns declared themselves “LGBT-ideology free zones”.

column1: “Being yourself is not your ideology
column2: ” Von der Leyen told applauding MEPs in the European parliament in Brussels. “It’s your identity
column3: ” she said. “So I want to be crystal clear – LGBTQI-free zones are humanity free zones. And they have no place in our union.”

column1: The EU is locked in a long-running dispute with Poland over the rule of law
column2: since the ruling Law and Justice party embarked on policies that weaken independent courts. With no end in sight
column3: that fight is set to intensify
column4: as Von der Leyen signalled she would not back down on linking EU funds to financial probity
column5: following questions over the use of European money in Hungary and the Czech Republic. She said protecting the EU budget “against any kind of fraud
column6: corruption and conflict of interest” was “non-negotiable”.

column1: The commission president lamented that EU foreign policy could be “delayed
column2: watered down or held hostage for other motives”
column3: as she called for an end to national vetoes.

column1: Brussels has long called for an end to national vetoes on foreign policy
column2: but Von der Leyen – who has pledged to lead a “geopolitical commission” – made the point by criticising EU governments for blocking stronger positions.

column1: The EU
column2: Von der Leyen said
column3: needed to call out human rights abuses
column4: whether in Hong Kong or over the fate of the Uighurs. “But what holds us back? Why are even simple statements on EU values delayed
column5: watered down or held hostage for other motives? When member states say Europe is too slow
column6: I say to them be courageous and finally move to qualified majority voting – at least on human rights and sanctions implementation.”

column1: She promised her officials would draft a “Magnitsky act”
column2: a targeted sanctions regime to punish human-rights offenders. Similar legislation already exists in the US and was recently introduced in the UK. The acts take their name from the Russian lawyer Sergei Magnitsky
column3: who died in a Moscow jail aged 37
column4: after uncovering a massive tax fraud by state officials.

column1: The commission president
column2: a close ally of the German chancellor
column3: Angela Merkel
column4: criticised the Russian government by describing the poisoning of the opposition activist Alexei Navalny as “not a one-off” and part of a pattern of behaviour. “This pattern is not changing – and no pipeline will change that
column5: ” she added in a cryptic reference to the German-Russian Nord Stream II pipeline from which Merkel’s government is under pressure to withdraw its support.

column1: Von der Leyen was delivering her first “state of the union” speech
column2: since beginning a five-year term last December. The annual speech to the European parliament
column3: an idea consciously modelled on its US namesake
column4: is intended to set out EU legislative priorities.

column1: In the speech that cited Andrei Sakharov
column2: Margaret Thatcher and John Hume
column3: she struck an upbeat tone about EU unity
column4: after a shaky start when EU member states closed borders and slapped export bans on medical supplies.

column1: Having chided EU governments in the past for failing to support Italy in its hour of need
column2: Von der Leyen struck a more optimistic note
column3: saying member states had overcome their differences; including by agreeing a €750bn (£688bn) recovery plan.

column1: “We turned fear and division between member states into confidence in our union
column2: ” she claimed. She said the EU needed more powers to tackle future pandemics and vowed to create an agency for biomedical advanced research and development
column3: an equivalent to the US agency funding vaccine research
column4: Barda.

column1: Without naming Donald Trump
column2: she made a few swipes at the US president
column3: criticising “vaccine nationalism” and major powers
column4: who are “pulling out of institutions or taking them hostage for their own interests”. But the EU could be on a collision course with a new Democratic incumbent of the White House
column5: as Von der Leyen promised to revive plans for an EU digital tax in the absence of an international agreement. Barack Obama’s administration complained that Brussels was unfairly singling out US tech giants.

column1: As widely trailed
column2: Von der Leyen proposed the EU should cut greenhouse gas emissions by “at least 55%” by 2030 compared with 1990 levels. Green campaigners have welcomed the increase in ambition (upping the current 40% reduction target) but fear “an accounting trick” in how the new target will be calculated.

column1: Preoccupied by coronavirus and foreign policy crises
column2: EU leaders have given little attention to Brexit in recent months. Von der Leyen said the chances of an agreement were fading with every day that passed
column3: as she warned the UK government not to renege on the Brexit withdrawal agreement Boris Johnson signed last year. Noting that the Brexit deal had been ratified by MEPs and MPs
column4: Von der Leyen said it could not be “unilaterally changed
column5: disregarded
column6: disapplied. This is a matter of law and trust and good faith.”

column1: Von der Leyen
column2: who is the first female president in the commission’s 63-year history
column3: said the EU had to do more to confront racism in the wake of the Black Lives Matter protests. In a move that could trigger conflict with sovereignty-conscious member states
column4: she proposed extending the list of EU crimes to cover all forms of hate crime and hate speech
column5: whether linked to race
column6: religion
column7: gender or sexuality.

column1: She promised to appoint the European commission’s first-ever anti-racism coordinator “to keep the issue “at the top of our agenda”.

column1: 2;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/sep/13/party-disputes-thwart-angela-merkels-hopes-of-an-orderly-succession";2020-09-13;"Party disputes thwart Angela Merkel’s hopes of an orderly succession";"The German chancellor is standing down next year
column2: but the handover is not going to plan for the three main rivals

column1: On the rocky road towards Germany’s post-Merkel future
column2: one thing used to seem certain: the shoes of the first female
column3: Protestant East German scientist at the top of German politics would be filled by a male Catholic Rhinelander with a law degree.

column1: That description still fits all the three official candidates who at a party congress in early December will pitch to lead Angela Merkel’s Christian Democratic Union
column2: the indispensable behemoth of postwar politics in Europe’s largest economy.

column1: But the pandemic has realigned the stars for some of its top politicians to the extent that CDU insiders worry the leadership race’s most likely outcome no longer looks ideal
column2: and the ideal outcome for the greater good of the party looks unlikely.

column1: The impressive lead the conservatives have built up through their handling of the Covid-19 threat
column2: they fear
column3: could melt away as a squabbling party emerges from the shadow of the chancellor that has unified them for the last 15 years.

column1: Merkel
column2: who will not be running for a fifth term at federal elections in 2021
column3: has already had to tear up her succession plan once: her designated continuity candidate
column4: Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer
column5: who took charge of the CDU in December 2018
column6: announced her resignation a year later
column7: her authority diminished by a series of internal power struggles.

column1: Before the onset of Covid-19
column2: a new chair was due to be crowned at a party congress in late April. Armin Laschet
column3: the moderate state premier of North-Rhine-Westphalia
column4: looked like the top contender after winning over the ambitious young health minister
column5: Jens Spahn
column6: as his number two.

column1: Laschet
column2: a loyal defender of Merkel’s refugee policy in 2015
column3: also has the advantage that his home turf is Germany’s most populous state
column4: providing almost 30% of the 1
column5: 001 delegates who get to cast their vote on the future leadership. But the 59-year-old with Wallonian roots has floundered during the pandemic
column6: in which he emerged as one of the most prominent voices of relaxing social distancing restrictions – only to then have to coordinate Germany’s first “second lockdown” following a Covid-19 outbreak at an abattoir in Gütersloh. In the eyes of many voters
column7: “pushy Laschet” looked more concerned with local business lobbyists than the welfare of the country as a whole.

column1: “It’s hard to imagine Laschet staring down Putin
column2: Xi or Trump
column3: ” said one previously sympathetic CDU delegate.

column1: As Laschet’s popularity ratings nosedived
column2: another conservative politician rose to unseen heights: polls showed the Bavarian premier Markus Söder
column3: who had introduced a lockdown in Germany’s southernmost state before it came into place in the rest of the country
column4: to be the most popular politician in the country.

column1: “In a world that is increasingly marked by insecurities – through migration movements
column2: climate change or global pandemics – we are seeing a high preparedness to trade some basic rights in exchange for stability
column3: ” says Wolfgang Merkel (no relation)
column4: a political scientist at Berlin’s Humboldt University.

column1: A recent study authored by Merkel shows populist attitudes in Germany to be in steep decline after rising during the refugee crisis – a trend
column2: he says
column3: which was accelerated by strong statesmanship by established parties at the height of the pandemic.

column1: “For governments
column2: there is a new premium on leaders who can demonstrate strength and act decisively
column3: albeit without the populist rhetoric. For the CDU
column4: that means polls will be crucial for choosing its chancellor candidate
column5: and for now they point towards Söder rather than Laschet.”

column1: As the leader of the CDU’s sister party
column2: the Bavarian Christian Social Union (CSU)
column3: Söder won’t be in the running when delegates gather for a socially distanced one-day congress in Stuttgart this winter
column4: most likely on 4 December.

column1: But he could become the two parties’ candidate for the chancellory – an option that has been tried before
column2: with an unhappy ending for the conservatives. Both in 1980 and 2002 the CDU/CSU lost an election as a result
column3: and many still believe that Bavarian politicians with their broad accents and overtly Catholic brand of conservatism simply cannot win enough votes north of the river Main.

column1: Söder’s growing band of vocal admirers point out that their man is in fact from Franconia
column2: and a Protestant at that. “He’s the least Bavarian leader the CSU has ever had
column3: ” says one fan.

column1: For the 6ft 4in southerner to run
column2: however
column3: he would need the support of the head of the CDU in Berlin: something that Laschet would be as unlikely to offer as Friedrich Merz
column4: the veteran hardliner and Merkel critic who is seen as the number two in the three-horse race for the leadership.

column1: Some Christian Democrat MPs envision a “dream ticket” of Söder and Spahn
column2: whose star has also shone brightly during the pandemic. But for the openly gay 40-year-old to run for the leadership would require reneging on his deal with Laschet. “In politics everyone loves betrayal
column3: but no one loves a traitor
column4: ” said an official at the CDU headquarters when asked about such an option.

column1: There’s an outside chance that the fiendishly complicated reshuffle at the top of Germany’s biggest party could benefit the outside candidate: Norbert Röttgen
column2: the third Catholic lawyer from Rhineland-Westphalia on the ballot.

column1: After leading the CDU to a crushing defeat in his home state in 2012 and losing his job in Merkel’s second cabinet as a result
column2: the former environment minister has slowly crept back into the limelight through his role as chair of the Bundestag’s foreign affairs committee.

column1: As the Alexei Navalny/novichok affair has forced Germany to reconsider its approach to Russia
column2: Röttgen’s outspoken views have impressed conservatives who are frustrated with Laschet and Söder’s soft-pedalling. But the suave
column3: sometimes over-confident 55-year-old’s biggest asset could be his openness to ceding the chancellor candidacy to Söder. If Röttgen made it to the second round
column4: he might end up with the votes of the embittered supporters of one of the two frontrunners almost by accident.

column1: Merkel’s line of succession
column2: which has been planned
column3: postponed and redrawn continuously over the last decade
column4: could in the end be a matter of chance.

column1: 3;"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2020/sep/07/why-the-germans-do-it-better-by-john-kampfner-review-in-praise-of-the-powerhouse";2020-09-07;"Why the Germans Do it Better by John Kampfner review – in praise of the powerhouse";"A veteran journalist’s even-handed hymn to Germany underlines why Britain will need its help in a post-Brexit world
Books about the contemporary state of a country are hard to pull off. They need to capture the sweep of recent history and sundry quirks of culture
column2: while weaving in their author’s passions
column3: aversions and contacts. Add to this the publisher’s requirements that anything currently written about Britain’s relations with Europe is framed polemically and the result is a title such as Why the Germans Do it Better: Notes from a Grown-Up Country.

column1: John Kampfner’s polemic treads the accompanying line between curiosity and sententiousness. It taps smartly into the hunch that Germany has got a lot of things right that Britain has not
column2: not least in the recent response to Covid-19.

column1: A veteran newspaper correspondent in Germany during the Wendezeit (“time of changes”)
column2: after the collapse of East Germany in 1989/90
column3: he is drawn to revisit the country and
column4: as next month marks 30 years of reunification
column5: it’s an ideal moment to take stock. Inevitably
column6: Angela Merkel looms large
column7: having been in power for 15 of those years. In essence
column8: this is a hymn of praise to the Federal Republic under her leadership. For those unhappy about the direction of a Britain “mired in monolingual mediocrity”
column9: as Kampfner puts it
column10: thriving on a TV diet of war documentaries and tone-deaf British politicians
column11: it looks like a very attractive alternative indeed.

column1: Merkel’s status as an icon is sealed by admiration for her bravely open-handed policy on migration in the refugee crisis of 2015
column2: when the rest of Europe was parsimonious with its assistance. As a well-researched chapter here on those events and their aftermath concludes
column3: this was the moment that created the view of Merkel as the high priestess of liberal values.

column1: In other areas
column2: more questionable assumptions abound. On a trip back across the old east
column3: Kampfner praises the amount of money spent on trying to glue the two uneven parts of a country divided by war and superpower standoff back together and cheers the €2tn devoted to that endeavour. The successes are nicely evoked: we discover that Leipzig
column4: the smog-laden city of the 1989 revolution
column5: is so fashionable and popular for investors that it has been dubbed “Hypezig”.

column1: Germany is placid
column2: unshowy and diligent. It can also be smug

column1: Yet the question that worries German policymakers is how vast the economic gap has remained. Its own annual Unity report flags up worrying gaps in pensions and earnings and how slowly these are closing
column2: more so than was intended by the optimistic architects of reunification.

column1: So
column2: yes
column3: Germany is placid
column4: unshowy and diligent. It can also be smug
column5: as underlined by the senior official whose analysis of populism is that “other countries have not learned the same lessons as we have”. In the shape of the AfD
column6: Kampfner finds the resurgent far right peddling a “collection bowl of grievances” with a nasty racist edge to boot. Here is the paradox of German politics - the country that is lauded as the most consensual produces election results in which a large portion of the popular vote now goes to parties of the extreme right and left
column7: and anti-vaxx and anti-mask demos happen on a large scale
column8: even while the Covid-19 response is widely praised.

column1: Being grown up means responsibility in the wider world and here the record is chequered. The laggardly approach to raising defence spending (the money matters less than the implied drift away from the western alliance)
column2: armed forces beset by interminable internal problems and a determination to plough on with the controversial Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline project reflect a fragmented geopolitical outlook in Berlin. The price of the “grown up” – corporatism that powers the German economy – is also that a lot of dubious stuff gets swept under the carpet
column3: as the saga of the car industry and the still unfolding emissions scandal shows.

column1: So to Brexit
column2: which
column3: as Kampfner points out
column4: has strained the “frenemy” relationship. Since 2016
column5: it has not looked as if either side has much appetite to extend an olive branch and those of us who wince at the “you crazy Brits” preachiness must concur that there has been a breach in relations that urgently needs to be healed. Britain’s post-EU future will in no small part depend on rebuilding an affinity with the European powerhouse and rubbing along together in a fragmented world. Whether Brexiters like it or not
column6: the heirs to Merkel will shape the next lurching chapter of our island story.

column1: Anne McElvoy is senior editor of the Economist and author of The Saddled Cow: East Germany’s Life and Legacy
• Why the Germans Do it Better: Notes from a Grown-Up Country by John Kampfner is published by Atlantic Books (£16.99). To order a copy go to guardianbookshop.com. Free UK p&p over £15

column1: 4;"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2020/sep/06/the-observer-view-on-russias-poisoning-of-alexei-navalny";2020-09-06;"The Observer view on Russia's poisoning of Alexei Navalny";"Western condemnation is worthless. But if Angela Merkel cancels the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline
column2: Putin will take notice

column1: Alexei Navalny
column2: who lies critically ill in a German hospital after being poisoned in Siberia
column3: is Russia’s unofficial leader of the opposition and the politician Vladimir Putin fears most. Relatively young
column4: resourceful and smart
column5: he has bravely defied many previous attempts to silence him
column6: including imprisonment and physical attacks. Navalny is not easily dismissed as a pro-western dissident or leftwing intellectual. He is a Russian patriot
column7: a daring
column8: Jason Bourne-like figure who recently flew drones over the private dachas of the Kremlin elite to expose their apparently corruptly acquired wealth
column9: then posted videos online.

column1: That the Kremlin is responsible for Navalny’s plight is not in serious doubt. Whether Putin had prior knowledge of the plot
column2: or personally authorised it
column3: will probably never be known. As usual
column4: the Kremlin is hiding behind a wall of denials and absurd claims
column5: such as that Navalny fell ill after flying on an empty stomach. But his German doctors are unequivocal. He was poisoned by a chemical nerve agent
column6: novichok
column7: which the Russian state secretly developed and which only Russia is known to have used.

column1: Novichok refers to a group of nerve agents developed by the Soviet Union in the 1970s and 80s to elude international restrictions on chemical weapons. Like other nerve agents
column2: they are organophosphate compounds
column3: but the chemicals used to make them
column4: and their final structures
column5: are considered classified in the UK
column6: the US and other countries.

column1: The most potent of the novichok substances are considered to be more lethal than VX
column2: the most deadly of the familiar nerve agents
column3: which include sarin
column4: tabun and soman.

column1: Novichok agents work in a similar way
column2: by massively over-stimulating muscles and glands. Treatment for novichok exposure would be the same as for other nerve agents
column3: namely with atropine
column4: diazepam and potentially drugs called oximes.

column1: The chemical structures of novichok agents were made public in 2008 by Vil Mirzayanov
column2: a former Russian scientist living in the US
column3: but the structures have never been publicly confirmed. It is thought they can be made in different forms
column4: including as a dust aerosol.

column1: The novichoks are known as binary agents because they only become lethal  after mixing two otherwise harmless components. According to Mirzayanov
column2: they are 10 to 100 times more toxic than conventional nerve agents.

column1: Why choose this particular moment to assassinate a longstanding opponent? One possible reason is widespread political unrest in Russia’s far east
column2: which Navalny tried to tap into before he was attacked. For a worried Kremlin
column3: the pro-democracy uprising in neighbouring Belarus sets a dangerous precedent he could exploit. Another possible reason is the negative impact of the pandemic on Russia’s economy
column4: which is in freefall
column5: and on Putin’s personal standing.

column1: The timing may also have been influenced by events further afield. Putin reportedly expects Donald Trump to be re-elected in November. According to US intelligence
column2: he is doing his covert best to help him. But if Joe Biden wins
column3: Putin’s easy ride will end. American tolerance for his anti-western subversion operations and malign meddling in places such as Ukraine
column4: the Baltic republics
column5: the Balkans and the Middle East will fall. The same goes for the regime’s internal repression and its egregious habit of killing or jailing critics.

column1: Who attacked Navalny is not realistically in doubt. The bigger
column2: unanswered question is what can the western democracies do about it? As after the Salisbury novichok poisonings
column3: there has been a chorus of condemnation from just about everyone except Trump. As in 2018
column4: sanctions and expulsions of Russian diplomats are mooted. Russia has been sternly told it must provide an explanation for breaching international law and the prohibition on using chemical weapons.

column1: Putin reportedly expects Donald Trump to be re-elected. If Joe Biden wins
column2: his easy ride will end

column1: Yet those making such calls
column2: including the EU
column3: Nato
column4: the UN and Britain
column5: know perfectly well that Putin will do no such thing. If punitive measures are imposed
column6: he will ride them out
column7: as he did over Crimea. Contemptuously flouting western liberal opinion matters far more to him than any damage that may be done to Russia and its people.

column1: But there is a way to hit him where it hurts and it’s in the hands of Germany’s chancellor
column2: Angela Merkel
column3: who has been outspoken over the Navalny affair. As urged by Germany’s Greens and many in her ruling coalition
column4: Merkel could and should scrap the Russia-to-Germany Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline
column5: which
column6: if completed
column7: will greatly enrich Putin and his larcenous henchmen. Cancellation could also reduce Russian leverage in Europe
column8: sending a powerful message Putin could not ignore.

column1: More important still
column2: abandoning the pipeline would be an environmental boon. It’s crazy to be boosting gas capacity during a climate emergency
column3: thereby increasing use of high-carbon fossil fuels. Merkel should perform a double U-turn: scrap Nord Stream 2 and lift her veto on nuclear power generation to assure Germany’s future energy supply. It’s asking a lot. But Merkel is nearing the end of her career and has political capital in the bank. To adapt her famous words in 2015: “Sie kann es schaffen” – she can manage it.

column1: 5;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/sep/05/navalny-poisoning-forces-merkels-party-to-ask-how-do-we-hit-back-at-putin";2020-09-05;"Navalny poisoning forces Merkel’s party to ask: how to hit back at Putin?";"The strength of the German chancellor’s condemnation of Russia was a surprise – and the multi-billion Nord Stream project could now be at risk
Germany is demanding answers from the Kremlin over the confirmed poisoning of the Russian opposition politician Alexei Navalny
column2: but is struggling to find methods to extract them that don’t involve a humiliating loss of face.

column1: The assertive manner in which Angela Merkel announced on Wednesday that Navalny
column2: who is lying in an induced coma in a Berlin hospital
column3: had been targeted with a nerve agent from the novichok group raised eyebrows
column4: and not just in the German capital.

column1: Stepping out in front of the press in person
column2: the chancellor described the “attempted murder by poisoning” as “an attack on the fundamental values and basic rights to which we are committed”.

column1: Her foreign and defence ministers reiterated the message on camera: three of the most senior figures in Merkel’s cabinet made themselves personally accountable
column2: knowing the rest of their careers could be judged on whether they will follow up words with actions.

column1: The tone was even more surprising because many felt Germany had soft-pedalled last year after the murder of a Chechen dissident in a park in central Berlin
column2: at the hands of what federal prosecutors believe was an assassin hired by the Russian state: an incident on paper more severe than Navalny’s
column3: who ended up in Berlin for treatment almost by accident
column4: at the request of his friends and relatives.

column1: For years
column2: we have misunderstood the game of chess that the Kremlin has been playing with us
column3: and now we cannot pull the sanction strings any tighter without garrotting ourselves

column1: In the case of Zelimkhan Khangoshvili
column2: or the attempted poisoning of Sergei Skripal in Britain in 2018
column3: there were suspects whose movements could be traced back to Russia. With Navalny
column4: there were only traces of the rare nerve agent
column5: which western intelligence agencies believe to be a sole prerogative of the Russian state.

column1: Instead
column2: German exasperation over the novichok find is also an expression of a broader disillusionment with its own “special relationship” with Russia. “Germany’s diplomatic approach to Russia has run out of road this week
column3: ” said Roderich Kiesewetter
column4: a member of Merkel’s Christian Democratic Union (CDU) who sits on the foreign affairs committee of the Bundestag.

column1: “For years
column2: we have misunderstood the game of chess that the Kremlin has been playing with us
column3: ” Kiesewetter told the Observer. “And now we cannot pull the sanction strings any tighter without garrotting ourselves.”

column1: In the postwar period
column2: German diplomacy towards Russia has tried – and often struggled – to reconcile a tough stance over security or human rights with a friendly dialogue that pays respect to a joint history of bloody wars and shared cultural memories.

column1: The question of which of these strands to prioritise cuts across traditional party lines
column2: not just between east and west but also north and south
column3: with the Bavarian sister party to Merkel’s CDU
column4: the CSU
column5: openly in favour of relaxing sanctions against Russia.

column1: “Germany has traditionally pursued a twin-pillar strategy with Russia: on the one hand confrontation
column2: on the other hand strategic selective engagement
column3: ” said Fabian Burkhardt
column4: a political scientist at the Leibniz Institute for East and Southeast European Studies in Regensburg.

column1: “But the use of a chemical nerve agent against a political opponent has genuinely shaken the second pillar. Merkel’s reaction on Wednesday spoke of a deep-seated frustration that has built up over the years. At the moment it is hard to see where the common basis for a strategic engagement could be.”
Merkel’s own approach during her 15 years in power
column2: while decidedly sceptical towards Vladimir Putin’s Russia
column3: was never openly aggressive. The Nord Stream 2 project
column4: a twin pipeline running from the Narva Bay in Russia to the German town of Lubmin
column5: was carried over from her Social Democrat predecessor Gerhard Schröder in spite of criticism from the US
column6: the European commission and EU member states in eastern Europe and the Baltics.

column1: As recently as Tuesday Merkel insisted that the €9.5bn project
column2: which is 94% finished
column3: was still on course to be completed. Party allies argue that the commitment to phase out nuclear and coal
column4: coupled with the slow build-up of power transmission routes from the windy north to the country’s south
column5: has made the import of Russian natural gas indispensable.

column1: In the wake of the Navalny poisoning
column2: however
column3: a U-turn on the profitable project may be Merkel’s only way to hit Putin “where it hurts”
column4: as the news weekly Der Spiegel wrote. Political voices calling for a moratorium on the project
column5: mainly from the Green party
column6: but also from the pro-business Free Democrats and Merkel’s own CDU
column7: have grown in volume.

column1: Berlin has not asked for [sanctions] and the location of the poisoning
column2: on Russian territory
column3: makes it different to the incident in Salisbury

column1: The pipeline
column2: which is owned by the Kremlin-controlled Gazprom
column3: “indirectly finances a regime that does not shy away from using banned weapons of mass destruction”
column4: Annalena Baerbock
column5: the Greens’ co-leader
column6: said on Friday.

column1: With work on the pipeline on hold after construction companies withdrew under threat of US sanctions
column2: critics say the time to stop the project has never been better: pulling the plug could be presented as a decisive political act rather than being cowed by American threats.

column1: Penalties for breach of contract
column2: estimated by the European Commission in 2017 to be as high as €800m
column3: would pale in comparison with the multibillion-euro pandemic rescue funds.

column1: Some economists also question whether Germany really needs the pipeline to keep its lights on at all. “Demand for natural gas in Germany has always been lower than forecast in the last 10 years and will decline in the future” says Claudia Kemfert of the German Institute for Economic Research (DIW).
Europe
column2: she argues
column3: could maintain its natural gas use almost at the same level even if Russia ended its deliveries completely
column4: by shipping in more liquefied natural gas from the Middle East
column5: west Africa or America.

column1: In Merkel’s chancellory such calculations will be studied with close interest in the coming weeks
column2: even as Berlin publicly calls for a joint European rather than a unilateral German response to the Navalny case.

column1: So far
column2: the EU as a whole has condemned “in the strongest possible terms the poisoning of the Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny” but there has been limited pressure within the bloc for sanctions.

column1: Despite the insistence of Josep Borrell
column2: the EU’s high representative for foreign affairs
column3: that such a move has not been ruled out there remains little appetite for it among the larger member states.

column1: “The Baltic states wanted them
column2: of course
column3: but Berlin has not asked for it and the location of the poisoning
column4: on Russian territory
column5: makes it different to the incident in Salisbury
column6: ” said one EU diplomat in Brussels.

column1: The incident has
column2: however
column3: thwarted what appeared to be a concerted attempt by the French president Emmanuel Macron to build bridges with the Kremlin. Plans for a visit by Macron to Moscow later this month along with a summit of foreign and defence ministers from the two countries are now in doubt.

column1: A meeting in September 2019 in Moscow had opened a “strategic dialogue” called for by Macron
column2: in a move that surprised European partners. “It was ill advised anyway and this has shown why
column3: ” said an EU source.

column1: 6;"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2020/sep/03/the-guardian-view-on-putin-and-navalnys-poisoning-actions-speak-louder-than-words";2020-09-03;"The Guardian view on Putin and Navalny’s poisoning: actions speak louder than words";"European countries have voiced their outrage at the attempted assassination of the Russian opposition leader. But what will they do?
Outrageous and reprehensible
column2: certainly. The international reaction to the poisoning of Russian opposition leader
column3: Alexei Navalny
column4: got that much right. But Germany’s description of the act as “astounding” was less apt. Few were surprised when Berlin confirmed on Wednesday that a nerve agent from the Novichok family had been used
column5: tying the attack firmly to the highest levels of the Russian state
column6: though Moscow has denied involvement. Mr Navalny is being treated in Germany and remains gravely ill.

column1: The question is what follows the condemnation. The wife of the British policeman who almost died after investigating the 2018 Salisbury poisonings gave a tart response to Boris Johnson’s denunciation: “Actions speak louder than words.” The attack on defector Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia – which led to the death of a British woman
column2: Dawn Sturgess – stirred the west to concerted diplomatic action
column3: with 20 countries carrying out a mass expulsion of Russian diplomats alleged to be spies. But it had little discernible effect
column4: and with fewer foreign diplomats left in Moscow
column5: countries are more reluctant to lose them to tit-for-tat expulsions.

column1: Angela Merkel was unusually vocal in her condemnation on Wednesday
column2: saying the attack was
column3: beyond doubt
column4: attempted murder
column5: which posed “very serious questions that only the Russian government can answer – and must answer”. But she was also adamant that Germany will press ahead with the Nord Stream 2 pipeline
column6: which could double the amount of gas brought into Europe from Russia.

column1: Mr Navalny had suggested action to rein in Russia should target those with close links to Mr Putin
column2: including in London. In the UK
column3: Magnitsky-style legislation and unexplained wealth orders give the government new options. It shows little interest. The long-delayed Russia report
column4: finally released in July
column5: found that British government and intelligence agencies failed to conduct any proper assessment of Kremlin attempts to interfere with the 2016 Brexit referendum. The Conservative party has received more than £3m from wealthy Soviet-born donors
column6: many of them with close ties to Mr Putin
column7: and a Brexit government wants to maximise foreign investment.

column1: To no one’s surprise
column2: though the White House has condemned the poisoning
column3: Donald Trump has barely deigned to acknowledge it. The US president was unhappy at the extent of the 2018 expulsions. He has yet to challenge Vladimir Putin over intelligence reports that Russia paid bounties to the Taliban for fatal attacks on US troops in Afghanistan. He suggested the Russian president’s denials of election meddling in 2016 bore more weight than US intelligence assessments
column4: and dismisses the reports that Kremlin-backed groups are trying to interfere in November’s election on his behalf.

column1: While many have suggested that the attack on Mr Navalny may have been sparked by Moscow’s anxieties about the uprising in Belarus
column2: and the protests in the Siberian city of Khabarovsk
column3: some have also wondered whether the prospect of a Biden administration might have prompted action sooner rather than later. What is certain is that while the Kremlin faces little or no cost for interfering in foreign democracies
column4: and not much more for endangering foreign citizens with attacks on foreign soil
column5: it will be confident that it can act with impunity within its own borders. Others cannot claim to be surprised by the results."

column1: 7;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/sep/03/merkel-pressured-to-end-nord-stream-2-support-after-navalny-poisoning";2020-09-03;"Merkel pressured to end Nord Stream 2 support after Navalny poisoning";"German opposition calls on chancellor to use gas pipeline project to warn Kremlin

Angela Merkel is under growing domestic pressure to end her support for the joint German-Russian Nord Stream 2 pipeline project over the confirmed poisoning of the Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny.

The German Green party called on the chancellor to use the nearly completed infrastructure project to press the Kremlin into answering allegations over what Merkel called the “silencing” of Navalny with a novichok nerve agent.
“This openly attempted murder through the Kremlin’s mafia-like structures should not just worry us but needs to have real consequences
column2: ” said Katrin Göring-Eckardt
column3: the co-chair of the Greens in the Bundestag.

column1: “Nord Stream 2 is no longer something we can jointly pursue with Russia
column2: ” said the politician for the ecological party
column3: currently second in polls to Merkel’s CDU and a likely contender for the next coalition government.

column1: Russia insisted there was no reason for the west to accuse it over Navalny and said any response from Germany or other countries would be premature. The Kremlin claimed hospital tests carried out on Navalny inside Russia before he was flown to Berlin found nothing suspicious.
“There are no grounds to accuse the Russian state. And we are not inclined to accept any accusations in this respect
column2: ” Vladimir Putin’s press spokesman
column3: Dmitry Peskov
column4: said.

column1: Instead
column2: senior Russian figures offered their own counter-explanations for Navalny’s illness. Sergei Naryshkin
column3: the head of Moscow’s foreign intelligence service
column4: said western intelligence agencies were to blame. Andrei Lugovoi – who was charged by the UK with poisoning Alexander Litvinenko in 2006 with radioactive tea– accused Berlin. The Germans had contaminated Navalny with novichok
column5: he said.

column1: The EU’s foreign policy chief Josep Borrell called on Moscow to cooperate with an international probe into the poisoning and said the 27-nation bloc would not rule out sanctions. Brussels “reserves the right to take appropriate actions
column2: including through restrictive measures”
column3: Borrell said in a statement.

column1: Calls to permanently halt the construction of the two 764-mile (1
column2: 230km) pipelines beneath the Baltic Sea
column3: from the Narva Bay in Russia to the German town of Lubmin
column4: were echoed within the German chancellor’s own party.

column1: Norbert Röttgen
column2: the chairman of the Bundestag’s committee on foreign affairs and a candidate for the CDU leadership
column3: told German media on Wednesday that completing the joint project would amount to encouraging Putin’s “inhuman and contemptuous politics”.

column1: “After the poisoning of Navalny we need a strong European answer
column2: which Putin understands
column3: ” Röttgen said. “The EU should jointly decide to stop Nord Stream 2.”

column1: The tabloid newspaper Bild also called for a change of mind from the chancellor
column2: who as recently as Tuesday reiterated her government’s intention to complete the multibillion-euro infrastructure project.

column1: “The government can condemn the poisoning of Putin critic Navalny ‘in the strongest terms possible’
column2: ” said a Bild editorial on Thursday. “It can show its ‘dismay’. It can ‘urgently’ call on the Kremlin to explain itself. But as long as it acts in collusion with Putin on the Nord Stream 2 pipeline
column3: all these declarations are just empty words”.

column1: Not just the US
column2: but also states in eastern Europe and the Baltics have repeatedly expressed concerns about the pipeline since the former German chancellor Gerhard Schröder approved its construction in 2005
column3: saying it will increase Putin’s geopolitical influence.

column1: The Nord Stream 2 twin pipeline is nearly finished
column2: with only about 160 out of a planned 1
column3: 220km (760 miles) remaining.

column1: However
column2: the construction of the gas project has been on halt since late December last year
column3: when the Swiss pipeline manufacturer Allseas ceased its work after threats of targeted US sanctions.

column1: The German utility firm Uniper
column2: one of Gazprom’s five financial partners in the project
column3: last month conceded there was an increasing possibility the pipeline would never be completed.

column1: Though set into motion by Merkel’s centre-left predecessor shortly before the start of her tenure
column2: the construction project is of vital economic importance for the country because Germany is likely to need more imported gas in the future – and particularly for the chancellor’s own constituency in the north-eastern state of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern.

column1: The German broadsheet Süddeutsche Zeitung commented on Thursday that Merkel’s strong condemnation of Navalny’s poisoning would make it harder to square the circle of her support for the joint project.
“The government waved goodbye to a fiction on Wednesday
column2: ” the newspaper’s correspondent Daniel Brössler commented. “A fiction that made it possible to slap Russia with sanctions one day and court it as a business partner the next.”

column1: The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) said Navalny’s poisoning was a matter of grave concern. It said the use of chemical weapons by anyone under any circumstances was reprehensible and “wholly contrary to the legal norms established by the international community”.
In April 2018 undercover officers from Russia’s GRU military spy agency tried to hack the OPCW
column2: which is based in The Hague. They were arrested in a car park opposite the building. The mission took place shortly after the novichok poisoning of Sergei and Yulia Skripal by two GRU assassins.

column1: The OPCW said it was monitoring the Navalny situation and was ready to engage with any state that needed its help.

column1: 8;"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2020/sep/03/germany-extend-furlough-scheme-britain-kurzarbeit";2020-09-03;"Germany is right to extend its furlough scheme. Why won't Britain do the same?";"The Kurzarbeit part-time working scheme is criticised as expensive – but it has protected German jobs and skills
Alongside Zoom
column2: Netflix and Amazon
column3: Germanophilia has to be counted as one of the prime victors of the pandemic that has so thoroughly remade the world this year. It isn’t hard to see why: for every collapse of Anglo-American leadership
column4: there seems to have been a German counter-example. From testing to lockdowns
column5: contact tracing to hospital beds
column6: Germany has thrived where Britain has floundered. Most recently
column7: the decision of Merkel’s coalition government to extend the popular furlough scheme known as Kurzarbeit (literally
column8: “short work”)
column9: is being greeted by many as another example of Teutonic good sense.

column1: The Kurzarbeit programme
column2: in which the government provides workers whose hours have been reduced with a minimum of 60% of their lost pay
column3: has been credited by many with softening the economic blow of the pandemic. Shekhar Aiyar
column4: the IMF’s mission chief for Germany
column5: praised the programme lavishly in an interview
column6: claiming that Germany
column7: by expanding the scope of the scheme and making it more flexible
column8: “is doing precisely what should be done in deep recessions”. Dominic Rushe attributes a substantial portion of the difference between the US unemployment crisis and Germany’s moderate bump in jobless numbers to Kurzarbeit
column9: while the Economist claims that for many experts
column10: “the model for a Covid-19 furlough scheme has been Germany’s”.

column1: The scheme wasn’t built in a day. It first emerged in the early 20th century
column2: when it was instituted as a means of softening the mass unemployment that followed the first world war in Germany – in 1924
column3: nearly a quarter of all Germans were on Kurzarbeit
column4: while another 11% were unemployed. The same system was largely adapted by West Germany after the war
column5: and it helped to soften unemployment during recessions in 1967
column7: and 1983. Beyond the obvious benefit of reducing unemployment
column8: the scheme is particularly adept at ensuring that highly trained workers can continue to use their skills despite recessions. Thomas Fuster
column9: writing in the Neue Zürcher Zeitung
column10: claims that it is “no coincidence that Kurzarbeit is most commonly found in countries where on-the job training is especially important”. Companies that invest heavily in their employees are more heavily motivated to invest in their retention. Companies – and countries – whose economies rely largely on unskilled labour are more comfortable with unstable labour markets.

column1: The scheme is not without its problems. There are
column2: of course
column3: concerns about the costs. Christian von Stetten of Merkel’s CDU complained that the programme would constitute a “sabbatical at taxpayers’ expense”
column4: while Katja Suding
column5: a politician from the liberal FDP
column6: claimed that it amounted to “burning taxpayers’ money”. These claims are often coupled with the argument that the system merely delays the loss of jobs
column7: rather than preventing them. This seems not to have been the case during the global financial crisis of 2008
column8: when Kurzarbeit was largely credited with softening the blow to Germany’s labour market. Yet there are substantial concerns that the scheme could help prop up companies
column9: or even entire industries
column10: that should properly be contracting. The Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung warned in 2019 that the German auto industry
column11: which was already struggling with a bad export market prior to the pandemic
column12: should not be propped up with Kurzarbeit indefinitely. Now – after profiting from a massive bailout in 2008 – German automakers continue to rely on government subsidies thanks to the programme.

column1: There are also substantial concerns that the system is rife for abuse – companies can easily claim that their workers are spending fewer hours on the job
column2: while business goes on as usual. Yet the number of such cases seems to be limited. Currently
column3: there are just 900 cases under investigation
column4: while 880
column5: 000 companies have claimed Kurzarbeit during the pandemic. A more substantial problem has to do with the nature of the scheme itself. It’s easy to tell whether a factory worker is working less than a full day. It’s very hard to tell whether a computer programmer
column6: lawyer or graphic designer has finished their work in six hours or eight
column7: particularly when everyone is working from home. In one columnist’s view
column8: newspapers that sent their entire editorial staff into Kurzarbeit risk defrauding taxpayers
column9: given that the competitive culture that had long thrived in journalism prior to the pandemic makes it virtually impossible to imagine that editors are in fact working part time.

column1: For all of these problems
column2: the decision to extend coronavirus Kurzarbeit protections has been widely praised in Germany. It’s not hard to see why. As serious as these issues might be
column3: they pale in comparison to the kind of mass unemployment the US is currently experiencing
column4: and investing in the retention of highly qualified workers now may prop up some failing industries
column5: but it will also help others to stay competitive through an unprecedented global crisis. The question
column6: really
column7: isn’t why the Germans are extending their programme; given the widespread acclaim for it among both trade unions and economists
column8: the question is much more why Britain is still resisting extending its own furlough programme.

column3: killed by nerve agent poison
column4: hopes Angela Merkel will put more pressure on Moscow after attack of Navalny

column1: The father of the woman who died in the Wiltshire nerve agent poisonings said he hoped the novichok attack on the Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny would lead to fresh scrutiny of Moscow
column2: adding that he believed Germany might work harder to get answers than the UK had done since the death of his daughter.

column1: Stan Sturgess
column2: father of Dawn
column3: who died in July 2018
column4: said he felt Germany’s chancellor
column5: Angela Merkel
column6: would ask more searching questions than did Boris Johnson following the novichok poisonings in Salisbury. Johnson was the foreign secretary at the time of the Wiltshire poisonings.

column1: He added that the revelations from the German government that it believed Navalny
column2: who is being treated in Berlin
column3: had been poisoned with the deadly nerve agent had brought back awful memories.

column1: Sturgess said he was not surprised to learn novichok apparently had been used again. “As soon as I heard Navalny had been poisoned I thought it was novichok. It’s the Russians’ calling card. The Russians want everyone to know it’s them. We always said it could happen again.”

Sturgess said: “At least Angela Merkel may ask more questions than Boris Johnson was ever going to ask. Maybe more pressure will be put on the Russians now. Boris never asked anything. We may get some more answers. I don’t know if we’ll get justice but everything opens the door a bit more.
“It brings back terrible memories
column2: it churns it all up again. It’s scary times for anyone who goes against the Russians.”

column1: Dawn Sturgess’s partner
column2: Charlie Rowley
column3: who is still recovering from the effects of novichok poisoning
column4: said: “They’ve done it once and got away with it and they can do it again and they feel they can get away with it with no come-back.” Rowley suffers from eye problems
column5: shortness of breath and mental health issues
column6: which he blames on his exposure to novichok.

column1: Rowley suggested the evidence continued to grow against Russia. “It comes across more and more that it leads back to Russia. Because it’s happened again
column2: you don’t know when it’s going to stop
column3: or if it’s going to stop.”

column1: Rowley said he was angry. “I want to find out what happened. I’m upset it’s happened again but I hope we get some results this time. I’d like questions to be answered and I hope this time around whoever is in charge will push forward and try to get some answers. I hope they get to the bottom of it.”
The wife of Nick Bailey
column2: the police officer who almost died after investigating the 2018 poisonings
column3: said there had been no justice for the victims of the Salisbury attack including for her husband and Dawn Sturgess’ family. Replying to a tweet from the prime minister in which he condemned the attack on Navalny
column4: Sarah Bailey said: “Actions speak louder than words.”

column1: The former Russian spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter
column2: Yulia
column3: were poisoned with novichok in March 2018. Nick Bailey was contaminated after going into Skripal’s house after the attack. The three survived after lengthy spells in hospital.

column1: At the end of June 2018
column2: Sturgess and her partner
column3: Rowley
column4: were poisoned by novichok in Amesbury
column5: eight miles north of Salisbury
column6: after he found a fake perfume bottle that turned out to contain the nerve agent. Rowley survived but Sturgess
column8: died on 8 July 2018.

column1: The two men suspected of bringing the novichok to Salisbury
column2: Alexander Mishkin and Anatoliy Chepiga
column3: colonels in Russia’s GRU military spy agency
column4: have been charged in absentia over the poisoning of the Skripals
column5: but it is highly unlikely the men will ever be brought before a court in the UK.

column1: Both Bailey and his wife replied via Twitter to a post from Johnson in which the prime minister said the attack against Navalny was “outrageous”.
“The Russian government must now explain what happened
column2: ” he added.

column1: It’s outrageous that a chemical weapon was used against Alexey Navalny. We have seen first-hand the deadly consequences of Novichok in the UK. The Russian government must now explain what happened to Mr Navalny – we will work with international partners to ensure justice is done.
Bailey responded: “I have so much that I want to say about this tweet. But I can’t
column2: and I won’t.”

column1: Sarah Bailey said: “Justice would be nice. Actions speak louder than words
column2: ” before adding that there’s been no justice for the Sturgesses and Skripals in the two and a half years since the attacks
column3: and “now it’s happened again”.

column1: 10;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/sep/02/alexei-navalny-poisoned-with-novichok-says-german-government-russia";2020-09-03;"Alexei Navalny novichok finding prompts calls for answers from Moscow";"Angela Merkel says poisoning was attempted murder and White House calls it ‘reprehensible’

World leaders are demanding answers from the Kremlin after toxicological examinations indicated that the Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny was poisoned with a nerve agent from the novichok family.
The German chancellor
column2: Angela Merkel
column3: revealed that tests carried out at a military laboratory had “identified unequivocally” the Soviet era nerve agent. She referred to the case as an “attempted murder” and said the findings raised “very difficult questions that only the Russian government can answer
column4: and has to answer”.

column1: The UK prime minister
column2: Boris Johnson
column3: called the findings “outrageous” and said: “The Russian government must now explain what happened to Mr Navalny.”

column1: The White House called the attack “completely reprehensible”. Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden called it an “outrageous and brazen attempt on Mr Navalny’s life” and noted that Donald Trump had yet to personally condemn the attack.
Navalny
column2: whose foundation publishes investigations into corruption among high-level officials in Russia
column3: fell ill on a flight back to Moscow from Siberia on 20 August and was transferred to Berlin two days later.

column1: Doctors who treated him in the Siberian city of Omsk
column2: where his flight made an emergency landing
column3: insisted there was no proof of poisoning and were initially reluctant to allow him to leave the country on a specially equipped plane.

column1: The discovery that novichok was used on Navalny will lead many to conclude that the attack was meant as a brazen message to critics of the Kremlin
column2: and Navalny’s associates quickly pointed the finger at Putin.

column1: “Choosing novichok to poison Navalny in 2020 is basically the same thing as leaving an autograph at the scene of the crime
column2: ” wrote Navalny’s associate Leonid Volkov on Twitter
column3: appending an image of Putin’s autograph to the tweet.

column1: Ivan Zhdanov
column2: the director of Navalny’s anti-corruption foundation
column3: wrote that it was “beyond any reasonable doubt” that only Russian security services would be able to use novichok.

column1: Born in 1976 just outside Moscow
column2: Alexei Navalny is a lawyer-turned-campaigner whose Anti-Corruption Foundation investigates the wealth of Vladimir Putin’s inner circle.

column1: He started out as a Russian nationalist
column2: but emerged as the main leader of Russia's democratic opposition during the wave of protests that led up to the 2012 presidential election
column3: and has since been a thorn in the Kremlin’s side.

column1: Navalny is barred from appearing on state television
column2: but has used social media to his advantage. A 2017 documentary accusing the prime minister
column3: Dmitry Medvedev
column4: of corruption received more than 30m views on YouTube within two months.

column1: He has been repeatedly arrested and jailed. The European court of human rights ruled that Russia violated Navalny's rights by holding him under house arrest in 2014. Election officials barred him from running for president in 2018 due to an embezzlement conviction that he claims was politically motivated. Navalny told the commission its decision would be a vote 'not against me
column2: but against 16
column3: 000 people who have nominated me; against 200
column4: 000 volunteers who have been canvassing for me'.

column1: There has also been a physical price to pay. In April 2017
column2: he was attacked with green dye that nearly blinded him in one eye
column3: and in July 2019 he was taken from jail to hospital with symptoms that one of his doctors said could indicate poisoning. In 2020
column4: he was again hospitalised after a suspected poisoning
column5: and taken to Germany for treatment. The German government later said toxicology results showed Navalny was poisoned with a Novichok nerve agent.

column1: The nerve agent was used to poison the former Russian spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia in Britain two years ago. It is a cholinesterase inhibitor
column2: part of the class of substances that doctors at Berlin’s Charité hospital initially identified in Navalny.

column1: According to the German news magazine Der Spiegel
column2: experts at the Charité sought advice from Porton Down
column3: Britain’s secretive laboratory for research on chemical and biological weapons
column4: because of possible similarities with the 2018 Skripal attack.

column1: The use of novichok nerve agents was banned last year after being added to the chemical weapons convention’s list of controlled substances.
The UK foreign secretary
column2: Dominic Raab
column3: said: “The Russian government has a clear case to answer. It is absolutely unacceptable that this banned chemical weapon has been used again
column4: and once more we see violence directed against a leading Russian opposition figure.”

column1: The US National Security Council noted that Russia had used novichok “in the past”
column2: and said the US would “work with allies and the international community to hold those in Russia accountable
column3: wherever the evidence leads
column4: and restrict funds for their malign activities.”

column1: The German government’s official statement described the attack on Navalny as an “astounding act” and appealed to the Russian government to urgently offer an explanation.
Novichok refers to a group of nerve agents developed by the Soviet Union in the 1970s and 80s to elude international restrictions on chemical weapons. Like other nerve agents
column2: they are organophosphate compounds
column3: but the chemicals used to make them
column4: and their final structures
column5: are considered classified in the UK
column6: the US and other countries.

column1: The most potent of the novichok substances are considered to be more lethal than VX
column2: the most deadly of the familiar nerve agents
column3: which include sarin
column4: tabun and soman.

column1: Novichok agents work in a similar way
column2: by massively over-stimulating muscles and glands. Treatment for novichok exposure would be the same as for other nerve agents
column3: namely with atropine
column4: diazepam and potentially drugs called oximes.

column1: The chemical structures of novichok agents were made public in 2008 by Vil Mirzayanov
column2: a former Russian scientist living in the US
column3: but the structures have never been publicly confirmed. It is thought they can be made in different forms
column4: including as a dust aerosol.

column1: The novichoks are known as binary agents because they only become lethal  after mixing two otherwise harmless components. According to Mirzayanov
column2: they are 10 to 100 times more toxic than conventional nerve agents.

column1: “We condemn this attack in the strongest possible terms”
column2: said the foreign minister
column3: Heiko Maas
column4: adding that the Russian ambassador in Berlin had been summoned in light of the new findings.

column1: Official reaction in Moscow on Wednesday afternoon was a mixture of denial and obfuscation. The Kremlin said it had not yet been informed of the findings
column2: while some other officials suggested Russia was willing to work with German investigators
column3: but attempted to cast doubt on the test results.

column1: “The Russian side is still expecting an official answer from Berlin to the inquiry from the Russian prosecutor general’s office and Russian medical institutions
column2: ” said the foreign ministry in a statement.

column1: The Russian doctors who treated Navalny in Siberia have repeatedly contested the German hospital’s conclusion
column2: saying they ruled out poisoning as a diagnosis and that their tests for poisonous substances came back negative.

column1: “We will demand that the Germans send their analyses so we can compare with our data and work out what really happened
column2: ” Vladimir Dzhabarov
column3: of Russia’s upper house of parliament
column4: told Interfax. “We are ready to cooperate. The main thing is whether they are. Because ideally they should have invited us and familiarised our investigation team with their materials.”

column1: Merkel’s spokesperson Steffen Seibert said the German government would inform its partners in the EU and Nato about the test results. He said it would consult with its partners on appropriate next steps in light of any Russian response.
In the wake of the killing of a Chechen dissident in a central Berlin park last August
column2: the German government was initially cautious to blame the Kremlin
column3: even after federal prosecutors alleged that Russian state agencies had tasked the assassin.

column1: The language of the German government’s statement on the Navalny affair could prompt a more decisive response. Merkel said on Wednesday that the poison attack went “against the basic values we stand for”.
Sergey Lagodinsky
column2: a German Green MEP and former fellow student of Navalny’s at Yale University
column3: said: “I’m impressed by the clear framing of the government’s response. The confirmation that a banned nerve agent was used to poison a Russian opposition politician brings this case on to an international level. We need an international investigation.”

column1: Whether the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) has the capacity to carry out such an investigation remains unclear.
On Tuesday
column2: before the use of novichok was confirmed
column3: Merkel had again confirmed that her government would continue and finish the construction of the Nord Stream gas pipeline in spite of pressure from the US government.

column1: The infrastructure project
column2: which eastern European states fear will boost Russia’s geopolitical power
column3: plays an important role in the state of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern
column4: home to Merkel’s own constituency.

column1: Navalny is being kept in a medically induced coma and on a ventilator at the intensive care unit of the Charité hospital. While his condition remains serious
column2: a spokesperson said last Friday there was no immediate danger to his life.
