column2: Angela Merkel
column3: said in a personal statement that testing by a special military laboratory had shown proof that the Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny was poisoned with a novichok nerve agent. 'It is now clear: Alexei Navalny is the victim of a crime
column4: ' Merkel said. 'He was meant to be silenced. This raises very difficult questions that only the Russian government can answer
column5: and has to answer'

column1: 12";"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/aug/30/angela-merkel-great-migrant-gamble-paid-off";2020-08-30;"How Angela Merkel’s great migrant gamble paid off";"Five years ago
column2: as more and more refugees crossed into Europe
column3: Germany’s chancellor proclaimed
column4: ‘We’ll manage this.’ Critics said it was her great mistake – but she has been proved right

column1: Mohammad Hallak found the key to unlock the mysteries of his new homeland when he realised you could switch the subtitles on your Netflix account to German. The 21-year-old Syrian from Aleppo jotted down words he didn’t know
column2: increased his vocabulary and quickly became fluent. Last year
column3: he passed his end of high school exams with a grade of 1.5
column4: the top mark in his year group.

column1: Five years to the month after arriving in Germany as an unaccompanied minor
column2: Hallak is now in his third term studying computer science at the Westphalian University of Applied Sciences and harbours an aspiration to become an IT entrepreneur. “Germany was always my goal”
column3: he says
column4: in the mumbled sing-song of the Ruhr valley dialect. “I’ve always had a funny feeling that I belong here.”

column1: Hallak
column2: an exceptionally motivated student with high social aptitude
column3: is not representative of all the 1.7 million people who applied for asylum in Germany between 2015 and 2019
column4: making it the country with the fifth highest population of refugees in the world. Some of those with whom he trekked through Turkey and across the Mediterranean
column5: he says
column6: haven’t picked up more than a few words and “just chill”.

column1: But Hallak is not a complete outlier either. More than 10
column2: 000 people who arrived in Germany as refugees since 2015 have mastered the language sufficiently to enrol at a German university. More than half of those who came are in work and pay taxes. Among refugee children and teenagers
column3: more than 80% say they have a strong sense of belonging to their German schools and feel liked by their peers.

column1: Success stories like Hallak’s partially redeem the optimism expressed by Angela Merkel in a sentence she spoke five years ago this week
column2: at the peak of one of the most tumultuous years in recent European history – a sentence that nearly cost her her job and that she herself has partially retreated from.

column1: “I put it simply
column2: Germany is a strong country
column3: ” the German chancellor told the media at a press conference in central Berlin on 31 August 2015
column4: trying to address concerns about the steeply rising number of people – mostly from Syria
column5: Iraq and Afghanistan – applying for asylum in Germany that summer.

column1: “The motive with which we approach these matters must be: we have already managed so much
column2: we’ll manage this.” During the German TV broadcast of her interview
column3: headlines flashed up to report that Hungary was sending trainloads of people to the German border
column5: 000 of whom turned up at Munich central station the following week alone.

column1: The German phrase Merkel used
column2: Wir schaffen das
column3: became so memorable mainly because it would in the weeks and months that followed be endlessly quoted back at her by those who believed that the German chancellor’s optimistic message had encouraged millions more migrants to embark on a dangerous odyssey across the Med. “Merkel’s actions
column4: now
column5: will be hard to correct: her words cannot be unsaid
column6: ” wrote the Spectator. “She has exacerbated a problem that will be with us for years
column7: perhaps decades.”

column1: The Alternative für Deutschland party
column2: founded two years previously on a more narrowly anti-euro ticket
column3: discovered a new populist stride: when Merkel said “We will manage”
column4: the rightwing party claimed
column5: she really meant “You will manage”
column6: asking the German public to cope with rising levels of crime
column7: terrorism and public disorder.

column1: “We don’t want to manage this!” the AfD politician Alexander Gauland proclaimed at a party rally in October 2015. Over the coming months and years – in the wake of the New Year’s Eve sexual assaults in Cologne
column2: the Bataclan terror attack in Paris and the truck rampage on Berlin’s Breitscheidtplatz Christmas market – that sentiment seemed to gain traction with a growing part of the German population
column3: even when the crimes were not carried out by people who had arrived in 2015.

column2: there was a prevalent view that Wir schaffen das would be Merkel’s undoing
column3: a “catastrophic mistake” as Donald Trump said in January that year. “The worst decision a European leader has made in modern times
column4: ” Nigel Farage told Fox News. “She’s finished.”

column1: Yet today Merkel still sits at the top of Europe’s largest economy
column2: her personal approval ratings back to where they were at the start of 2015 and the polling of her party
column3: the Christian Democratic Union (CDU)
column4: buoyed to record levels by the global pandemic. When Merkel steps down ahead of federal elections in 2021
column5: as is expected
column6: her party’s successor currently looks more likely to be a centrist in her mould than a hardliner promising a symbolic break with her stance on immigration.

column1: The question is what could she have done differently? You can’t seal a wide-open border with rhetoric and a few guards
The AfD
column2: meanwhile
column3: never reached the point “when it will be the country’s second-largest party”
column4: as historian Niall Ferguson predicted in February 2018. The party has established a steady presence in local parliaments across Germany
column5: especially in the states of the formerly socialist east. But at federal level the AfD has dropped to fourth in the polls
column6: down from its third place and 12.6% at elections in 2017
column7: and has been stricken with infighting since immigration has dropped off the top of the political agenda.

column1: The spectre of jihadist terrorism
column2: which some feared the refugee crisis would usher into the heart of central Europe
column3: has faded from view in recent years. After a spate of seven attacks with an Islamist motive in Germany in 2016
column4: culminating with a truck driven into a Berlin Christmas market that December
column5: the country has seen no further attacks for the last three years.

column1: Peter Neumann
column2: a terrorism expert at King’s College London’s Department of War Studies
column3: recalls being invited onto a German TV programme at the height of the crisis in 2015. “I gave my optimistic best back then
column4: but deep down I was worried
column5: ” he says. “Will this work out? With nearly a million people about whom we know so little? In the end
column6: those fears were misplaced.

column1: “We know that some of the men involved in the Bataclan attack had exploited the chaos to smuggle themselves into Europe
column2: in some cases posing as Syrian refugees. We also knew that the vast majority of people who arrived were young men
column3: the very demographic that is most susceptible to radicalisation. And yet
column4: we can now say that the worst fears haven’t come true.

column1: “In hindsight
column2: Isis’s collapse happened quicker than we expected. It’s now clear that what made them so attractive for a while is less their ideology than their success. And when Isis stopped being successful
column3: it stopped being attractive.”

column1: However
column2: Neumann says this was also due to the increasing efficiency of German intelligence agencies. According to data collected by Petter Nesser
column3: a senior research fellow with the Norwegian Defence Research Establishment
column4: 16 terror plots with a jihadist motive have been foiled on German soil since the start of 2015
column5: more than in France or the UK over the same period.

column1: The events of the summer of 2015 did evidently mobilise and further radicalise Germany’s rightwing extremist circles
column2: who targeted asylum shelters with arson attacks or assassinated politicians with pro-immigration views
column3: such as the CDU’s Walter Lübcke. No other country in Europe saw as much severe and fatal rightwing violence in 2019 as Germany.

column1: Germany’s Federal Office of Criminal Investigations records a rise of criminal offences
column2: including violent crime
column3: in the years between 2014 and 2016
column4: linking the trend to the influx of migration. The percentage of asylum seekers found guilty of such crimes also doubled in the same period. However
column5: the majority of these offences were within the refugee shelters where new arrivals were initially housed. By 2017
column6: when Trump claimed that “crime in Germany is way up” because it had taken in “all of those illegals”
column7: the number of overall recorded crimes was decreasing. Last year
column8: crime in Germany sank to an 18-year low.

column1: What about the organised crime on Europe’s borders
column2: where human traffickers prey on those willing to risk it all in the hope of a better life? In a 2017 book on reforming asylum policy
column3: British economist Paul Collier argued that “while the industry was already well-established in the Mediterranean
column4: the massive rise in demand triggered by the invitation from Germany further increased demand for smuggling by criminal syndicates.”

column1: Gerald Knaus
column2: chairman of the European Stability Initiative
column3: a thinktank that advises EU member-states on migration policy
column4: disagrees vehemently: “The thesis that Merkel created the refugee crisis was absurd in 2015
column5: and it’s even more absurd in retrospect
column6: ” he says.

column1: Empirical studies have failed to find data proving that Merkel’s Wir schaffen das significantly intensified the movement of refugees into Europe
column2: although it is likely that the attention drawn towards Germany’s liberal stance on asylum influenced the decisions of those who were already in Europe at the time.

column1: “The question is: what could she have done differently?” says Knaus. “Reintroduce borders and try what France did after the Bataclan attacks in November 2015
column2: sending all irregular migrants back to Italy? That proved futile: France received twice as many asylum applications in 2019 as in 2015. You can’t seal a wide-open border with rhetoric and a few more border guards
column3: while brutality was fortunately ruled out in Germany.”

column1: Germany’s stance in 2015 did prove too optimistic in the sense that Merkel’s government seemed to believe that the tumultuous events of that summer would lead to a quick reform of the Dublin Regulation
column2: the mechanism that determines which state is responsible for examining an asylum application. Knaus says: “The Germans thought everyone would sign up to a quota system because it was ‘fair’
column3: but they couldn’t explain how this would work in practice.”

column1: Instead
column2: Merkel’s government took unilateral steps to slow down the rate of new arrivals to a trickle. An agreement between Turkey and the EU to stop irregular migration and replace it with a resettlement scheme
column3: developed by Knaus’s thinktank
column4: drastically stemmed the flow of migrants to Europe in 2016. Merkel’s government later tried to limit asylum applications from north Africa by adding Algeria
column5: Morocco and Tunisia to its list of countries considered safe
column6: though the proposal was later rejected by the upper chamber of Germany’s parliament.

column1: In March this year
column2: Germany launched a social media campaign to deter Syrian refugees from embarking on a journey to central Europe
column3: and Merkel’s “grand coalition” with the centre-left Social Democratic party voted against taking in even just 5
column4: 000 vulnerable refugees stranded in Greek camps.

column1: Merkel never recanted her words of August 2015
column2: as many even in her own party insisted she should. But she did ensure a situation like the one that followed won’t be repeated on German soil during her tenure.

column1: On a sweltering afternoon in Berlin’s suburban south
column2: preparations are afoot for the annual summer fete at the Marienfelde transit centre
column3: a sprawling concrete camp that used to be the first port of call for many East Germans who fled to the west during the cold war
column4: and now houses asylum seekers from around the world. While volunteers erect socially distanced benches and hang up garlands in the courtyard
column5: a group of men and women from Syria
column6: Afghanistan and Iraq have gathered inside to meet the Berlin senate’s integration officer
column7: to ask for advice and air grievances.

column1: A 44-year-old Syrian is concerned that he might fail next month’s language exam
column2: even though he will need a pass in order to start working. German classes have been cancelled because of the pandemic
column3: and the wireless signal inside the camp is too weak for online learning. “Berlin
column4: on our doorstep
column5: that is Europe
column6: ” says the man
column7: who doesn’t want to give his name for fear of getting into trouble with the Syrian embassy. “But this shelter is like a little Syria: everyone speaks Arabic.”

column1: Germany was not the destination of choice for the father of three
column2: who arrived in the country via the resettlement programme of the United Nations’ refugee agency
column3: the UNHCR
column4: in 2018. He is grateful that Merkel’s government took him in
column5: but the wait for a work permit is starting to exasperate him. Before Berlin
column6: he worked for six years as a pastry chef in Izmit
column7: Turkey
column8: but German bakers won’t accept his qualifications – he would need to do another two-year apprenticeship first. “It’s very frustrating.”

column1: It’s a success story even if no one quite has the confidence to say it yet. Germany has managed
The integration officer assures him she empathises with his plight: Katarina Niewiedzial
column2: who has been in the post since 2019
column3: was once a migrant herself
column4: having arrived in Germany from Poland as a 12-year-old. She knows from personal experience the areas of public life where Germany is ill-equipped for the task of integrating newcomers.

column1: German employers are often still reluctant to recognise foreign qualifications. If migrants lack the certificates to prove they are qualified enough to do a job
column2: they can apply to prove their skills in an interview
column3: but they need fluent German to do so – a bigger challenge for adults in their 40s than teenagers like Hallak. Last year
column4: the German Chamber of Commerce only carried out 80 such “qualification analysis” processes in the whole of Germany.

column1: Often refugees end up in jobs they are overqualified for
column2: such as catering
column3: which in turn are more precarious and have cut staff during the pandemic: in May this year
column4: the number of unemployed Berliners without a German passport was up by 40% compared to the same period in 2019.

column1: Many experts think that the integration classes that have been mandatory for refugees in Germany since 2005 are no longer fit for purpose
column2: holding back those with academic qualifications while failing to offer real help for those who arrive without being able to read or write. The percentage of those failing the all-important B1 language test has risen rather than fallen over the last five years. And yet
column3: Niewiedzial is optimistic. “Germany can be a very sluggish country
column4: full of tiresome bureaucracy
column5: ” she says. “But it’s also able to learn from its mistakes and draw consequences from them.”

column1: Since 2015
column2: she says
column3: the state had massively expanded its asylum authority
column4: created thousands of posts to coordinate volunteers
column5: turned shelters into permanent homes and trained specialist teachers. Germany has managed. “It’s a success story
column6: even if no one quite has the confidence to say that yet.”

column1: 27 August 2015 71 migrants are found dead inside a refrigerated lorry abandoned in Austria. The discovery sparks international revulsion
column2: and contributes to the decisions of several countries to open their borders to people fleeing war and poverty.

column1: 31 August 2015 Angela Merkel
column2: the German chancellor
column3: says Wir schaffen das – We’ll manage this – after visiting a camp for newly arrived refugees. Soon after she announces an open-door policy; in the year that follows over a million people claim asylum in Germany.

column1: 13 November 2015 The Bataclan attack in Paris is the first of a series of deadly attacks by Isis-affiliated extremists across Europe. In July 2016 a Syrian who declared his support for the group kills himself and injures 15 others with a homemade bomb at a music festival in the German town of Ansbach. The far right uses the attacks to argue against Merkel’s refugee policies.

March 2016 The EU strikes a deal with Turkey to return all refugees and migrants who reach Europe across the Aegean sea. This dramatically reduces the number of people arriving in Germany and other European countries to claim asylum.
19 September 2016 Merkel’s CDU party suffers a slump in support to just 18% in Berlin state elections
column2: while anti-immigration populists Alternative für Deutschland (AfD) enters the German capital’s state parliament for the first time. Mayor Michael Müller warns that the level of support it won “would be seen around the world as a sign of the return of the rightwing and the Nazis in Germany”.

column1: 19 December 2016 A Tunisian whose asylum application had been turned down rams a truck into a crowded Christmas market in Berlin
column2: killing 12 people and wounding 70. Isis claims it inspired the attack.

column1: 24 September 2017 The populist radical-right AfD party enters the Bundestag
column2: the German parliament
column3: as the third biggest party. After Merkel forms a coalition with the Social Democrats
column4: it becomes the largest opposition party.

column1: October 2018 After crushing defeats in local elections
column2: Merkel says she will step down as CDU leader almost immediately
column3: and will not contest the 2021 elections
column4: making her fourth term as Germany’s chancellor her last.

column1: 2020 Merkel’s effective handling of the coronavirus crisis helps restore her popularity
column2: particularly as the US and UK stumble. One poll finds over 80% of Germans think she is doing her job “rather well”.

column1: Emma Graham-Harrison

column2: Morocco and Tunisia to its list of countries considered safe; in fact this proposal was later rejected by the Bundesrat."

column1: 13;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/aug/21/cinema-for-peace-the-ngo-trying-to-airlift-alexei-navalny-to-germany";2020-08-21;"Cinema for Peace: the NGO trying to airlift Alexei Navalny to Germany";"Berlin film foundation steps in to help ‘poisoned’ Kremlin critic at request of Pussy Riot member

Germany’s plans to airlift the Russian opposition activist Alexei Navalny to Berlin for treatment are being orchestrated by a charitable foundation acting with the explicit blessing of the federal government.
Jaka Bizilj
column2: the Slovenian-born promoter and producer who founded Cinema for Peace in 2002
column3: said his organisation was financing the flight and medical aid through private donors.

column1: The foundation is supported by a group of philanthropists who give aid to humanitarian projects
column2: in particular filmmakers who highlight global social challenges. It hosts an annual awards ceremony for films focusing on political and societal causes
column3: which runs parallel to the Berlin film festival. Previous speakers at its awards gala have included Elton John
column4: George Clooney
column5: Angelina Jolie and Mikhail Gorbachev
column6: the former Russian president.

column1: Navalny
column2: Russia’s most prominent opposition activist
column3: is in a coma in the Siberian city of Omsk after collapsing during a flight to Moscow on Thursday
column4: allegedly from poisoning.

column1: Bizilj’s involvement in the proposed airlift to Germany came about after Pyotr Verzilov
column2: a member of the Russian political punk group Pussy Riot
column3: intervened. Verzilov was himself flown from Moscow to Berlin by Cinema for Peace two years ago
column4: after another suspected poisoning.

column1: Verzilov
column2: who had been treated at Berlin’s Charité university hospital
column3: approached Bizilj on behalf of Navalny’s family this week. Bizilj told the newspaper Bild: “On the request of Pyotr Verzilov
column4: for humanitarian reasons
column5: we organised an aeroplane equipped with necessary medical supplies
column6: so that Navalny can be brought to Germany.”

column1: The Charité has a longstanding reputation for treating foreign patients
column2: including prominent political ones from the Arabic and Russian-speaking worlds
column3: as well as from Africa. In 2012 it sent a team of medical staff to treat the Ukrainian opposition leader Yulia Tymoshenko for back pain in prison
column4: and in 2014 she was flown to Berlin for treatment at the hospital.

column1: Paul Ziemiak
column2: general secretary of the ruling CDU
column3: indicated on Thursday that Germany was ready to treat Navalny
column4: saying: “If it’s desired
column5: we have the possibility to help with the treatment.” Angela Merkel
column6: speaking at a meeting on Thursday with president Emmanuel Macron of France
column7: added her support
column8: saying: “What is now very
column9: very important is that this is urgently resolved.”

column1: The Charité’s reputation as a hub for foreign VIP patients was already strong during the cold war when
column2: as the leading hospital in the communist German Democratic Republic
column3: it treated international figureheads such as the Palestinian political leader Yasser Arafat. Its international patients department
column4: which advertises for patients
column5: says on its website that it will “ensure that international patients benefit optimally from the excellence of the Charité”
column6: and that it has translators in English
column7: Arabic and Russian. It adds: “The consideration of cultural and confessional customs is just as much a part of our philosophy as the personal care before
column8: during and after your stay.”

column1: While Russian doctors refused to release Navalny on Friday morning
column2: Bizilj told German media he was optimistic that it would still be possible to airlift the activist to Berlin. “Two years ago
column3: when we transported [Verzilov]
column4: there were delays
column5: but in the end everything worked
column6: ” he said.

column1: 14;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/aug/18/germany-to-extend-coronavirus-furlough-to-24-months";2020-08-18;"Germany to extend coronavirus furlough to 24 months";"Angela Merkel backs proposal to continue Kurzarbeit part-time working scheme
Germany is expected to extend its pandemic furlough scheme to 24 months after Angela Merkel indicated that she welcomed the proposal to let the Kurzarbeit programme run on.
The chancellor’s spokesperson said on Monday she was “positively” inclined towards the suggestion to extend the scheme
column2: which allows firms to put their staff on part-time work to reduce their cost. Britain’s furlough scheme initially only allowed staff to be sent home and not work
column3: but staff have been allowed to work part-time since July.

column1: The finance minister
column2: Olaf Scholz
column3: first proposed extending the benefit programme
column4: which is currently limited to claims lasting a maximum of 12 months
column5: on Sunday. “The corona crisis won’t suddenly disappear in the next few weeks
column6: ” said Scholz
column7: who was recently announced as the centre-left Social Democrats’ candidate for chancellor in next year’s elections.

column1: He added: “Businesses and employees need a clear signal from the government: we’ve got your back for the long haul in this crisis
column2: so that no one is being let go without need.”

column1: A final decision on an extension
column2: which it is estimated will cost €10bn (£9bn)
column3: is expected on 25 August.

column1: The UK furlough scheme is scheduled to end in October. From August employers have had to start contributing towards its cost
column2: first with pension and national insurance contributions
column3: and with 10% and then 20% of wages in the next two months.

column1: The chancellor
column2: Rishi Sunak
column3: said this month that the decision to wind down the UK furlough was “one of the most difficult decisions” he had had to make. But he said it was not sustainable
column4: and that most other countries were making similar moves to wind down their schemes.

column1: The UK scheme paid 80% of wages
column2: up to £2
column3: 500 a month
column4: for about 9.5 million employees at its peak. The total cost to date is nearly £35bn.

column1: Germany’s furlough scheme is modelled on a programme that won the country praise during the 2008-09 financial crisis.
Called Kurzarbeit (“short work”)
column2: it is essentially an unemployment benefit paid out to companies by the government’s Federal Employment Agency
column3: designed to compensate lost earnings for workers who have been temporarily placed on reduced hours
column4: and help companies avoid cutting jobs.

column1: While the economic output of Europe’s powerhouse suffered a 10% slump in the second quarter of 2020
column2: the furlough scheme has so far largely absorbed the accompanying shock on the labour market. German unemployment in July was at 6.3%
column3: an annual increase of a mere 1.3 percentage points. In the US
column4: by comparison
column5: unemployment temporarily rose to a record 14.7% in April.

column1: Companies can apply for Kurzarbeit if at least 10% of their workforce have had their working hours cut by more than 10%. By the end of April 2020
column2: German companies had signed up more than 10.1 million workers to the scheme – almost 10 times as many as at the peak of the financial crisis.

column1: However
column2: not all companies that applied for the scheme used it
column3: meaning the actual number of recipients is considerably lower.

column1: According to estimates by the Ifo Institute for Economic Research
column2: in July about 5.6 million employees we still on the scheme
column3: which has proved especially popular in the manufacturing and retail sector.

column1: Ifo’s labour market expert Sebastian Link predicted redundancies “in the high hundred thousands” if the scheme ended after 12 months.
Link said there were political reasons why the furlough would not end: “I see it as absolutely inevitable that the Kurzarbeit scheme will be extended
column2: not least because we are facing federal elections next year.

column1: “Whether it’s sensible to do so is another matter; in some areas of the economy
column2: such as the car industry
column3: the furlough scheme could end up actually preventing necessary structural changes.”

column1: When the scheme was last used on a mass scale
column2: it only replaced about 60% of workers’ lost earnings. During the coronavirus crisis
column3: Merkel’s coalition government decided to increase payments: after four months on the scheme
column4: recipients receive about 70% of lost earnings
column5: and about 80% after seven months
column6: if they have lost more than 50% of their working hours.

column1: 15;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/aug/18/female-led-countries-handled-coronavirus-better-study-jacinda-ardern-angela-merkel";2020-08-18;"Female-led countries handled coronavirus better
column2: study suggests";"Analysis points to earlier lockdowns and lower death rates under likes of Jacinda Ardern and Angela Merkel

column1: Countries led by women had “systematically and significantly better” Covid-19 outcomes
column2: research appears to show
column3: locking down earlier and suffering half as many deaths on average as those led by men.

column1: The relative early success of leaders such as Germany’s Angela Merkel
column2: New Zealand’s Jacinda Ardern
column3: Denmark’s Mette Frederiksen
column4: Taiwan’s Tsai Ing-wen and Finland’s Sanna Marin has so far attracted many headlines but little academic attention.

column1: The analysis of 194 countries
column2: published by the Centre for Economic Policy Research and the World Economic Forum
column3: suggests the difference is real and “may be explained by the proactive and coordinated policy responses” adopted by female leaders.

column1: Even after clear and frequently cited outliers such as New Zealand and Germany – and the US for male leaders – were removed from the statistics
column2: the study found
column3: the case for the relative success of female leaders was only strengthened.

column1: “Our results clearly indicate that women leaders reacted more quickly and decisively in the face of potential fatalities
column2: ” said Supriya Garikipati
column3: a developmental economist at Liverpool University
column4: co-author with Reading University’s Uma Kambhampati.

column1: “In almost all cases
column2: they locked down earlier than male leaders in similar circumstances. While this may have longer-term economic implications
column3: it has certainly helped these countries to save lives
column4: as evidenced by the significantly lower number of deaths in these countries.”

column1: The two researchers said they analysed differing policy responses and subsequent total Covid-19 cases and deaths until 19 May
column2: introducing a number of variables to help analyse the raw data and draw reliable comparisons between countries.

column1: Among the datasets considered were GDP
column2: total population
column3: population density and proportion of elderly residents
column4: as well as annual health spending per head
column5: openness to international travel and level of gender equality in society in general.

column1: Since only 19 of the nearly 200 countries were led by women
column2: the authors also created so-called “nearest neighbour” countries to offset the small sample size
column3: pairing Germany
column4: New Zealand and Bangladesh with male-led Britain
column5: Ireland and Pakistan.

column1: “This analysis clearly confirms that when women-led countries are compared to countries similar to them along a range of characteristics
column2: they have performed better
column3: experiencing fewer cases as well as fewer deaths
column4: ” Garikipati said.

column1: She added that while female leaders “were risk averse with regard to lives”
column2: locking their countries down significantly earlier than male leaders
column3: that also suggested they were “more willing to take risks in the domain of the economy”.

column1: When compared according to the “openness to travel” criterion
column2: female-led countries did not experience significantly lower Covid cases but did report lower deaths
column3: the researchers found
column4: concluding that this may suggest “better policies and compliance”.

column1: Garikipati said the evidence of a “significant and systematic difference” showed that even accounting for institutional context and other controls
column2: “being female-led has provided countries with an advantage in the current crisis”.

column1: The researchers said they hoped the study would “serve as a starting point to illuminate the discussion on the influence of national leaders in explaining the differences in country Covid-outcomes”.

column1: 16;"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2020/aug/15/why-germany-would-be-especially-happy-to-see-the-back-of-trump";2020-08-15;"Why Germany would be especially happy to see the back of Trump";"The competence embodied in Merkel provokes loathing from the US president
Donald Trump has declared war on Germany. In a manner of speaking. Europe’s most important country
column2: potentially America’s most valuable partner
column3: has in the mind of the president become an adversary. Of all Trump’s many foreign policy disasters
column4: this is perhaps his most significant.

column1: In late July
column2: it was announced that retired army colonel Douglas Macgregor
column3: a decorated combat veteran
column4: would become the next ambassador to Berlin. Macgregor is a regular contributor to Trump’s favourite channel of information
column5: Fox News. He has variously suggested that the US border guard should shoot people if they tried to enter illegally from Mexico; described eastern Ukrainians as “Russians”; defended Serbia’s actions against a “Muslim drug mafia” in Kosovo; and criticised Germany for giving “millions of unwanted Muslim invaders” welfare benefits rather than providing more funding for its armed services.

column1: Most painfully for his new hosts
column2: Macgregor seems to have sided with the far right in talking down Nazi crimes. He described the concept of Vergangenheitsbewältigung (coming to terms with history)
column3: which has underpinned culture and politics since the war
column4: as a “sick mentality that says that generations after generations must atone sins of what happened in 13 years of German history and ignore the other 1
column5: 500 years of Germany”.

column1: If the Senate’s foreign relations committee confirms Macgregor’s nomination
column2: he will replace another Fox shock-jock commentator. No sooner had Richard Grenell arrived in Berlin in 2018 than he went on the offensive
column3: vowing to “empower other conservatives” across Europe. By that
column4: he did not mean Angela Merkel’s coalition
column5: but nationalists surrounding her
column6: such as in Hungary and Poland. A number of German MPs called for Grenell to be declared persona no grata. Merkel resisted
column7: but the affair spoke volumes for the collapse in ties.

column1: Trump rewarded Grenell for his work
column2: promoting him to acting director of national security in Washington. In a further demonstration of pique
column3: he announced last month the withdrawal of nearly 12
column4: 000 troops from bases in Germany.

column1: From the outset
column2: Trump loathed Merkel. She represents everything he is not. On the international stage
column3: she respects interlocutors who do their preparation and don’t spring surprises. She disdains his visceral vulgarity. The leader who let in a million of the world’s most destitute in 2015 refuses to be cowed by a bigot and bully.

column1: She couldn’t be accused of not trying to get along. In March 2017
column2: two months into his administration
column3: she flew to Washington for their first meeting. She prepped assiduously. She studied a 1990 Playboy interview that had become a set text on Trumpism for policymakers. She read his 1987 book
column4: The Art of the Deal. She even watched episodes of his TV show
column5: The Apprentice.

column1: It started badly. She offered him a handshake in the Oval Office in front of the cameras. He didn’t take it. Her studied lack of emotion and her deeply analytical mind were anathema to him. Her aides say she learned to explain complicated problems to him by reducing them to bite-size chunks. He read this as high-handedness.

Trump has a track record of misogyny and some cite this as the reason for his dislike. Others put it down to a narcissistic resentment of praise conferred on others. When she was chosen as Time magazine’s person of the year in 2015
column2: he said: “They picked the person who is ruining Germany.” What particularly upset him was the magazine calling her chancellor of the free world. “What Merkel did to Germany
column3: it’s a sad
column4: sad shame.”

column1: Yet this same woman
column2: who from a young age dreamed of driving across the American plains and adored Ronald Reagan for freeing the world (and her native GDR) from communism
column3: is by instinct a staunch Atlanticist.

column1: She has found the setbacks hard to take. Arguably the single worst incident came before Trump. It was the revelation in 2013
column2: courtesy of Edward Snowden
column3: that the National Security Agency had been bugging Merkel’s personal mobile phone for years. She was incandescent when told
column4: for once losing her famous impulse control. In an angry phone exchange with President Barack Obama
column5: deliberately shared with the media
column6: she told him: “This is like the Stasi.”

column1: This relationship has always been complicated. Germans remember with fondness the liberation of their country
column2: the airlift that ended the Russians’ blockade of Berlin. They devoured American culture. They fell in love with John F Kennedy
column3: his 1963 trip to divided Berlin indelibly etched in the history books. But the left fought tooth and nail against nuclear deployments under Reagan. George Bush’s Iraq misadventure drove a terrible wedge
column4: not least his attempts to divide the continent into New and Old Europe. Even with the more centrist and amenable Bill Clinton and Obama there were bad moments.

column1: Successive US administrations have expressed frustration. The Nord Stream gas pipeline
column2: chaired by former chancellor Gerhard Schröder
column3: has underlined Germany’s dangerous energy dependency on Russia. It contradicts Merkel’s otherwise consistently tough approach towards Vladimir Putin. She was instrumental in ensuring that the EU imposed sanctions after the annexation of Crimea and invasion of eastern Ukraine. Berlin no longer praises China as the gift that keeps on giving and belatedly sees it as a strategic competitor
column4: but Merkel balks at strong criticism of it. As for defence
column5: the failure of Germany to meet the agreed Nato target of spending 2% of GDP on defence has been a source of irritation.

column1: But nothing comes close to the current situation.
The German foreign policy establishment is clinging to the hope that Trump will be defeated in November. A Biden presidency would not remove all the tensions
column2: but it would signal that the US was moving back towards the diplomatic mainstream. The country that personifies the mainstream would have reason to celebrate.

The other day
column2: I had a dream. I dreamed that I was sitting on a beach in the summer of 2030 and looking back on how Germany had saved Europe.

column1: The German chancellor had brokered a European recovery package after the Covid-19 crisis of 2020
column2: with large grants and loans to help hard-hit south European economies
column3: drawing on shared European borrowing. It had maintained constructive relations between the EU and post-Brexit Britain
column4: helped the citizens of Poland and Hungary to defend liberal democracy
column5: confounded Vladimir Putin by seriously committing to a common European energy policy
column6: used the regulatory power of the EU to curb Facebook
column7: shaped a common strategy towards China and made a world-leading example of Europe’s green new deal.

column1: All this Germany had done by working as “first among equals” with other European countries
column2: while partnering with the US and other democracies around the world. In realising this ambitious agenda
column3: it had kept its civilised
column4: consensual style of politics and the support of its own people. What an achievement for Germany and Europe at the beginning of the 2030s. What a contrast to the beginning of the 1930s.

column1: My daydream was prompted by the €1.8tn (£1.6tn)
column2: seven-year EU budget and recovery deal brokered by German chancellor Angela Merkel
column3: along with President Emmanuel Macron and the EU’s institutional leaders
column4: in a marathon summit earlier this month. The door to this breakthrough was opened by a major shift in Germany’s position
column5: accepting the need for fiscal solidarity. A year ago I despaired so much of major change coming from the grand coalition government in Berlin that I argued that the only way to get essential reform in Europe was for that government to go. History proved me wrong in the way history has a habit of proving everyone wrong – through a totally unexpected development.

column1: With what Hegel would call the cunning of reason in history
column2: Germany’s long overdue shift was precipitated by a previously unknown virus of Asian origin and a ruling of the German constitutional court. The former made it clear even to a sceptical German public that south European countries were suffering from a disaster no one could say was their own fault
column3: and therefore deserved economic solidarity. The latter
column4: firing a warning shot over the bows of the European Central Bank
column5: made it clear that everything could not be left to the monetary policy of the bank. A Europe-wide fiscal response was needed as well. Precisely as I dared to hope in a commentary earlier this year
column6: Merkel has seized the opportunity with both hands. Hats off to her.

column1: But there are also longer-term developments underpinning my hopeful dream. Berlin now has a critical mass of politicians
column2: officials
column3: journalists
column4: thinktanks and foundations who are thinking hard about what Europe’s strategy should be – and not just for the current German presidency of the EU. If a black-green (CDU/CSU-Green) coalition government emerges from next autumn’s general election
column5: that will only strengthen its European commitment. In the European Council on Foreign Relations’ recent EU-wide survey of foreign policy professionals
column6: 97% of those asked said Germany is the most influential country in the EU and 82% identified it as the “most-contacted” country. In Europe
column7: Germany is the indispensable nation.

column1: Yet
column2: awoken from my daydream by a cold shower of rain
column3: something the British summer is always happy to provide
column4: I see two major difficulties down the road ahead. Ever since the first unification of Germany
column5: a century and a half ago
column6: the country has wrestled with the problem of what Kurt-Georg Kiesinger
column7: a federal chancellor in the 1960s
column8: called its “critical size”. His near-namesake
column9: former US secretary of state Henry Kissinger
column10: put it more pithily: “too big for Europe
column11: too small for the world”. Kissinger’s formulation is brilliant but not quite right. Germany is too big to be just another European country
column12: but it’s not big enough to be a hegemon even in Europe

column1: So however wise a German strategy may be
column2: it cannot be realised without a set of international partners. The giant challenges of climate change and the emergent authoritarian superpower China – which is to the early 21st century world what Wilhelmine Germany was to early 20th century Europe – cannot be addressed unless you have the United States under a President Joe Biden returning to a constructive internationalism
column3: and the strategic engagement of powers like Australia
column4: Japan and India. Europe’s own problems cannot be solved without the active involvement not just of France and Spain but also of Italy (understandably preoccupied with its own internal problems)
column5: Poland (currently peddling an archaic anti-German line)
column6: the Netherlands and others. For foreign and security policy
column7: Europe also needs the clout of Britain – which is the big strategic reason for Merkel to try to broker the Brexit deal which I believe still can be done this autumn.

column1: The other great unknown is German public opinion. On the face of it
column2: there seems to be a solid pro-European
column3: internationalist consensus in German society. But underneath
column4: there are some worrying trends. The outside world is always alert to any possible revival of a greater Germany tendency
column5: yet more prevalent is still the greater Switzerland tendency: just leave us alone to be rich and free. The German stereotype of south Europeans in the Eurozone scrounging off virtuous
column6: hardworking north Europeans has not simply disappeared. The way electoral support surged for the xenophobic nationalist Alternative for Germany (AfD) following the refugee crisis was a worrying sign. So are well-documented reports of far-right sympathies in the military and security services. And contemporary Germany society has not yet gone through the test of really hard times at home.

column1: To be denounced by Donald Trump as “delinquent” must be infuriating
column2: but the emotional extremism of German alienation from the United States goes far beyond eminently rational anti-Trumpism. A real ideological and geopolitical myopia is revealed in the finding of a recent Körber foundation poll that only 37% of Germans think having close relations with the US is more important for Germany than having close relations with China
column3: while a staggering 36% say it’s more important to get on with China and another 13% favour equidistance.

column1: Germany cannot simply conjure up the necessary international partners
column2: but this is something that’s in its own hands. As a distinguished former German ambassador to China
column3: Volker Stanzel
column4: has argued
column5: foreign policy can no longer be left to the elites. It needs to be anchored in a much wider process of education and democratic debate. That’s all the more true because
column6: due to the country’s “critical size” and the shadows of its past
column7: the international role that the German public needs to understand and support is this historically unusual
column8: difficult
column9: carefully balanced one. For Germany can never be the prancing hegemon
column10: just the steady
column11: skilful football midfielder who keeps the whole team together – and doesn’t even get the applause for scoring goals. Yet sometimes those midfielders are the true heroes of the team.

Bad-tempered
column2: late-running EU summits have hardly been unusual over the last decade of eurozone crisis and endless rows over migration. But the latest gathering of EU leaders
column3: now in its fourth day with no end in sight
column4: may be one of the most acrimonious yet.

column1: With a €1.8tn (£1.6tn) financial plan on the table
column2: the stakes are huge. Nobody expected talks to be easy
column3: but expectations of a historic step towards EU fiscal union had risen since Angela Merkel abandoned Germany’s long-standing opposition to shared debt – reversing the position she took during the eurozone crisis.

column1: After a friendly start
column2: where EU leaders exchanged playful elbow bumps and birthday greetings
column3: the temperature soon plummeted.

column1: Dinner on Friday evening was “a bit surly” according to the Dutch prime minister
column2: Mark Rutte
column3: after other leaders rounded on him over his insistence on being able to veto others’ access to a €750bn coronavirus recovery fund
column4: if their economic reforms were deemed inadequate. Bulgaria’s prime minister
column5: Boyko Borissov
column6: accused Rutte of wanting to be “the police of Europe”
column7: while Poland’s leader
column8: Mateusz Morawiecki
column9: called Rutte and his “frugal” north European allies “misers”. Italy’s prime minister
column10: Giuseppe Conte
column11: accused the frugals of blackmail.

column1: The second big fight centred on the size of recovery fund grants: a proposed €500bn in grants for the hardest hit countries has been shaved down to €390bn. But it remains unclear if that is acceptable for the frugal club of the Netherlands
column2: Austria
column3: Denmark
column4: Sweden
column5: and unofficial member
column6: Finland.

column1: Leaders battled through Sunday night over the size of recovery grants
column2: finally quitting the Europa HQ shortly after 5.45am. As tempers flared during the small hours
column3: Emmanuel Macron banged his fist on the table
column4: saying he was ready to walk out if “sterile blockages” continued. The French president criticised Rutte for behaving like David Cameron
column5: the former UK prime minister whose EU strategy “ended badly” in Macron’s words.

column1: The British are the ghosts at the negotiating table – another big stumbling block is the size of the rebates on offer to the frugal four
column2: discounts on their EU budget contributions that came after Margaret Thatcher got “our money back” in 1984.

column1: The previous night
column2: Merkel and Macron walked out of midnight talks with the frugals – a display of unity by the Franco-German pair
column3: who first proposed a massive recovery fund underpinned by taboo-breaking EU borrowing on financial markets to pull the EU out of the worst recession in its history.

column1: At stake is a €750bn coronavirus recovery plan intended to pull the EU out of a historic recession
column2: as well as a €1.074tn seven-year budget. One big row is how far countries should be able to access grants. France and Germany
column3: backed by the European commission
column4: proposed €500bn in grants (the rest in loans) targeted at countries hardest hit by coronavirus. That has been whittled down to €390bn in a compromise plan
column5: but whether it will be accepted remains unclear.

column1: Angela Merkel and Emmanuel Macron think the unprecedented crisis requires serious financial firepower
column2: backed by Italy and Spain
column3: who see Covid-19 as a test case for European solidarity.  A group of northern states - Austria
column4: Denmark
column5: the Netherlands and Sweden
column6: styled the “frugal four” - are wary of fiscal transfers.  Dutch prime minister Mark Rutte takes the most hardline position
column7: as he also wants his government to be able to veto recovery funds if a recipient is deemed failing on economic reforms.

column1: Adding to the complexity is an argument  over tying EU funds to respect for democratic values. Hungary and Poland
column2: currently subject to EU inquiries on the rule of law
column3: want a veto on any attempt to remove funds from a rogue government. France
column4: Germany and the Scandinavian countries
column5: who fear the weakening of democratic checks and balances
column6: say there must be a link. Now some diplomats fear the issue could become hostage to a recovery plan deal.

column1: Jennifer Rankin in Brussels
“They ran off in a bad mood
column2: ” Rutte complained. “We are ready to compromise without giving up ambition
column3: ” said Macron.

column1: Yet by Monday
column2: Macron said there was “a spirit of compromise”
column3: while Rutte said “progress had been made”.

column1: The third battleground also put the Dutch in the firing line
column2: as Hungary’s prime minister
column3: Viktor Orbán
column4: compared Rutte to the communist police. The Netherlands
column5: along with many EU governments
column6: wants to tie European funds to upholding democratic values – a plan staunchly opposed by Hungary and Poland
column7: both subject to EU investigations on the rule of law.

column1: The communist police used “unclarified legal terms
column2: exactly the same which is written in the proposal of the Dutchman
column3: ” said Orbán recalling his own encounters with state police as a young activist.

column1: Orbán’s chief spokesman tweeted that “only Hungarians should get to decide how to spend the money that belongs to [Hungary]” – a stance that is likely to raise hackles
column2: as the country receives six times more from the EU than it pays in.

column1: Some EU diplomats fear that western Europe’s united stance on the rule of law is beginning to fragment. “It’s a bargaining chip
column2: ” said one EU diplomat. The frugals give the impression “we might settle for less rule of law
column3: if you agree to the overall recovery plan”
column4: the diplomat said.

column1: As the fourth day wore on
column2: agreement on the €1.8tn deal (the EU’s next seven-year budget and recovery plan) was still hanging in the balance. Some EU sources are already pencilling in a rematch summit in late July or late August – the latter seen as providing more breathing space for countries to rethink their red lines. The head of the European Central Bank
column3: Christine Lagarde
column4: warned against a quick deal that falls short. “The leaders’ agreement should be ambitious in terms of size and composition of the package ... even if it takes a bit more time
column5: ” she told Reuters.

column1: The longer EU leaders stay in Brussels
column2: the higher the political price of leaving with no deal. Failure to agree will weigh heavily on the EU. The hardest-hit countries already have access to a €540bn financial cushion
column3: but France
column4: Germany
column5: Italy and Spain see this as inadequate to the scale of the looming recession.

column1: Leaving Brussels empty-handed would also be a damaging political blow
column2: tarnishing the EU’s prestige and triggering questions about its ability to act in a crisis. It would also undermine the newish leaders of the EU institutions
column3: the European commission president
column4: Ursula von der Leyen
column5: the architect of the recovery plan
column6: as well the European council president
column7: Charles Michel
column8: the main deal-broker.

column1: Even with a deal
column2: this bitter summit has exposed poisonous mistrust between some leaders
column3: as well as the EU’s struggle to deal with nationalists in central Europe
column4: who are feared to be trampling on Europe’s basic values. A few bad-tempered days in Brussels may leave political scars."

The leaders have been in intense debates over the size of the recovery fund for countries hit hardest by the coronavirus pandemic and the EU’s seven-year budget
column2: known as the multi-financial framework
column3: which is due to start next year.

column1: There are also stark differences over the nature of the conditions attached to the emergency funding and the balance between grants and loans on offer. The money will be borrowed from the capital markets by the European commission.
Rutte has insisted he cannot be expected to take on extra national debt in order for the EU to make cash payments to member states without his parliament having a say.
In response
column2: Orbán
column3: the nationalist prime minister of Hungary
column4: who was an anti-communist dissident in his youth
column5: accused Rutte of aping Soviet methods to crush dissent by failing to properly set out the terms on which funds would be blocked.

column1: The Netherlands is seeking reassurance that commonly issued debt will be properly spent and wants the ability to hold back disbursements where there are governance concerns.

column2: ” Orbán told reporters

column2: Rutte said on Monday: “We are not here because we are going to be visitors at each others birthday party later. We are here because we do business for our own country. We are all pros.”

column4: with “frugal” countries of the Netherlands
column5: Austria

column1: The summit had been markedly bad-tempered from the first day on Friday
column2: and Michel was forced to table a new set of proposals on Saturday morning in an attempt to reboot the talks.

column1: In recent days the UK has seen a sudden sharp increase in Covid-19 infection numbers
column2: leading to fears that a second wave of cases is beginning.

column1: Epidemics of infectious diseases behave in different ways but the 1918 influenza pandemic that killed more than 50 million people is regarded as a key example of a pandemic that occurred in multiple waves
column2: with the latter more severe than the first. It has been replicated – albeit more mildly – in subsequent flu pandemics. Until now that had been what was expected from Covid-19.

column1: How and why multiple-wave outbreaks occur
column2: and how subsequent waves of infection can be prevented
column3: has become a staple of epidemiological modelling studies and pandemic preparation
column4: which have looked at everything from social behaviour and health policy to vaccination and the buildup of community immunity
column5: also known as herd immunity.

column1: This is being watched very carefully. Without a vaccine
column2: and with no widespread immunity to the new disease
column3: one alarm is being sounded by the experience of Singapore
column4: which has seen a sudden resurgence in infections despite being lauded for its early handling of the outbreak.

column1: Although Singapore instituted a strong contact tracing system for its general population
column2: the disease re-emerged in cramped dormitory accommodation used by thousands of foreign workers with inadequate hygiene facilities and shared canteens.

column1: Singapore’s experience
column2: although very specific
column3: has demonstrated the ability of the disease to come back strongly in places where people are in close proximity and its ability to exploit any weakness in public health regimes set up to counter it.

column1: In June 2020
column2: Beijing suffered from a new cluster of coronavirus cases which caused authorities to re-implement restrictions that China had previously been able to lift. In the UK
column3: the city of Leicester was unable to come out of lockdown because of the development of a new spike of coronavirus cases. Clusters also emerged in Melbourne
column4: requiring a re-imposition of lockdown conditions.

column1: Conventional wisdom among scientists suggests second waves of resistant infections occur after the capacity for treatment and isolation becomes exhausted. In this case the concern is that the social and political consensus supporting lockdowns is being overtaken by public frustration and the urgent need to reopen economies.
However Linda Bauld
column2: professor of public health at the University of Edinburgh
column3: says “‘Second wave’ isn’t a term that we would use at the current time
column4: as the virus hasn’t gone away
column5: it’s in our population
column6: it has spread to 188 countries so far
column7: and what we are seeing now is essentially localised spikes or a localised return of a large number of cases.”

column1: The overall threat declines when susceptibility of the population to the disease falls below a certain threshold or when widespread vaccination becomes available.

In general terms the ratio of susceptible and immune individuals in a population at the end of one wave determines the potential magnitude of a subsequent wave. The worry is that with a vaccine still many months away
column2: and the real rate of infection only being guessed at
column3: populations worldwide remain highly vulnerable to both resurgence and subsequent waves.

column1: EU leaders were poles apart on the terms of a €1.8tn (£1.6tn) budget and recovery package as they met for the first time in five months on Friday
column2: with Angela Merkel warning of the possibility of talks dragging into a second destabilising summer summit.

column1: Spain’s prime minister
column2: Pedro Sánchez
column3: told fellow leaders in Brussels they had an “obligation” to agree on a response to an economic downturn unparalleled since the Great Depression.

column1: His comments were echoed by Italy’s Giuseppe Conte
column2: whose country
column3: like Spain
column4: was among those hit hardest by the coronavirus pandemic and faces a devastating recession.

column1: But EU diplomats said little progress had been made in the first day of what were described as “intense discussions”. “So far the temperature in the room hasn’t substantially risen”
column2: an EU diplomat said. “It seems leaders are preserving their energy for what is to come.” The summit is slated to finish on Saturday but it could run on into Sunday if the negotiations are fruitful
column3: sources said.

column1: The German chancellor
column2: whose country holds the rotating presidency of the EU
column3: offered a notably downbeat assessment about the level of unity among leaders as she arrived in Brussels.

column1: “The differences are still very large and so I can’t predict that we will achieve a result this time
column2: ” Merkel said. “It would be desirable
column3: but we also have to be realistic. And it really does take a great deal of willingness to compromise on the part of everyone if we are to achieve something that is good for Europe. In this respect I expect very difficult negotiations.”

column1: Merkel and the French president
column2: Emmanuel Macron
column3: have backed plans to borrow on the capitals markets to fund a €750bn recovery package
column4: but others are at loggerheads over the size of the plan
column5: the terms under which the cash is distributed
column6: and the conditions attached.

column1: There are also major obstacles in getting agreement on the EU’s next seven-year budget
column2: which is due to start next year. The so-called frugal countries of the Netherlands
column3: Austria
column4: Sweden and Denmark are lobbying for less spending but they are also seeking to retain their valuable budget rebates. Denmark’s prime minister
column5: Mette Frederiksen
column6: said she planned to push for cuts to the budget ceiling. “We are not in favour of just spending a lot more money in Brussels
column7: ” she said.

column1: The European parliament
column2: however
column3: wants to loosen the purse strings and has threatened to block a proposal from the European council president
column4: Charles Michel
column5: to spend nearly €1.1tn over the seven years
column6: a smaller sum than previously tabled.

column1: Mark Rutte
column2: the Dutch prime minister
column3: said he believed the chance of finding agreement given the differences was “less than 50%. What’s more
column4: in the end
column5: content is more important than speed. A weak compromise will not take Europe any further.”

column1: Rutte said Hungary’s rejection of any rule-of-law conditions on the distribution of the recovery fund could be “a very big problem”. Hungary’s leader
column2: Viktor Orbán
column3: has threatened to veto any deal that would involve the commission linking the quality of governance at home with a right to EU handouts.

column1: Hungary is facing EU proceedings over claims it has undermined the independence of the country’s judiciary.
