column1: ‘It would be ideal if you could hit a deer
column2: ” Julian Reichelt
column3: editor-in-chief of Europe’s largest tabloid
column4: Bild Zeitung
column5: told his chauffeur. “Guardian readers could do with a bit more colour.” We had reached escape velocity out of ice-encrusted Düsseldorf. The Mercedes S-Class locked into place like a bobsled on the Autobahn. I sat shotgun with Reichelt’s assortment of sports gear
column6: a hockey stick between my legs. “We are lucky in our driver today
column7: ” Reichelt said
column8: deadpan. “Last time we hit a wild boar and the boar and the car went flying.”

column1: I was travelling with Reichelt on one of his publicity tours across Germany. For the past two years
column2: he has made an appointment once a month to commune with groups of Bild’s 1.3 million readers. “You have to feel their emotions
column3: ” he told me from the backseat. “You have to listen to their hearts.”

column1: Reichelt
column2: who is 40
column3: made his name as a war reporter in Syria
column4: but today confines most of his battle courage to Twitter
column5: where he enjoys needling the German political establishment and barging into leftwing echo chambers. In person
column6: Reichelt exudes a twitchy exuberance
column7: like a fighter pilot who has managed to smuggle champagne into the cockpit. His eyes restlessly gauge the world around him
column8: clocking who he needs to avoid and who he needs to attract. Into his phone
column9: he volleys directives to subeditors
column10: assistants and the band of young male disciples he sends around the world to collect stories. “The leading populist in western Germany
column11: ” is how Albrecht von Lucke
column12: editor of the prestigious left-liberal monthly Blätter

column1: Available at train stations
column2: supermarkets
column3: bakeries
column4: kiosks
column5: factories
column6: Portuguese beach resorts
column7: online
column8: and everywhere else Germans buy things
column9: Bild Zeitung squats like a large toad on German life. Bild
column10: which was partly modelled on the Daily Mirror
column11: is the largest newsprint publication in the world that uses Roman characters. Unlike its closest analogue in Britain
column13: it has no real national competitors. Twenty regional editions seep into every pore of the country. Each month
column14: its website attracts about 25 million readers. Bild is the prize battleship of Axel Springer
column15: the German company founded in 1945 by the rightwing publisher of the same name. Today
column16: Axel Springer is the largest media publishing firm in Europe
column17: and is valued at about €7bn. Last year
column18: the US private equity firm KKR acquired a 44% stake in the company.

column1: For decades
column2: Bild was an object of scorn for any self-respecting West German of social democratic orientation. In a political culture more conformist and decorous than most of its western peers
column3: Bild functioned like the Las Vegas strip
column4: concentrating all of the Federal Republic’s seediness in one place. Seven days a week
column5: Bild pumped free-market mantras
column6: alongside ads for car tyres and chicken wings
column7: into the stiff arteries of cold war West Germany. Bild decried long hair on men and the marriage of its top models to foreigners. It genuflected before South African apartheid
column8: Greek dictatorship
column9: Bavarian sedans and American Pershing missiles. Above all
column10: Bild dedicated itself to the destruction of communist East Germany
column11: and fought a long battle against what it viewed as enemy collaborators in the leftist student movement at home.

column1: Such was the stature of Bild in West Germany that in 1965
column2: after the daily rose in price from 10 to 15 pfennigs
column3: Axel Springer
column4: who referred to Bild as his “dog on a chain”
column5: proposed to Chancellor Ludwig Erhard that the state introduce a special 15 pfennig coin to make it easier to purchase the paper. Meanwhile
column6: the East German Stasi was so impressed by Bild as a state propaganda tool that it crafted its own – imaginatively titled – NEUE Bild Zeitung
column7: which was sold at the border with West Germany
column8: where it conspicuously failed to wean class enemies off the original.

column1: Today Bild is paradoxically less influential than it was in the 60s
column2: but more politically important. “I read it first in the morning because it is the agenda-setter
column3: ” says Josef Joffe
column4: the publisher-editor of the liberal weekly
column5: Die Zeit. “Politicos in Berlin probably read it first in the morning as well.” The paper enjoys a close relationship with the German political elite. The former German chancellor
column6: Helmut Kohl
column7: was one of the best men at the wedding of former Bild editor
column8: Kai Diekmann
column9: and in 2008
column10: Diekmann performed the same role for Kohl at his wedding. “Kohl rules with Bild
column11: ” the Nobel laureate Heinrich Böll wrote
column14: affirmed the practice: “To govern I need Bild

column1: Bild’s intimate relationship with some of Germany’s most powerful figures is a vestige of its days as the country’s decisive reputation maker-and-breaker. The former defence minister
column2: now the president of the European commission
column3: Ursula von der Leyen
column4: has shown up at one of Reichelt’s dinner parties at the Bild offices in Berlin
column5: and for the past few years Bild has hosted part of the annual Munich Security Conference
column6: the equivalent of Davos for the global defence industry. Although Angela Merkel has not ingratiated herself with the Springer complex — despite receiving early political support from Bild — her husband is nevertheless paid €10
column7: 000 a year to grace the board of the nonprofit Friede Springer Foundation
column8: named after Axel Springer’s widow.

column1: Despite its traditional proximity to power
column2: Bild has mutated into something beyond a stalwart defender of the German status quo. Now
column3: says Joffe
column4: it is “an equal-opportunity anti-establishment force”. “Previous Bild editors made their alliances more based on personal feeling
column5: ” says the journalist Stefan Niggemeier
column6: who in 2004 co-founded the BILDBlog
column7: a website that corrects Bild’s factual errors and misrepresentations. “But Reichelt is different. He is an actually political person.”

column1: Reichelt’s agenda is marked less by novelty than by a chest-crunching resuscitation of Bild’s core commitments: pro-US
column2: pro-Nato
column3: pro-Israel
column4: pro-austerity
column5: pro-capital
column6: anti-Russia
column7: anti-China. According to the Bild worldview
column8: the best way to counter the left is to portray its demands as totalitarian
column9: and the best way to kill off the far right is to cannibalise its grievances. While Bild prints relatively little material that a supporter of the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) party would object to
column10: Reichelt sees the party as a threat to his effort to remake the German political scene. “We want nothing to do with the imbeciles of the AfD
column11: ” he told me. “The way to destroy them is to make room for their voters in what used to be the political mainstream of this country.”

column1: Bild’s main attack targets remain Germany’s “Gutmenschen” – the do-gooders
column2: vegetarians
column3: Greens and 1968ers who are treated as parasites and irritants to Germany’s robust economy and middle class. More recently
column4: the paper’s sights have also turned on Merkel and her party
column5: the Christian Democratic Union (CDU). “The paper’s constant targeting of Merkel
column6: but also its current take on refugees and all sorts of minorities definitely reproduces rhetorical elements of the AfD
column7: ” says Fatma Aydemir
column8: a novelist and columnist for the leftwing daily Tageszeitung
column9: known as Taz. In the absence of serious challenges from within Merkel’s own party
column10: or from other parties – she has been chancellor for 14 years
column11: a tenure surpassed only by Kohl and Bismarck – Bild has attempted to make itself into that opposition. Yet any populist challenger finds itself in the hard position of convincing Germans that Merkel’s very successful form of reactive politics has run out of historical steam. “We are the voice of ordinary people
column13: they would really think the whole system is against them.”

column1: We pulled into the fire station in the proud town of Sprockhövel
column2: about 18 miles north-east of Düsseldorf
column3: where a few dozen people greeted us
column4: most of them in firefighter gear. Bild beer steins
column5: Bild lighters and other Bild paraphernalia had been laid out on the firefighters’ bar. Reichelt marched out to the garage with the fire engines
column6: where a small table stood. He took a sip of beer
column7: and addressed the group with aplomb.

column1: “It’s an honour to be among you because
column2: as you know
column3: I like to meet our readers face to face
column4: ” Reichelt said. He wanted to know why they had become firefighters. “It’s that feeling that we’re brothers
column5: ” said one of the younger firefighters. “That we have each other’s back. You don’t get that feeling elsewhere.” Yes
column6: Reichelt agreed
column7: courage was in short supply in Germany. Courage: that was a virtue Bild could get behind.

column1: “The only trouble we have with Bild
column2: ” said another
column3: old fireman
column4: “is your picture contest!”

column1: Reichelt made a show of pricking up his ears. “Oh really? Is there something we’re doing wrong? I welcome your criticism!”
“It encourages people to send in the most sensational photos possible
column2: but people block the way to fires because they’re trying to take photos for Bild!”

column1: Reichelt’s face registered the gravity of the charge. He moved like a matador
column2: coaxing anyone else with negative things to say to hurl them at his face. “Look
column3: that’s terrible
column4: and we’ll have to stop that. I’ll get on that immediately
column5: ” he told the man who complained about the photo contest.

column1: After Reichelt had presided over dinner in the firefighters’ hall
column2: we got back into the Mercedes and sped into the dark. I asked him why he goes out of his way for pow-wows with his readership. “Bild is the last national campfire experience in German life
column3: ” he told me. “It’s the last thing that Germans can come together for.” It was a curious way of viewing a newspaper that has
column4: for decades
column5: polarised a country otherwise committed to “consensus politics” into two camps: Bild readers and Bild haters. Yet Reichelt delivered this well-greased lump of Springer-speak with what seemed like sincerity.

column1: The experience of reading Bild is a sugar-rush of gossip
column2: accompanied by the clanging gong of headlines. As is traditional
column3: scandals are designated for the front page
column4: but in Bild’s current iteration
column5: fear-mongering appears to be privileged over celebrity soup: “Germany’s most dangerous gang leader is free again” reads a typical headline. Alongside the main stories
column6: the front page also lists the dollar exchange rate and the price of gold
column7: as well as the “winners” and “losers” of the day. A loser might be Prince Charles
column8: whose charity
column9: according to the Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project
column10: may have received dark money from Russians. (“Bild says: black money for blue blood!”) Or a loser might be Sergei Lavrov
column11: the foreign minister of Russia
column13: coordinated campaign” by the German government to fund misinformation in Russia: “Bild says: what nonsense!” Winners tend to be businessmen making big deals or celebrities being nice to children.

column1: The most reliably absurdist section of Bild typically falls on page 3 or 4
column2: with a report from Paul Ronzheimer
column3: Reichelt’s star protege. There one finds Ronzheimer posing in front of a Brazilian forest fire; Ronzheimer posing in front of the Venezuelan opposition leader; Ronzheimer posing in front of a Hong Kong street fight; Ronzheimer posing in front of Syrian refugees; Ronzheimer disbursing fake Drachmas to poor Greeks encouraging them to leave Europe. His stories appear as little frames of text under giant
column4: hard-won selfies
column5: as if to declare: Bild was here! “Ronzheimer does have a discernible function
column6: ” says von Lucke. “He makes Bild readers feel like they’re reading a paper that has incredible access
column7: that Bild has a global presence.”

column1: As editor
column2: Reichelt sees himself less as a news impresario than as an emotional entrepreneur. “Journalism is basically about emotions
column3: as all of the other news outlets in this country seem to have forgotten
column4: ” he told me. Reichelt likes to point out what he sees as the shared delusions of the more “respectable” German press. He gave the example of Merkel
column5: around whom he said the press had created an “elaborate mythology” that she has such natural wit and is extremely clever
column6: whereas her skill lay in identifying the direction of the prevailing winds.

column1: For Reichelt
column2: Merkel represents the depoliticisation of German society
column3: a process that has obscured the faultlines between conservatives and liberals. For almost two decades
column4: at a series of decisive moments
column5: Merkel has deftly stolen her antagonists’ platforms out from under them. In 2003
column6: she phased in a neoliberal agenda in the CDU
column7: but when it nearly backfired at the polls two years later
column8: she started to introduce programmes from the Social Democrats. In the wake of the Fukushima disaster
column9: Merkel became anti-nuclear overnight. Merkel’s response to the 1 million migrants entering Germany in the summer of 2015 has been widely interpreted as an instance of principle over pragmatism – a chancellor seizing the chance to make amends for her nation’s past – but even then
column10: Merkel had carefully weighed German public opinion
column11: and promptly ramped up anti-refugee legislation once the middle class’s pro-refugee enthusiasm had subsided. The leftwing sociologist Wolfgang Streeck once described Merkel as “a postmodern politician with a premodern
column12: Machiavellian contempt for both causes and people”.

column1: This shape-shifting has made German politics a much more difficult game to play
column2: and Reichelt sees it as his job to restore the old pre-Merkel divisions. To this end
column3: he has made Bild into a loudspeaker for some of the chancellor’s fiercest critics. In early September 2018
column4: in the wake of violent far-right demonstrations in the Saxon city of Chemnitz
column5: Reichelt met with Hans-Georg Maassen
column6: the head of German intelligence
column7: and offered him the the pulpit of Bild when Maassen wanted to contradict Merkel’s account of anti-migrant “hunts” that had allegedly taken place in Chemnitz. Maassen’s attempt to cast doubt on the chancellor’s version of events got him removed from his post
column8: but it transformed him into one of the most vocal martyrs of the German right.

column1: The real trouble for Merkel’s rightwing critics within her party
column2: however
column3: is that she remains the most popular politician in the land – with her approval ratings reaching 80% during the coronavirus pandemic
column4: considerably higher than her closest European peers. Meanwhile
column5: their own political position – a kind of xenophobic neoliberalism that would stress the free movement of capital over the free movement of “undesirable” people – has been vigorously touted by the AfD. It will take some doing to wrangle their copyright back.

column1: Since his earliest teenage years
column2: Reichelt dreamed of becoming the editor of Bild Zeitung. I asked him how someone like himself
column3: born in Hamburg in 1980 – when Bild was still considered radioactive by most teachers and students across Germany – could have concocted such an ambition. “I was born into a family of journalists
column4: ” Reichelt told me. “In our household
column5: Axel Springer was a hero
column6: and Heinrich Böll was an enemy.” Reichelt
column7: who perfected his English abroad at Cushing Academy
column8: a boarding school in Massachusetts
column9: looked up to young Bild reporters as bourgeois paladins pitted against the leftwing rabble of 1980s Hamburg
column10: a city teeming with wealth
column11: but also one of the hubs of the country’s anarchist left.

column1: “You must understand that Bild was right about the three major questions of postwar German life
column2: ” Reichelt said. “We backed Israel …
column3: which you can hardly say for the international left. We backed the USA …
column4: which the student protesters didn’t want. And we were convinced that German reunification could work
column5: unlike those leftist worthies
column6: [Jürgen] Habermas and Günter Grass.” Reichelt is correct that Bild had confidence in a reunified Germany that could purge itself of any lingering leftwing utopian residues in the East. “The German left basically gave up on reunification in the 1980s
column7: ” Niggemeier told me. “The cause became almost quaint for them. Meanwhile
column8: Axel Springer built the Bild headquarters right smack up against the Berlin Wall – and now
column9: look
column10: it’s in the middle of Berlin. So they can say: ‘We never gave up.’”

column1: It is hard to think of an institution more tightly bound up with the history of the Federal Republic than Bild Zeitung. The first introduction that some young Germans get to the paper today is Günter Wallraff’s withering exposé
column2: Der Aufmacher (The Leader-writer)
column3: which continues to be taught in a few secondary schools four decades after its publication. In 1977
column4: Wallraff went undercover in order to try to expose Bild as a giant fabrication mill. Instead he discovered an underworld of cynical publicists intent on becoming cheerleaders of the postwar German economic boom. In one scene
column5: which describes a regular day at the Bild office
column6: one of the Bild reporters listens to a distressed caller who has called into a fake suicide-prevention hotline that Bild has set up
column7: and whispers to Wallraff: “He’s about to jump off the balcony any minute
column8: he’s nearly there!”

column1: I visited Wallraff last year in his light-filled studio in the Ehrenfeld neighbourhood of Cologne. His office is full of African art
column2: and the books of his heroes
column3: such as Upton Sinclair. “In the 1970s and 80s
column4: Bild was in total control of the media
column5: and there was very little being done about it
column6: ” Wallraff told me
column7: over a game of ping-pong in his workshop. “If you were their enemy
column8: they made you into a terrorist.”

column1: We retreated back into Wallraff’s studio
column2: where he had the latest copy of Bild. The headline was about Boris Johnson’s hair: “This mop now rules Britain”. “I haven’t flipped through it in a while
column3: ” Wallraff told me. “But I can see it’s taken a more civilised tone. You should have seen it in the 1970s: all of the articles in support of the dictatorship in Greece and Chile
column4: the articles in favour of apartheid.”

column1: Wallraff remains a heroic figure for many Germans who remember Bild as an enemy of the student protesters of 1968 – whom the newspaper referred to as “rioters”
column2: “a radical danger”
column3: and “left-academic fascists”. One of Springer’s main targets was the Marxist thinker and activist Rudi Dutschke
column4: who was shot in 1968 in Berlin by a rightwing fanatic inspired by the murderer of Martin Luther King Jr. A few days before the attack
column5: Bild had referred to Dutschke as “State Enemy #1”
column6: and it had previously run headlines such as “Stop Dutschke now!” After the shooting
column7: tens of thousands of people took to thestreets of Berlin
column8: chanting
column9: “Bild shot as well!”. Dutschke suffered brain damage from the attack
column10: and died years later as a result of his injuries.

column1: “West Germany in the 1960s was a completely authoritarian state
column2: ” said Gretchen Dutschke-Klotz – Dutschke’s widow
column3: and an author of several books about 1968 – when we met in Berlin earlier this year. “Bild was the symbol of that.” Dutschke-Klotz agrees with Wallraff that Bild is a milder publication today
column4: and that the 1968ers triumphed over it. “Society was full of old Nazis then
column5: ” she said. “It was full of people who
column6: outside of the Weimar Republic
column7: had barely lived in a democracy. Bild has been beaten in the cultural sphere
column8: especially if you consider the place of women in society now
column9: or climate politics.”

column1: But in the 60s there were others who took a different view: that what they were witnessing was the irreversible Springerisation of society. Heinrich Böll devoted not one
column2: but three books
column3: including one of his literary masterpieces – The Lost Honour of Katharina Blum – to denouncing Bild
column4: which he credited not only with poisoning public life
column5: but also with wrecking the German language itself with “primitive bon-mot-ism”. Bild
column6: wrote Böll in 1972
column7: was “no longer crypto-fascistic
column8: no longer fascisoid
column9: but naked fascism: incitement
column10: lies
column11: garbage”.

column1: The most visible element of West Germany’s hard left
column2: the Red Army Faction
column3: and its leading voice
column4: Ulrike Meinhof
column5: took Böll’s criticism a considerable step further. In May 1972
column6: after calling for the expropriation of Springer
column7: and holding public hearings against the company
column8: the Red Army Faction bombed the Axel Springer offices in Hamburg
column9: injuring at least 17 people. Meinhof declared the attacks were in the name of Springer’s victims: communists
column10: Palestinians
column11: foreign workers. “Who else were they going to attack?” Dutschke-Klotz told me. “The mayor of Berlin? He had already apologised for attacking student protesters. Bild was the obvious target.”

column1: That was almost 50 years ago. After the cold war
column2: Bild became a celebrity rag
column3: which former adversaries could dismiss as a more innocuous symptom of a depoliticised culture than an ideological lodestar in its own right. Kai Diekmann
column4: who edited the paper from 2001 to 2015
column5: neatly exhibited the contradictions of German conservatism in the Merkel era. A faithful page of Helmut Kohl
column6: he wanted to maintain Germany’s position as the prime European reaper of globalisation – the country’s export model depends on taking advantage of a currency weakened by its fellow Eurozone members – but also attacked expressions of globalisation within Germany’s borders.

column1: In his 2007 screed
column2: The Great Self-Deception
column3: Diekmann railed against the usual suspects of the German right: Muslims
column4: “multi-kulti” liberals and environmentalists. Diekmann’s idea was that the leftwards shuffle of the political consensus – exemplified in Merkel’s long-standing coalition with the Social Democrats – needed to be beaten back by an elite-led populist movement that would restore German conservatives to their former glory. The dream was to bring back good old-fashioned German values
column5: but keep the settings of German economic dominance in place. As the political face of this movement
column6: Diekmann favoured Merkel’s defence minister
column7: Karl-Theodor zu Guttenberg
column8: whose impeccably aristocratic credentials and Ted-talk persona would make him the ideal patrician-tribune of Germany’s silent majority. But the dream collapsed in 2011
column9: when Guttenberg fell into disgrace after it was discovered he had plagiarised his doctoral dissertation. Today
column10: the man who was once due to make German conservatism great again runs an investment firm in Manhattan
column11: and lives in Greenwich

column1: Reichelt took over Bild in 2018
column2: after his immediate predecessor
column3: Tanit Koch
column4: who tried to steer the paper in a more anodyne
column5: Merkel-friendly direction
column6: left the position. (Koch has spoken of her exit in cool terms
column7: telling a German news website that she felt she did not have the support of the Axel Springer CEO.) Under Reichelt’s tenure
column8: the paper quickly established itself as a battering ram against Merkel. Bild once again plays the game of guiding and reflecting public opinion on a host of questions. Among its enthusiasms are German cars and the arms industry. “At last! The Leopard-2 tank in Idlib and possibly soon in the fight against Assad’s Russian tanks (T-55
column10: T-72 and T-90)
column11: ” tweeted Bild’s political editor about recent events in Syria. “As always
column12: it takes a Turk to use a German tank for what it was built for.”

column1: In the higher echelons of German media
column2: Reichelt is perhaps best known for his dogfights on Twitter
column3: where
column4: until recently at least
column5: he spent a lot of time. “You never win anything on Twitter
column6: ” he told me
column7: a bit mournfully
column8: like a recovering addict. On the platform
column9: Reichelt can still be relied upon to submit world events to the logic of the Marvel universe. “Runaway Ed” Snowden is “the hero of global terrorism”. Trump’s assassination of the Iranian military leader Qassem Suleimani “freed the world of a monster”.

column1: There are a few non-populist positions Reichelt takes that have the appearance of principle. “He has staked out anti-Putin
column2: pro-Nato
column3: pro-Israel positions well beyond the standard German line
column4: ” says Niggemeier. But the majority of the paper’s content is an ever-shifting attempt to harness popular discontent rather than indoctrinate readers in any specific programme. Reichelt himself has
column5: for instance
column6: repeatedly come to Merkel’s defence on her decision not to close the border to Syrian refugees in 2015
column7: describing it as an ethical “no-brainer”
column8: but the paper goes to great lengths to associate migrants with crime
column9: and to demand deportations. On the environment
column10: one day Bild might be lamenting Merkel’s call to shutter coal factories by 2038 (“The coal deadline is going to cost us!” ran a headline about the prospective job losses.) But another day you might read that “Our government officials are destroying the environment!” atop an article detailing the 200
column11: 000 yearly flights German officials take between ministries in Berlin and Bonn. Like Merkel herself
column13: congenitally averse to letting crises go to waste.

column1: Several German journalists I spoke to attributed Reichelt’s heightened focus on Bild’s politics to a desperate attempt to counteract falling readership numbers. One of Reichelt’s heroes
column2: he told me
column3: is Franz-Josef Strauss
column4: a legendary conservative postwar politician
column5: who was famous for his political mantra: “Never allow a party right of the Christian Social Union”. Bild’s competitors on its right today come from Breitbart-esque news blogs such as Politically Incorrect. Bild seems to have done its best to outflank these outlets by covering the same kinds of stories as them
column6: often in much the same tone. In more than one case
column7: these articles have been false. In 2017
column8: the paper ran a story about a mob of Arab men assaulting women in a Frankfurt restaurant
column9: which police subsequently confirmed never happened.

column1: On the international front
column2: Bild echoes the calls of prominent German centrist liberals who believe Germany must assume a leading role in world affairs. “You have this ongoing performance whereby they call for Germany to be in the middle of the action
column3: but have no sense of responsibility for what that would entail
column4: ” says Blätter editor Albrecht von Lucke. “As soon as you have German troops deployed anywhere
column5: even on the most humanitarian mission imaginable
column6: who will be the first to cry out about it when the first guys fall in the war? Who will demand they come home and that it’s all been a mistake? Bild. You can count on that.” It is the same mentality that led one Bavarian AfD politician earlier this year to tweet against the banning of a beer festival because of Covid-19 – only to go on to sue the city of Rosenheim for the rise in cases after the beer festival did take place.

column1: The coronavirus pandemic initially caught Bild – and the German right – off guard. After the government’s strong response to the crisis
column2: Merkel seemed immune to criticism. Bild turned its focus to China. In April
column3: Reichelt published a public letter demanding €149bn in reparations from Beijing for the economic impact of Covid-19. “You shut down every newspaper and website that is critical of your rule
column4: ” Reichelt wrote in the letter
column5: “but not the stalls where bat soup is sold.” The stunt made headlines around the world
column6: and predictably enraged the Chinese embassy in Berlin. (A more expansive version of Bild’s letter by Springer’s CEO
column7: calling for the decoupling of western economies from China
column8: appeared in Springer’s respectable daily
column9: Die Welt.) It’s this willingness to play fast and loose with geopolitics
column10: now in a populist vein
column11: that makes Bild
column13: “much more dangerous than it ever was before”. (Not that Bild neglected the domestic front. “Despite corona restrictions
column14: 300 people gather at mosque for prayer”
column15: read one headline in April. “Churches closed for fear of Ramadan-chaos

column1: When public impatience with closed schools and shops began to mount in late May
column2: Bild
column3: having failed to gain traction with its usual scapegoats
column4: changed tack. Its new target was Germany’s leading virologist
column5: Christian Drosten
column6: who had become an unexpected celebrity thanks to his measured media interviews and his advisory role to Merkel’s government. On 25 May
column7: one of Bild’s reporters sent him an email
column8: claiming that other experts had serious criticisms of his latest study on Covid-19. The reporter demanded that Drosten respond within an hour. Instead
column9: Drosten published the email on Twitter and said there that he had “better things to do”. The subsequent article
column10: which tried to blow up minor statistical disagreements into a public assault on Drosten’s reputation
column11: backfired drastically. The German mediasphere rallied to his defence: #Ichhabebessereszutun (#betterthingstodo) became a hashtag. Georg Streiter
column12: a former deputy government spokesperson who also used to work at Bild and still praises the paper
column13: called it a baseless smear campaign
column14: and put the blame squarely on Reichelt. “It’s like dog owners
column15: ” he said. “The problem is usually at the top of the leash.”

column1: “We’re read by more German professors than any other publication
column2: ” Reichelt told me when I visited his office in the Axel Springer building in Berlin last year. “We’re read by the businessmen and the workers – and if some read us for ironic reasons
column3: well
column4: that’s fine
column5: too.”

column1: The Springer building is a giant glass structure that towers over nearby restaurants and embassies. (A new Springer building
column2: designed by Rem Koolhaas
column3: which resembles a damaged glass cube
column4: has been recently erected across the road.) Outside is a statue of a vaguely leprous-looking Axel Springer. A few streets over
column5: extending more than five storeys up the side of the headquarters of Taz
column6: the leftwing daily
column7: stands another piece of Bild lore: a giant high-relief sculpture of Kai Diekmann’s penis. This ostentatious invasion of the former Bild editor’s privacy
column8: unveiled in 2009
column9: sprouted out of a long conflict that had begun seven years earlier
column10: when Diekmann sued Taz for publishing a satirical article claiming he had undergone penis enhancement surgery in Miami. (At the time the judge ruled that
column11: as the nation’s leading purveyor and profiteer of gossip
column12: Diekmann must learn to live with this jab at this dignity.)

column1: With its smartly dressed assistants and ample supply of alcohol
column2: Bild’s headquarters in Berlin succeeds in transmitting a throwback aura. “In case there’s any doubt that I’m a real tabloid editor
column3: ” Reichelt said
column4: flashing me his lighter with a naked woman on it
column5: as he lit up a Gauloises Blue in his office. The room was strewn with Americana: a Kennedy photograph
column6: a Reagan biography. On top of a pile of books lay a child’s car seat
column7: next to a contemporary military-grade helmet that Reichelt wore when he covered the Syrian war for Springer. On the floor was a copy of the Financial Times. (“It repays the attention you give it every morning
column8: ” he told me. “It’s such a great product.”) I asked him why
column9: in the past couple of years
column10: Bild has reduced the number of naked women in the paper. “It wasn’t for any politically correct reason
column11: ” said Reichelt. “It’s just that when so much of your staff is female
column13: it just gets slightly awkward having to rank naked women with them day in and day out.”

column1: For the daily editorial meeting
column2: we entered a conference room
column3: where about 12 staffers were seated around a long table
column4: overlooking the Berlin skyline. “What have we got?” Reichelt asked. An image of Ursula von der Leyen was displayed on a big screen. “Can we give her a bit more brightness in her face?” asked one of the women at the table. “She looks a bit lugubrious.” “There we go
column5: there we go – more gravitas now
column6: ” said another woman.

column1: “What’s going on in that?” Reichelt said
column2: looking at a photo of a musician wearing lederhosen and a high-and-tight haircut. Reichelt was munching on chocolate now. I had been told that Bild editorial meetings could be rough going
column3: but this one was running smoothly.

column1: “That’s the folk singer Andreas Gabalier
column2: ” said another man at the table. “He going to be awarded the Karl Valentin prize in Munich
column3: but apparently he’s some kind of rightwing hardliner.”

column1: “What’s he doing in the photo?” Reichelt asked.
“Apparently he’s contorted his body into the form of a swastika
column2: ” the man replied.

column1: “I don’t quite see it
column2: ” Reichelt said.

column1: “Couldn’t it just be a walk-like-an-Egyptian dance move there?”
“Yes
column2: it’s all a bit unclear.”

column1: “All right
column2: we’ll just say that some people interpret it as a swastika.”

column1: “OK
column2: got it.”

column1: “Anything on the crime front?” Reichelt asked.
“We’ve got a paedophile paediatrician who sexually abused young boys for 15 years.”
“What was the ruling on this guy?” Reichelt asked.
“Judge has put him away for ever.”
“Nice. Great judge. Can I see a photo of him?” A photo of a grey-haired man named Roland Christiani flashed up on the screen. “What a great face! He looks like a professor
column2: ” Reichelt said. “Let’s give him a bump in the headline.”

column1: “How about ‘Judge locks paediatrician away for ever’?”
“I like it!” said Reichelt.

“Can I get a show of hands of how many of you are for the proposed speed limit?” Reichelt asked his lieutenants. Merkel’s government was threatening to impose a speed limit on German cars. A few hands went up. “God
column2: it’s just like the country at large – we’re completely divided on this
column3: ” Reichelt said. “Why are you against it?” He trained his eyes on an editor.

column1: “People just drive too fast. I’m tired of being scared on the autobahn when a car comes by doing 200km/h.”
“The trouble is that if you lower the speed limit I can’t make it to Hamburg in two hours any more
column2: ” another editor said.

column1: “You drive to Hamburg in two hours? That’s insane: maybe there should be a limit
column2: ” Reichelt joked.

column1: The trouble with the speed limit
column2: Reichelt later told me in private
column3: was that it interfered with the fundamental German ideal of freedom
column4: which is that
column5: within the rules
column6: you can do what you want. “There are too many Germans now waking up to find that if they eat meat and love their car
column7: they’re suddenly Nazis
column8: ” Reichelt said. “And that’s exactly how the German left speaks. They speak of their fellow citizens as criminals
column9: as people committing crimes against future generations
column10: and they even want to see if they can perhaps introduce punishments – to formally make this into a crime. But what about all those people who aren’t waiting for the delivery of their new Tesla?”

column1: Next year will almost certainly be Merkel’s last as chancellor. She has already relinquished her position as the secretary of the CDU. When it came to the struggle to determine her successor last year – specifically
column2: who would fill the role of secretary – Reichelt personally favoured the millionaire businessman Friedrich Merz over Merkel’s chosen successor
column3: Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer. But Reichelt hastened to point out that his favourites don’t get special treatment in Bild. “Did I want Merz to replace Merkel? Probably. Did we hesitate to [let him destroy himself]? No. Bild ran the interview that fatally damaged his campaign when he claimed he was a millionaire but still middle-class.” Reichelt said his newspaper had to be open to destroying reputations; this was a “most valuable weapon” that he would not sacrifice even for his own preferences.

column1: With Merkel’s departure on the horizon
column2: the fight is already brewing at the political centre
column3: as German regional leaders try to outbid each other with the comprehensiveness of their coronavirus crackdowns in a headlong appeal to the aged voters who still determine German politics. In the face of this political future
column4: Reichelt is sanguine. “Trump has shown that anything can happen – that’s just a fact
column5: ” he told me. “There is no reason that the future has to be dictated by Green parties and child protesters.”

column1: But there seems little chance that Bild will be able to retrieve any viable vintage of German conservative leadership from the cellar. “We have to hope that the radicalisation of Bild
column2: like the rise of autocrats around the world
column3: represents the last gasp of patriarchal thinking
column4: ” says Tania Martini
column5: a media critic for Taz. As Bild’s sputtering failure to derail Merkel and her scientists during the pandemic showed
column6: the German public is largely unwilling at present to diverge from what it takes to be the steady course. Threats to Bild’s position as Merkel’s leading critic are closer to home: the most scathing recent critique of Merkel’s government has come from outside any established political platform
column7: in the form of a blue-haired
column8: 27-year-old internet influencer who castigated the German political establishment for its record on climate change
column9: welfare
column10: and migration in a 55-minute
column11: copiously annotated YouTube video
column12: which has been viewed more than 17m times.

column1: The last time I saw Reichelt in his office
column2: last summer
column3: he wanted to talk about his preferred enemies. “There is Putin
column4: ” he told me. “He wants to weaken our German institutions and interfere with our elections. You know why? Because he knows he lives in a piece of shit country – that he has made his country into shit – and so he wants other countries to come down to his level so that his disastrous record can be less easily seen.”

column1: Before he could get any further in his diatribe
column2: a Bild reporter lunged into the office. “Piëch is dead
column3: ” he announced. The family owner of Porsche
column4: Ferdinand Piëch
column5: had apparently died.

column1: “Really? Piëch?” Reichelt said. “How?”
“In a pizzeria
column2: ” said the reporter. “It seems it was a heart attack.”

column1: “That’s fantastic. A pizza restaurant!”
“It seems so.”
“Can we get confirmation?” He suggested giving Gerhard Schröder a call.
“Sure
column2: we’ll get confirmation.”

column1: Piëch had not died in a pizzeria after all
column2: we learned a few moments later
column3: somewhat to Reichelt’s annoyance. But then he quickly picked back up the thread. “Then we have the spineless left at home
column4: that just wants to let Putin and Assad run roughshod over the whole liberal western order. They want to bring the German car industry to a screeching halt
column5: freeze rents in Berlin
column6: starve the economy and keep Germany from doing anything in the world. I remember meeting with some people here in the defence ministry when I got back from covering the war in Syria. Let’s build a no-fly zone in northern Syria
column7: I said. Let’s go do it alone if we have to. But no one in Germany with power knows how to use it – or even wants to use it.”

column1: “What about Bild?” I asked.
“With Bild
column2: ” Reichelt smiled
column3: “it’s the other way around.”

column1: 28;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/jul/16/angela-merkel-set-for-central-role-in-talks-on-eu-recovery-plan";2020-07-16;"Angela Merkel set for central role in talks on EU recovery plan";"Germany has foot in both camps as leaders try to agree on rescue package and seven-year budget
When Angela Merkel attended her first EU summit as Germany’s chancellor
column3: she joined Tony Blair
column4: Jacques Chirac and leaders from central and eastern Europe that had joined the bloc only 17 months earlier. Nearly 15 years later
column5: Merkel is the EU’s longest-serving leader and seen as the key to unlocking a deal to help Europe face the worst economic slump forecast in its history.

column1: A year ago Merkel was seen as tired and drifting
column2: having announced her intention to stand down as chancellor in 2021 after disastrous election results. Now credited for her calm leadership during the coronavirus pandemic
column3: with personal approval ratings close to 80%
column4: she is once again seen as the indispensable broker as EU leaders seek a recovery plan.

column1: “Merkel was strengthened by coronavirus and by not being challenged inside her party
column2: ” said a senior EU diplomat. “I think that she is ready [to get a deal]
column3: she understands every small thing about the proposals.”

column1: When EU leaders sit down together on Friday and Saturday
column2: it will be their first face-to-face meeting since the pandemic struck. On the table is a €750bn (£680bn) draft recovery plan
column3: as well as a proposed €1.074tn EU budget for the next seven years. Getting a deal on the budget will be fiendishly difficult as the EU attempts to square the circle of more spending on the environment
column4: security and health and the €75bn shortfall caused by Brexit.

column1: Daniela Schwarzer
column2: the director of the German Council on Foreign Relations in Berlin
column3: said Merkel would play a crucial role both because she was “so respected for her work” and because Germany was taking a middle position in the recovery plan
column4: giving it a foot in both camps.

column1: She said Germany had “a very strong commitment … to really invest heavily in the recovery of the EU
column2: ” but demands from northern countries to link funds to economic reform were “something that is very close to the German heart as well”.

column1: Optimistic officials are encouraged by the coincidence that Germany took on the EU council’s rotating presidency on 1 July
column2: amid sniping about the performance of the leaders of EU institutions. Charles Michel
column3: the European council president
column4: tasked with brokering a compromise
column5: has been criticised by some for his handling of budget talks. “He is still paralysed by the failure of the European council in February
column6: ” said one senior EU diplomat.

column1: An EU official responded that Michel had fully prepared for that February summit
column2: but the task had not been easy as some EU leader were unprepared to compromise. “Since then we have had a global pandemic landing on our doorstep and the world has changed completely.”

column1: Germany opened the way to a recovery plan with its own political conversion
column2: enshrined in the deal Merkel struck with France’s Emmanuel Macron for a fund based on grants to countries hardest hit by coronavirus. Pierre Sellal
column3: who spent a decade as France’s most senior diplomat in Brussels
column4: said Merkel had crossed two of Germany’s traditional red lines; “The first
column5: no deficits
column6: no common borrowing. And secondly
column7: no transformation of the rules underpinning in the single currency
column8: no budgetary transfers.”

column1: The Germany presidency could crystallise a consensus
column2: he said. “Now we are at a very particular moment
column3: the stakes are very high.”

column1: Germany’s readiness to accept large-scale EU borrowing contrasts with the stance Merkel took during the eurozone debt crisis
column2: when she stood firmly against a transfer union. The German government “realised that its own approach doesn’t allow the necessary convergence and cohesion in the EU
column3: ” said Schwarzer
column4: who highlighted the role of Germany’s Social Democrat finance minister
column5: Olaf Scholz
column6: as architect of the policy shift. Schwarzer said Germany’s change of heart was “not out of some kind of abstract idea of solidarity – but it’s really in Germany’s self-interest to do so.”

column1: Since Brexit and the election of Donald Trump in the US – two hammer blows to the European project – all EU leaders have become more aware of their economic interdependence and the risks of the European single market unravelling. “Thanks to Brexit … suddenly the leaders say we will defend the single market
column2: ” said a second senior EU diplomat
column3: who also cited Trump and tensions in the EU-China relationship. As political frost descends on global trade
column4: what was once seen as Germany’s strength
column5: its export-led economy
column6: suddenly looked more like a vulnerability.

column1: Merkel’s change of heart has weakened the “frugal four”
column2: a quartet of northern European states that want less EU spending and more budget discipline. For months
column3: Germany had been perceived as an unofficial member. Now they stand more isolated.

column1: But EU officials caution that Germany’s policy shift is not enough for agreement
column2: as the frugal four continue to insist on tough conditions for loans that southern European governments reject as unacceptable. “Even having the Franco-German proposal is not always helpful
column3: said one official. “We are playing chess on many different levels.” The Dutch prime minister
column4: Mark Rutte
column5: shop steward of the frugal four
column6: said on Tuesday he was “not hopeful” of a deal.

column1: The other big obstacle comes from the leader second only to Merkel in years running his country: Viktor Orbán. Hungary’s prime minister is resisting plans to tie the disbursement of EU funds to the rule of law
column2: a key demand for western European governments alarmed about the weakening of democratic checks and balances in Hungary. Orbán got a symbolic boost from lawmakers in his Fidesz party this week who passed a resolution declaring that EU funds should not be linked to “political or ideological conditions – under the label of rule of law”.

column1: Solving this political Rubik’s cube is now bound up with the political legacy of the German chancellor
column2: who told MEPs this month: “The top priority in the Germany presidency will be unity in Europe.”

column1: 29;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/commentisfree/2020/jul/13/world-leadership-germany-eu-europe-us";2020-07-13;"The world needs grown-up leadership. Time for Germany to step up";"With Germany at the EU helm
column2: there’s a unique chance for Europe to fill the vacuum left by the retreating US

column1: With Trump’s US missing in action from the global stage
column2: the European Union should be stepping into the vacuum. Germany
column3: which has just taken over the bloc’s rotating presidency
column4: could use the next six months to provide the leadership to boost Europe’s global impact. But is it ready to shake off its traditional reticence?

column1: Immediate economic challenges will dominate EU leaders’ first in-person encounter since the lockdown
column2: on 17 and 18 July. And Berlin is right to prioritise agreement on the EU’s new seven-year budget and a pandemic recovery plan
column3: a task complicated by internal rifts and new forecasts warning of an even deeper recession than expected across the 27-nation bloc. As Angela Merkel said in a recent Guardian interview: “For Europe to survive
column4: its economy needs to survive.”

column1: But Europe’s recovery is conditional on the state of the global economy. And without the US at its side
column2: the EU is struggling to revive faltering multilateral commitments to health
column3: keep up the pressure to meet global climate targets and fight against trade protectionism.

column1: As a bloc it must accept the US retreat and grab the mantle of global leadership because
column2: diminished as it is
column3: multilateralism has never been so needed. Germany is in the right place at the right time to give a powerful boost to this endeavour. Not only is Merkel’s government chairing the EU
column4: it has a two-year stint as a (non-permanent) member of the UN security council until 31 December.

column1: Europe already has the regulatory and market power as well as the multilateral credentials to matter worldwide. EU officials have recently organised two fundraising events for Covid-19 vaccine research and the bloc is trying to bolster both the World Trade Organization and the World Health Organization
column2: key multilateral institutions bruised and battered by US-China rivalries and
column3: in the case of the WHO
column4: by the US decision to formally withdraw from the organisation.

column1: Yet
column2: in its EU presidency programme
column3: Berlin modestly promises to assume “considerable responsibility” to help shape the global order. It has also presented a laudable but impossibly long list of “key priorities”.

column1: This is a recipe for failure. The EU will not
column2: for instance
column3: be able to bring peace to the Middle East
column4: however hard it tries. The US has torpedoed EU attempts to strike a nuclear deal with Iran and internal divisions complicate EU-Russia relations. Merkel will have to be selective in deciding just when
column5: where and how the EU acts
column6: both at home and abroad.

column1: The first step is for Berlin and Brussels to wean themselves off their over-dependence on the US
column2: a fact recognised by Merkel. The quandary isn’t Europe’s alone. As the chancellor underlined
column3: a world that grew up in the “certain knowledge” that the US was a global power now has to adjust to a new reality.

column1: EU discussions on the principle of “strategic autonomy” are a step in the right direction. Initially associated with security and defence
column2: strategic autonomy is now also being sought on trade
column3: foreign investment and a post-pandemic focus on reshoring supply chains linked to essential medical products.

column1: Second
column2: while the EU’s focus is unrelentingly on its volatile relationship with China
column3: its global standing hinges also on upgrading relations with other Asian economic giants
column4: including Japan
column5: India and Indonesia.

column1: Third
column2: Europe must re-imagine its outdated relationship with Africa
column3: learn from past mistakes and finally give up old-fashioned Eurocentric and paternalistic views of Africa as a junior partner needing Europe’s guidance. New EU efforts to build “a partnership of equals” with African states will fall flat unless backed up by investment
column4: support for the African Continental Free Trade Area and stronger ties between European and African local and regional authorities
column5: business leaders
column6: civil society
column7: female groups
column8: young professionals and students.

column1: Fourth
column2: the EU’s reputation
column3: especially as a human rights defender
column4: is tarred by its weak responses on migration and populism. Greece
column5: currently accused of pushing back asylum-seekers at the border with Turkey and preventing refugee boats from reaching EU waters
column6: isn’t the only country suspected of violating migrants’ rights.

column1: Ursula von der Leyen
column2: the EU commission president
column3: has said she wants a “fresh start” via a new migration pact but that has now been put off until autumn as officials seek to win over recalcitrant leaders such as Hungary’s Viktor Orbán. A tendency in Europe to speak of migration and security in the same breath also needs to change
column4: especially in view of evidence of the growing threat posed by far-right extremism
column5: also in Germany.

column1: In the end
column2: the EU needs to showcase its unique leadership qualities for a changed and changing world. Covid-19 has demonstrated the weakness of strongmen and populists. Complex challenges can’t be tackled by reliance on a sole global policeman but require actions by a changing constellation of state and non-state actors working in different formats and at different times. Hard power may still matter to those engaged in real wars but it’s the EU’s quiet diplomacy and strong adherence to the rule of law that count for many others.

column1: In an increasingly cantankerous world Germany can make sure EU governments practise at home what they preach abroad. Above the clamour of great power struggles and zero-sum games
column2: Berlin can steer its EU partners to stop looking in the rear-view mirror and to embrace instead a more interesting
column3: if less predictable
column4: future.

column1: 30;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/jul/12/eu-leaders-are-split-over-coronavirus-recovery";2020-07-12;"EU leaders are split over coronavirus recovery";"This week’s emergency summit will expose national divisions over budgets and the €750bn pandemic fund
Lockdown has proved challenging for most workplaces
column2: and the European Council is no different. All-night sessions
column3: corridor huddles and fine dining in the glass Europa building in Brussels have been replaced with hours staring at a gallery of fellow heads of state reading out prepared lines in front of a backdrop of EU and national flags – and the odd bit of pop art
column4: as in the case of Luxembourg’s prime minister Xavier Bettel.

column1: But this week
column2: leaders will be forced to switch off their laptops and make their way across recently reopened borders to Brussels for their first face-to-face meeting in five months – and it is set to be a bruising encounter.

column1: With the continent heading into a recession not seen since the 1930s
column2: the EU’s institutional heads
column3: the presidents of the European commission and council
column4: Ursula von der Leyen and Charles Michel
column5: have struggled to find consensus between sparring member states over both a long-term budget and a huge one-off economic stimulus. The German chancellor
column6: Angela Merkel
column7: and French president
column8: Emmanuel Macron
column9: have given their backing to a €750bn (£675bn) pandemic recovery fund. But “frugal” northern states have raised issues. Efforts to placate them have angered Hungary’s nationalist prime minister and the European parliament.

column1: “It became obvious deals weren’t going to be made online
column2: ” said one EU official. “You need the work in the margins
column3: bilaterals and discussions between advisers to find the common ground. It needed a physical meeting.”

column1: But the set-up will be far from normal this weekend. The usual back-slapping and cheek-kissing will be replaced by social distancing in the presence of mask-wearing aides. The army of reporters that flock to the summits has also been banned from taking the usual seats in the expansive foyer of the Justus Lipsius building next door to the Europa.

The European commission forecasts an 8.3% drop in economic activity across the EU this year followed by a 5.8% rebound in 2021 but countries are expected to emerge from the crisis at starkly different speeds
column2: risking a breakdown in the bloc’s single market as the disparity between Europe’s haves and have-nots is exacerbated

column1: In Brussels’ latest proposal
column2: Michel
column3: a former Belgian prime minister said to have had a lacklustre first year in his role chairing leaders’ debates
column4: only appeared to stir up new problems.

column1: In response to the unapologetically “frugal” positions taken by Mark Rutte
column2: the Netherlands’ prime minister
column3: Michel tabled a €25bn smaller seven-year budget than last proposed
column4: through which day-to-day programmes including the common agricultural policy are funded.

column1: He also suggested greater accountability for countries seeking cash from the separate recovery pot
column2: which is to be partly financed through issuing joint EU debt. But the move to placate the Dutch ended up annoying Hungary and Europe’s parliament.

column1: One of the big tasks facing Brussels is bridging the demand for financial relief from countries such as Italy and Spain
column2: whose economies are in freefall due to the pandemic
column3: and maintaining the faith of sceptical taxpayers in the richer north. “Are European governments ready for their business to be our business?” asked one EU diplomat from a northern state.

column1: We need a strong budget and if you want to deal with the future challenges you need to invest
Confirming EU officials’ predictions that the leaders faced a “very difficult” meeting
column2: with doleful diplomats fearful that the talks starting on Friday will drag on into Sunday
column3: Michel’s plan to find the right balance drew immediate fire from countries outside the “frugal four” of the Netherlands
column4: Sweden
column5: Denmark and Austria
column6: who have hitherto made Michel’s life difficult by demanding less spending and tighter controls.

column1: Following Michel’s suggestion that the commission be joined by the European court of auditors
column2: the EU’s financial watchdog
column3: in reporting on the governance of member states seeking recovery cash
column4: and making funding conditional on backing from a qualified majority of member states
column5: Hungary’s prime minister Viktor Orbán was first to go on the attack.

column1: Speaking on state-owned Kossuth Rádió
column2: Orbán threatened to scupper both the long-term budget and the recovery fund if “rule of law” strings were attached to funds
column3: telling reporters “there will not be an economic restart
column4: there will not be a budget
column5: there will be drawn-out debates”.

column1: “Let’s put this debate aside now
column2: ” Orbán said. “Let’s resolve the economic problems
column3: restart our economies
column4: start creating jobs
column5: then we can continue the rule of law debates.”

column1: Hungary and Poland could be big winners from the recovery fund but are facing proceedings over concerns that changes to their judicial systems have undermined the independence of their judges and breach EU treaties.
There was also rejection of Michel’s proposals from the European parliament’s negotiators
column2: who disapprove of cuts to the budget known as the multi-annual financial framework.

column1: Both the budget and recovery fund have to be approved by MEPs. A cross-party group has been tasked with finding a package that can command a majority in the chamber. The European parliament has strongly advocated a significantly larger budget for the bloc than Michel’s proposal of €1.074tn over seven years.
Rasmus Andresen
column2: a Green MEP who is the only German budget negotiator for the parliament
column3: told the Observer that Michel’s proposal would be swiftly voted down if it came to the chamber. He said: “We need a strong budget and if you want to deal with the future challenges you need to invest and it is not enough to have a recovery fund for three or four years.

column1: There is a lot of criticism in the parliament and it will be much louder when colleagues are analysing what it means.”
If this week’s meeting fails to find common ground
column2: a second has been pencilled in for the last week of July
column3: with Merkel insisting the EU must resolve the problem by the summer.

column1: Rutte – whose country would benefit from Michel’s proposed retention of its budget rebate and €5bn reserve set aside should the UK end its relationship with the EU without a new deal – said he would “handle” any criticism at this week’s summit.
“I’m not made of marzipan
column2: ” he said. “It is starting to go our way.”

column1: 31;"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2020/jun/28/why-the-uk-is-the-sick-man-of-europe-again";2020-06-28;"Why the UK is the sick man of Europe again";"British neoliberalism
column2: social inequality and arrogance have left us trailing in Germany’s wake in the fight against coronavirus
column3: argue John Green and Glyn Turton
column4: while Jinty Nelson says the UK has been losing ground in other areas for years

column1: Martin Kettle is absolutely right in his comparison between Germany’s response to the Covid-19 pandemic and that of the UK (On different planets: how Germany tackled the pandemic
column2: and Britain flailed
column3: 24 June). But one big factor is the fact that Germany is not
column4: as he writes
column5: just “a bit more prosperous” than Britain. Its standard of living is much higher than ours and there is certainly less of a divide between the rich and poor than there is here. The much higher standards of hygiene in Germany and of health care have also been an important contributing factor to the country’s much lower Covid-19 infection and death rates.

column1: Our government of Little Englanders and fanatical privateers will never admit that we could learn something from another nation
column2: let alone from Germany. Angela Merkel has pursued a politics of consensus and moderation
column3: whereas our Conservatives have consistently followed the discredited neoliberalism of the US and the chaotic response to this pandemic is a direct result.John GreenLondon

column1: • Martin Kettle’s excellent analysis of why the UK’s handling of the Covid-19 outbreak is so much worse than Germany’s segues into a critique of the general condition of delusional arrogance that infects this country’s ruling class. It calls to mind Tolstoy’s comparison in War and Peace of the reasons why each of the major European nations is self-assured.
The English come off best: “An Englishman is self-assured
column2: as being a citizen of the best organised state in the world
column3: and therefore always knows what he should do and knows that all he does as an Englishman is undoubtedly correct.” We are now the sick man of Europe because the first part of this statement has long since ceased to be true
column4: while the second
column5: alas
column6: hasn’t.Emeritus Professor Glyn TurtonBaildon
column7: West Yorkshire

column1: • Twenty years ago
column2: the British Academy set up a working party to inquire into the quality of the teaching of modern languages in Britain
column3: compared with other European countries. The main finding was (to borrow Martin Kettle’s phrase) that British quality was trailing not world-beating. Our working party looked at technology teaching in British schools and compared it with the state of technical high schools in Germany. Trailing
column4: or being beaten? Plus ça change?Jinty NelsonLondon

column1: 32;"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2020/jun/28/the-guardian-view-on-germany-taking-the-eu-presidency-good-timing";2020-06-28;"The Guardian view on Germany taking the EU presidency: good timing";"Europe’s largest and most powerful nation can provide necessary leadership amid daunting challenges
As Europe emerges from the worst of the coronavirus pandemic
column2: it faces challenges on an epic scale.

column1: In Italy and Spain
column2: the spectre of spiralling
column3: unsustainable debt jeopardises recovery in economies that were already fragile. In Brussels
column4: there is concern that amid the post-pandemic fallout
column5: the generational task of addressing the climate emergency and implementing tough green targets will be put to one side. Europe’s place in a newly multi-polar world
column6: dominated by the increasingly tense rivalry between the United States and China
column7: must be worked out anew. Post-epidemic
column8: there is a new emphasis on economic self-sufficiency
column9: particularly in medical manufacturing and key industries. The European Union’s future trading relationship with Britain needs to be agreed in a matter of months.

column1: In a context this formidable
column2: it is the EU’s good fortune that Germany
column3: the largest and most powerful member state
column4: will take over its rotating presidency this week. For obvious reasons of history
column5: Germany has traditionally been reluctant to punch its weight on the European stage. But extraordinary times demand clear leadership. The German chancellor
column6: Angela Merkel
column7: appears determined to provide it. Outlining her plans for the presidency recently
column8: Ms Merkel told German MPs that: “Europe needs us
column9: just as we need Europe.” Brexit trade talks are likely to be treated as one dimension of a bigger problem: shoring up the single market during a period of economic turmoil.

column1: In an interview with the Guardian and other European newspapers this weekend
column2: Ms Merkel made it clear that her most urgent priority will be to reach swift agreement on a €750bn post-coronavirus recovery fund
column3: to be financed by EU-issued debt and distributed to countries in the form of grants rather than loans.

column1: Signing off on this innovation
column2: first proposed by Ms Merkel and the French president
column3: Emmanuel Macron
column4: in May
column5: would be a landmark moment. The prospect of pooling debt with impecunious southern neighbours has traditionally been anathema to the EU’s more prosperous member states
column6: with the resistance usually led by Germany. A so-called Frugal Four – Austria
column7: Denmark
column8: Sweden and the Netherlands – will mount a fierce rearguard action to water the plan down. But the searing experience of the last three months appears to have changed perceptions in Berlin of what is possible and desirable.

column1: Domestically
column2: a sacrosanct commitment to balanced budgets has been put to one side to allow a gigantic stimulus package and state bailouts. At a European level
column3: Ms Merkel believes a step-change in solidarity is required. She has rightly warned that a failure to take collective action to stabilise Europe’s reeling economies will play into the hands of anti-democratic and authoritarian forces.

column1: The tone and approach are strikingly different from a decade ago
column2: when Ms Merkel and her then finance minister
column3: Wolfgang Schäuble
column4: helped enforce EU-wide austerity measures in the wake of the financial crash. But during her 15-year stint as chancellor
column5: Ms Merkel has demonstrated a peerless ability to adapt to changing circumstances. Before Covid-19 struck
column6: she was viewed as a lame-duck leader
column7: having announced her intention to stand down in 2021. Instead
column8: Germany’s assured handling of the epidemic has enhanced her authority and provided the political capital to take necessary risks in what has become a crisis presidency. Germany has sometimes been criticised for “leading from behind”. For the next six months
column9: Ms Merkel will be leading from the front. For the EU
column10: at a time when the stakes have never been higher
column11: that is good news.

column1: 33;"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2020/jun/27/greta-thunberg-hits-out-at-leaders-who-use-her-fame-to-look-good";2020-06-27;"Greta Thunberg hits out at leaders who use her fame to 'look good'";"Climate change campaigner said after UN summit
column2: Angela Merkel queued up for a selfie

column1: Environmental campaigner Greta Thunberg has hit out at world leaders for wanting to be pictured with her to “look good”.
The 17-year-old became a global star thanks to her activism
column2: and gave a powerful speech at the United Nations climate change summit in September in which she told world leaders: “You have stolen my dreams and my childhood with your empty words … how dare you!”

column1: As part of a series she has made about her campaigning for Swedish radio during the coronavirus lockdown
column2: Thunberg revealed that the German chancellor
column3: Angela Merkel
column4: had queued up to have a “selfie” with the teenager at the international gathering in New York.

column1: On the radio programme
column2: she was critical of the way high-ranking figures had behaved after her UN appearance.

column1: She said: “Presidents
column2: prime ministers
column3: kings and princesses came and wanted to talk to me.

column1: “They saw me and suddenly saw the chance that they could take a photo with me for their Instagram account. Then the hashtag #savetheplanet.
“It seemed as if they had forgotten for a moment to be ashamed that their generation had let future generations down.”
In follow-up comments made to the BBC
column2: Thunberg
column3: who has more than 4m Twitter followers
column4: said she had a “dislike” for politicians who wanted to capitalise on her fame by being photographed alongside her.

column1: “To be fair
column2: it was not only her
column3: it was many
column4: ” she said
column5: when asked about the situation with Merkel.

column1: “And those kinds of things happen all the time. People just want to stand next to me and other climate activists.
“They can post it on social media and it makes them look good
column2: it makes them seem like they care.”

column1: In January
column2: Thunberg was pictured with Prince Charles
column3: the Prince of Wales
column4: after he gave a speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos
column5: Switzerland.

column1: Thunberg did not refer to Charles
column2: a longstanding environmentalist
column3: when making her comments
column4: however.

column1: When asked if global leaders vying for picture opportunities made her feel “used”
column2: the founder of the school strike for climate movement said: “Yes
column3: people definitely see me sometimes as someone to stand next to
column4: to look good
column5: and that is something I really dislike because that’s not the sort of person I want to be.”

column1: During the 25-minute interview
column2: Thunberg said she hoped that the changes made by governments and people across the globe in the face of the Covid-19 pandemic would help to change the perception around the action required to tackle global warming.

column1: The advocate has previously slammed the UK’s declining carbon emissions figures as “creative accounting” and has pushed for firmer action to be taken.
“If anything it [coronavirus] will change the way we perceive and treat crises because it shows that during a crisis you act with necessary force
column2: ” she told the BBC.

column1: “And it has also opened up the discussion around how much we value human life.
“For example
column2: people say they are ready to sacrifice the economy. They are saying we will do what it takes because we cannot put a price on a human life.

column1: “If you introduce that logic for the climate
column2: for instance
column3: then that opens up many possibilities and it changes the discussion of the debate.”

column1: • This article was amended on 30 June 2020 to correct the name of the climate movement: it is “school strike” not “schools strike”.
… we’re all in. Are you? On November 4
column2: a day after the presidential election
column3: the US will formally withdraw from the Paris agreement on constraining global heating. It’s urgent that we tell the world what this means
column4: and the Guardian is pulling out all the stops to do so. Will you help us by supporting our journalism?
