column1: 34;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/jun/26/for-europe-survive-economy-needs-survive-angela-merkel-interview-in-full";2020-06-26;"'For Europe to survive
column2: its economy needs to survive': Angela Merkel interview in full";"The transcript of the German chancellor discussing Covid-19
column3: Brexit and global challenges

column1: As the rotating presidency of the EU council passes to Germany on 1 July
column2: the country’s chancellor
column3: Angela Merkel
column4: sat down for an interview with the Guardian and five other European newspapers – Germany’s Süddeutsche Zeitung
column5: France’s Le Monde
column6: Spain’s La Vanguardia
column7: Italy’s La Stampa and Poland’s Polityka – to talk about Europe’s economic response to the coronavirus pandemic
column8: her stance on the Brexit negotiations
column9: and global challenges posed by the US
column10: Russia and China.

column1: Germany’s European council presidency is taking place during an unprecedented crisis. There is a lot of pressure; Germany is expected to sort things out. How nervous are you?
My first council presidency as chancellor was in 2007. The European constitutional treaty had just been rejected in France and the Netherlands
column2: and we had set ourselves the task of shaping a new treaty. We succeeded in that. Then came the international financial crisis
column3: turbulence for the euro and the refugee issue – so difficult times are nothing new. And time and again it has been shown that Europe is not yet sufficiently resistant to crises. In the euro crisis
column4: we lacked the tools for an appropriate response. The movements of refugees in 2015 showed up the deficiencies of the EU asylum system.

column1: Now the coronavirus pandemic is confronting us with a challenge of unprecedented dimensions. It has struck us all indiscriminately. On the one hand
column2: it has torn us away from a period of positive economic development in all EU member states. On the other hand
column3: it has coincided with the two great disruptive phenomena of our time
column4: climate change and the digital revolution
column5: which are changing our lives and our economies regardless of the virus. I am very sharply focused on all of this.

column1: Given the sheer number of crises
column2: is the EU’s survival on the line?

column1: Rather than ask the existential question too often
column2: we should get on with the day job. It is very much in all the member states’ own interests to maintain a strong European internal market and to stand united on the world stage. In such an extraordinary situation
column3: I rely on the member states having a great interest in the things that unite us.

column1: The crisis has not just struck Europe; the whole world is fighting the pandemic as well as political demons.
Exactly
column2: and it is true that the tone of international discourse is brusque at the moment. After the 2008 financial crisis
column3: multilateralism was the order of the day. That was when the G20 started meeting at the level of heads of state or government
column4: and the countries gave a very unified response. That is not the case today. These days
column5: we have to do all we can to stop ourselves collapsing into protectionism. If Europe wants to be heard
column6: then it needs to set a good example. I am counting on it – though I am under no illusions about how difficult the negotiations will be.

column1: Your proposal for a recovery fund was a major concession to the southern countries. What reform efforts are you expecting in return?
I don’t find it helpful to talk about the northern countries
column2: the southern countries and the eastern Europeans. That is seeing things in black and white. I expect each of us always to put ourselves in the other person’s shoes and consider problems from the other’s point of view.

column1: The group known as the ‘frugal four’ is pursuing a defensive approach. Why has Germany left the cautious camp?
For Italy and Spain
column2: for example
column3: the coronavirus pandemic signifies a huge burden in economic
column4: medical and
column5: of course
column6: because of the many lives lost
column7: emotional terms. In these circumstances
column8: it is only right for Germany to think not just about itself but to be prepared to engage in an extraordinary act of solidarity. It was in that spirit that French President Emmanuel Macron and I made our proposal.

column1: Going into higher levels of debt is a U-turn for Germany. What happened to the chancellor with the tight purse strings?
In a crisis of this magnitude
column2: each and every one of us is expected to do what needs to be done. What needs to be done in this case is something extraordinary. Germany had a low debt ratio and can afford
column3: in this extraordinary situation
column4: to take on some more debt. It is also very important to us to keep the programme within the bounds of the European treaties. We have found a way to do that.

column1: And all this is in our own interests too
column2: of course. It is in Germany’s interest to have a strong internal market and to have the European Union grow closer together
column3: not fall apart. As ever
column4: what’s good for Europe is good for us.

column1: The recovery fund has generated an odd kind of harmony. Is the money drawing a veil over the real problems of burgeoning nationalism and latent populism?

The recovery fund cannot solve all of Europe’s problems. But not having it would make all our problems worse. Europe’s economic health can influence so many things. Very high unemployment in a country can become politically explosive and thereby increase the threat to democracy. For Europe to survive
column2: its economy needs to survive.

column1: Might the recovery fund spark movement towards a United States of Europe?
I see this fund as a unique response to a unique situation. If we wanted to change fundamental aspects of the way the EU budget is managed or
column2: for instance
column3: give it the right to raise taxes
column4: then we would have to amend the treaties. That would alter the static equilibrium between competence and oversight. I am sure this will be discussed in the years ahead
column5: but that should be done cautiously. In the current situation
column6: however
column7: we could not wait for the treaties to be amended. We have to respond quickly to the pandemic.

column1: Do you think Nadia Calviño [Spain’s economic affairs minister] would make a good Eurogroup president?

The finance ministers are discussing that at the moment. It is no secret that there is support for Nadia Calviño’s candidature in the German government. But the final decision lies with the Eurogroup. I am always pleased when women get leading political roles
column2: and the Eurogroup has never been headed by a woman. But it’s not my decision. This is for the Eurogroup to decide.

column1: Should Italy use what the European stability mechanism has to offer?

That is Italy’s decision to make. We have created these instruments through the EIB [the European Investment Bank]: the ESM with its precautionary credit lines and the Sure short-time work scheme. Anyone can make use of them. We didn’t make them available for them to remain unused.

You are the last head of government left of the 1989 generation. You experienced the eastern bloc and European unification. Is it not the case that Europe is drifting apart in spite of the pandemic-related efforts? Can the younger heads of government still find a common language?
Hungary’s prime minister
column2: Viktor Orbán
column3: was already politically active in 1989 too. Back then
column4: the liberal democratic order had initially triumphed over the dictatorship of socialism and communism. But that was only part of the reality. Conflicts broke out in the western Balkans and later in the Islamic world. China rose to become a major economic power. Indeed
column5: the example of China shows that even an undemocratic state can be economically successful
column6: which is a major challenge for our liberal democracies. Then came the challenge of Islamist terrorism
column7: particularly the attack on the United States of 11 September 2001. Add to this the disappointment that followed the Arab spring. In short
column8: we have not yet been able to furnish absolute proof that the liberal system is about to win the day. That worries me.

column1: Has Europe not reaped the benefits of its revolution?
Yes and no. On the one hand
column2: we have enjoyed an incredible success story since 1989
column3: but in our euphoria we failed to fully realise what long-term traces dictatorships had left in the 40 years since the second world war. After national socialism and the second world war
column4: many countries in eastern Europe went straight into a second period of dictatorship. The countries of the eastern bloc had only a few years to develop their own national identities. So only later did they undergo processes that had long been part of normal life in western countries.

column1: Many young EU accession countries share our enthusiasm for the European Union as a work of peace on the one hand
column2: yet display scepticism towards Europe on the other. We need to develop understanding for that. I see my job as working for a self-determined
column3: liberal Europe rooted in the fundamental rights of the individual.

column1: With all due respect to differences of historical experience
column2: where do you draw the line on violating the rule of law?

column1: We will
column2: of course
column3: talk about issues relating to the rule of law. The hallmark of democracy is that any opposition must have a fair chance of returning to government. An opposition must be guaranteed a clear set of rights – starting with appropriate speaking time in parliaments and at least the same amount of airtime from public broadcasters
column4: and extending to an independent judiciary and adherence to democratic rules.

column1: Is European legislation now in breach of national legislation – or vice versa? Doesn’t the European legal system ultimately need to have more weight than national ones as a matter of principle?
It’s not as if this topic was never talked about before the federal constitutional court issued its judgment on the European Central Bank. Without a doubt
column2: European law has precedence over national law – but that does not tell us where the realm of European law begins and ends. The essence of the European Union lies in the member states transferring powers. In the borderland between the spheres of jurisdiction of national and European law
column3: friction can occur if the European level defines its limits more broadly than
column4: for example
column5: the German parliament does. That’s what we are seeing in the ECB case.

column1: If the constitutional court finds that a boundary has been crossed
column2: it goes to the European court of justice and requests a review. Up until now
column3: all disagreements have been settled. Now we have a conflict. That is the nature of the beast
column4: since a nation state will always be able to lay claim to particular powers unless all powers are transferred to the European institutions
column5: which is surely not going to happen.

column1: The presidency wanted to find a joint strategy for dealing with China. Is that still realistic?
Because of the pandemic
column2: we cannot hold the summit with China in September as planned. But we intend to hold it later. Its objective is to advance EU-Chinese relations. We share common interests
column3: such as cooperating on climate action. We have been negotiating an investment agreement for some time but are not really moving forward on that. We should discuss our development policies in Africa
column4: where China is following a different path in some areas.

column1: At the same time
column2: the summit is forcing us to develop a joint European position vis-à-vis China. That is no easy task. We should develop a policy that reflects our interests and values. After all
column3: respect for human rights
column4: the rule of law and our concerns about the future of Hong Kong stand between China and ourselves and are addressed openly.

column1: Is China calling the western
column2: democratic edifice of Europe into question?

column1: We should start by doing everything we can to make ourselves more resilient. We need to stand together as Europeans
column2: otherwise we will only weaken ourselves. China has become a global player. That makes us partners in economic cooperation and combating climate change
column3: but also competitors with very different political systems. Not to talk to each other would certainly be a bad idea.

column1: A no-deal Brexit is looming at the end of the year. Would that be a personal defeat for you?
No. It would
column2: of course
column3: be in Britain’s and all EU member states’ interests to achieve an orderly departure. But that can only happen if it is what both sides want. What matters is not our wishes but only the reality before us
column4: in other words first of all what Britain wants. With Prime Minister Boris Johnson
column5: the British government wants to define for itself what relationship it will have with us after the country leaves. It will then have to live with the consequences
column6: of course

column1: 40;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/jun/04/angela-merkel-has-become-the-spend-spend-spend-chancellor";2020-06-04;"Angela Merkel has become the spend
column2: spend
column3: spend chancellor";"With its €130bn stimulus package
column4: Germany is showing others how to do the recovery

column1: And in one bound she was transformed. For Angela Merkel
column2: the days of being lampooned as the archetypal Swabian housewife keeping tight control over the purse strings are over. Now
column3: courtesy of a €130bn (£116bn) stimulus package
column4: she is the spend
column5: spend
column6: spend chancellor.

column1: Make no mistake
column2: much of the past criticism of Germany’s frugal approach to government spending and budget deficits was justified. Saving some money for a rainy day is one thing but running surpluses worth 8% of national output was unnecessary and harmful to the global economy.

column1: Nobody can accuse Europe’s biggest economy of stinting on this occasion. The package was bigger than expected and
column2: at about 4% of GDP
column3: doubles the size of Germany’s tax and spending stimulus since the start of the crisis.

column1: In recent days the UK has seen a sudden sharp increase in Covid-19 infection numbers
column2: leading to fears that a second wave of cases is beginning.

column1: Epidemics of infectious diseases behave in different ways but the 1918 influenza pandemic that killed more than 50 million people is regarded as a key example of a pandemic that occurred in multiple waves
column2: with the latter more severe than the first. It has been replicated – albeit more mildly – in subsequent flu pandemics. Until now that had been what was expected from Covid-19.

column1: How and why multiple-wave outbreaks occur
column2: and how subsequent waves of infection can be prevented
column3: has become a staple of epidemiological modelling studies and pandemic preparation
column4: which have looked at everything from social behaviour and health policy to vaccination and the buildup of community immunity
column5: also known as herd immunity.

column1: This is being watched very carefully. Without a vaccine
column2: and with no widespread immunity to the new disease
column3: one alarm is being sounded by the experience of Singapore
column4: which has seen a sudden resurgence in infections despite being lauded for its early handling of the outbreak.

column1: Although Singapore instituted a strong contact tracing system for its general population
column2: the disease re-emerged in cramped dormitory accommodation used by thousands of foreign workers with inadequate hygiene facilities and shared canteens.

column1: Singapore’s experience
column2: although very specific
column3: has demonstrated the ability of the disease to come back strongly in places where people are in close proximity and its ability to exploit any weakness in public health regimes set up to counter it.

column1: In June 2020
column2: Beijing suffered from a new cluster of coronavirus cases which caused authorities to re-implement restrictions that China had previously been able to lift. In the UK
column3: the city of Leicester was unable to come out of lockdown because of the development of a new spike of coronavirus cases. Clusters also emerged in Melbourne
column4: requiring a re-imposition of lockdown conditions.

column1: Conventional wisdom among scientists suggests second waves of resistant infections occur after the capacity for treatment and isolation becomes exhausted. In this case the concern is that the social and political consensus supporting lockdowns is being overtaken by public frustration and the urgent need to reopen economies.
However Linda Bauld
column2: professor of public health at the University of Edinburgh
column3: says “‘Second wave’ isn’t a term that we would use at the current time
column4: as the virus hasn’t gone away
column5: it’s in our population
column6: it has spread to 188 countries so far
column7: and what we are seeing now is essentially localised spikes or a localised return of a large number of cases.”

column1: The overall threat declines when susceptibility of the population to the disease falls below a certain threshold or when widespread vaccination becomes available.

In general terms the ratio of susceptible and immune individuals in a population at the end of one wave determines the potential magnitude of a subsequent wave. The worry is that with a vaccine still many months away
column2: and the real rate of infection only being guessed at
column3: populations worldwide remain highly vulnerable to both resurgence and subsequent waves.

column1: Peter Beaumont
column2: Emma Graham-Harrison and Martin Belam

column1: Germany showed the rest of Europe what was needed to limit the spread of the virus: a decentralised testing programme; a manufacturing sector capable of producing medical equipment quickly; and a political system that prizes results over grandstanding. Now it is showing other countries how to do the recovery.
It is not just a question of money
column2: important though that is. The package is a well-crafted mixture of a short-term spending boost
column3: targeted support for those parts of the economy that need it and measures that will help lay the foundations for long-term sustainable growth.

column1: There is a time limited cut in VAT lasting from July until the end of the year
column2: which should persuade German consumers to spend some of the euros they have accumulated during lockdown. There is recognition of the pressure on families
column3: with a payment of €300 per child
column4: extra incentives to buy electric cars
column5: and grants worth €25bn for small businesses in those sectors
column6: such as hospitality
column7: that will take longest to recover from lockdown restrictions.

column1: All that will ensure Germany will be one of the first countries to get output back to its pre-crisis levels. Yet
column2: the package also included €50bn for investment programmes
column3: with a focus on making the transition to a greener economy.

column1: All this is a bit of a contrast to the UK experience. So far
column2: Rishi Sunak has administered large amounts of expensive sticking plaster to the economy but not much more. As he contemplates options for a summer mini-budget
column3: the chancellor could do worse than to study what the Germans have come up with. A lot worse
column4: in fact.

column1: After a little bit of pressure
column2: the Bank of England has revealed the names of the big companies that have been taking advantage of its coronavirus corporate lending scheme and how much they are in for. An interesting list it is
column3: too.

column1: For those a little confused by the blizzard of government schemes designed to keep business going through the pandemic crisis
column2: the Covid corporate financing facility (CCFF) allows a company to sell its short-term bonds to Threadneedle Street in exchange for cash.

column1: Few would quibble with the basic principle behind the CCFF. The government stopped planes from flying
column2: football clubs from playing and shops from opening so it was obliged to give the likes of British Airways
column3: Tottenham Hotspur FC and John Lewis a helping hand. The alternative was to turn Britain into a tumbleweed economy.

column1: So far
column2: the Bank has lent £16bn to more than 50 businesses. To qualify
column3: a company need not be UK-owned. It merely has to have sizeable revenues in this country and be a sizeable employer. That explains why the German chemicals company BASF came to be the biggest borrower from the Bank under the scheme
column4: with £1bn outstanding
column5: and that Nissan has borrowed £600m.

column1: Clearly
column2: it would be foolish to deny a company help because it is foreign-owned
column3: since all the evidence is that German
column4: French
column5: Japanese and US run companies are more productive than indigenous businesses.

column1: A much more serious criticism is that the money has been provided with no strings attached. BA has announced 12
column2: 000 job losses despite securing £300m from the scheme. EasyJet tapped the CCFF for £600m but said it will axe 4
column3: 500 jobs – 30% of its workforce. The government appears not to have received or even asked for any job guarantees from companies
column4: nor to demand that a quid pro quo for state support should be a reduction in the airlines’ carbon footprint.

column1: All crises represent an opportunity as well as a threat. The opportunity here was for the government to use its financial leverage to change corporate behaviour for the better. That opportunity has been blown."

41;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/jun/04/germany-unveils-huge-130bn-coronavirus-recovery-package";2020-06-04;"Germany unveils €130bn coronavirus recovery package";"Tax and spending measures are designed to provide country with big economic boost
Germany has unveiled a €130bn (£116.4bn) package of tax and spending measures designed to boost the country’s economic recovery from the coronavirus crisis.
Announcing measures to drag Europe’s largest economy out of recession as lockdown measures are removed
column2: Angela Merkel’s government said it would use the package of sweeping temporary tax cuts and increase benefits to turbocharge its recovery.

column1: Measures included a cut in VAT until the end of this year and substantial payments for every child in the country designed to help ordinary German families
column2: alongside the launch of a €50bn fund to tackle global heating and finance new technologies. A state financial incentive to buy an electric car has been doubled to €6

column1: Against a backdrop of rising unemployment and with Germany already in a technical recession before Covid-19 struck
column2: Merkel said a “bold response” was required to secure jobs and keep the economy running. Measures announced include:

column1: A temporary VAT cut from 19% to 16%
column2: from 1 July until 31 December

column1: A €300 one-off payment for every child in the country
A €50bn fund to address climate change
column2: innovation and digital technology›

column1: A €25bn loan support programme for small firms that have seen their sales drop by more than 60% for June to August. This could be a particular boost for bars
column2: restaurants
column3: hotels and other hospitality businesses.

column1: €10bn for municipalities struggling with lower tax receipts
column2: with public spending on infrastructure and housing.

column1: Up until now
column2: countries around the world had largely announced emergency financial support to cushion the economic blow from the coronavirus outbreak rather than jump-start a recovery. Germany’s package of measures comes on top of a €750bn rescue package agreed in March. It included loan guarantees and direct spending measures such as furlough wage subsidies.

column1: Germany had typically taken a conservative approach to tax and spending policy in recent years
column2: despite repeated calls to loosen the purse strings to boost the economy as growth faltered.

column1: Merkel’s government came under pressure earlier this year to spend after overseeing a record €13.5bn budget surplus last year while the country’s economy slowed.
Berlin’s latest plans
column2: however
column3: come as more countries lift lockdown controls and attempt to reboot their economies as the world slides into its deepest recession since the Great Depression of the 1930s.

column1: The British chancellor
column2: Rishi Sunak
column3: is understood to be drawing up plans for a summer financial statement to revitalise the UK economy
column4: which is likely to focus on infrastructure spending and job creation schemes.

column1: Three former British chancellors told Sunak on Wednesday to prepare for 1980s levels of unemployment across the country as the coronavirus crash causes widespread job losses.
Alistair Darling
column2: Labour’s chancellor during the 2008 financial crisis
column3: said Sunak should also consider temporary VAT cuts similar to those used more than a decade ago during the financial crisis.

column1: The former chancellors also suggested more funding for green growth
column2: job support and retraining for the newly unemployed would also be vital for Britain’s recovery.

column1: 42;"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2020/jun/03/pandemic-no-deal-brexit-vote-leavers-coronavirus";2020-06-03;"The pandemic is being used as cover for a no-deal Brexit";"The Vote Leavers at the heart of government think the coronavirus crash will disguise the pain caused by a rupture with the EU
Most of us who have followed Brexit closely believed coronavirus would soften the government’s stance in trade talks with Europe. The economic shock triggered by the pandemic
column2: and the fact Whitehall is so overwhelmed managing it
column3: made it more likely the government would extend the transition period
column4: due to expire at the end of this year
column5: or strike a deal. It turns out that the opposite is true. Rather than encouraging a more flexible and pragmatic approach
column6: Covid-19 has instead reinforced the case for no deal at the very top of government.

column1: Perhaps the most important driver is the belief among ministers that the UK economy will be permanently reshaped by the crisis
column2: as companies create new supply chains and reshore production to provide greater resilience in the future
column3: not least in case of another pandemic. The government wants a free hand to facilitate this change
column4: one that it believes would be constrained by the EU’s demand that the UK remain tied to its labour and environmental standards and state aid rules.

column1: On the other side of the same coin
column2: there are growing fears in cabinet that maintaining close EU ties would lock the UK into the EU’s post-Covid-19 economic measures designed for its 27 member states
column3: with little regard for the UK’s interests. This is nonsense
column4: as the EU’s rescue package unveiled last Wednesday assumes no UK financial contribution. But it is a powerful argument on the Eurosceptic backbenches and has scared many in cabinet.

column1: Another argument popular with backbench Brexiteers
column2: but now more prominent among ministers
column3: is the belief that coronavirus presents the government with an opportunity to “bury” the loss of growth from no trade deal under the cover of the much more dramatic drop in GDP caused by coronavirus.

column1: The politics of this are very juicy for the Vote Leave team in the driving seat in government. Not least because it is only really a no deal that fully delivers on their substantive “divergence” agenda
column2: while any version of a deal with the EU
column3: no matter how distant
column4: will ultimately tie the UK into EU rules and regulations in some way
column5: an idea they hate and are loth to accept. No deal also facilitates a trade deal with the US
column6: and the symbolism of “Global Britain” is key for ministers – far more important than the limited economic benefit a UK-US trade pact would bring.

column1: Time is also running out. Despite three rounds of talks so far
column2: no progress has been made and negotiators on both sides are downbeat about the likelihood of a breakthrough this week. Big gaps remain – in the UK over whether and how far to align to EU standards
column3: the role of the European court of justice and the EU’s demands to fish in UK waters. But the government won’t extend the transition period. Boris Johnson believes he would struggle to sell to voters the extra £10bn in financial contributions and further spell of EU control of UK laws that this would bring.

column1: A political intervention on both sides will therefore be needed to move beyond the current stage. There will l be an opportunity this month
column2: when Johnson meets the European commission president
column3: Ursula von der Leyen
column4: virtually
column5: around the time of a long-planned EU leaders’ session in June to review progress. But the EU is unlikely to change its mandate and absent progress
column6: ministers plan to make a judgment in September so they can give business clarity about the trading arrangements from 1 January. They may switch to assuming and preparing for no deal then.

column1: Finally
column2: the survival of Dominic Cummings
column3: Johnson’s closest adviser
column4: despite allegations he broke the lockdown rules
column5: also enhances the prospect of no deal. One reason why Brexiteer ministers and aides rallied behind him is that he sees it as his personal mission to prevent Johnson extending the transition period in June
column6: and delivering a version of Brexit that lets the UK “take back control”. It would be wrong to underestimate his impact on the outcome of these negotiations.

column1: Of course
column2: this could all be tactics and bluster. Johnson and his cheerleaders on the backbenches have convinced themselves that such brinkmanship worked during the withdrawal agreement talks
column3: so it is no real surprise they intend to repeat the trick now. Especially as they believe
column4: wrongly
column5: that coronavirus will make the EU more desperate to conclude a deal and buckle at the last moment. But Downing Street is right that December is the real deadline.

column1: Germany’s role will be key. I say this not as a naive Brit
column2: believing that Angela Merkel will ride to Britain’s rescue
column3: but as someone who has spent more than two decades studying and working on EU affairs. With Germany at the head of Europe’s rotating presidency
column4: and Merkel in the final throes of her chancellorship
column5: she will find it very hard to sign off on no deal. Of all of the EU’s member states
column6: Germany has been the most focused on the longer-term
column7: geopolitical risk of no deal
column8: and the necessity for the UK and EU to maintain constructive ties.

column1: But even Merkel can’t and won’t save the UK from itself
column2: and will not agree to a deal at any price. If the net effect of Covid-19 is that ministers see more benefit than cost from no deal
column3: with the dominant view in cabinet now opposed to extending the transitional period
column4: then that will indeed be the outcome at the end of this year.

column1: • Mujtaba Rahman is the managing director for Europe at Eurasia Group
column2: a political risk research and consulting firm"

column3: however

column2: to be distributed to the worst-hit EU countries
column3: could be a breakthrough moment

column2: following the American war of independence
column3: Alexander Hamilton proposed that federal government should take on the huge debts incurred during the struggle by individual states. It had long been Hamilton’s view that this move would be a key moment in the forging of a true United States of America. “A national debt
column4: ” he had written
column5: “if it is not excessive
column6: will be to us a national blessing. It will be a powerful cement of our union.”

column1: Until now
column2: this kind of thinking has never gained a foothold in the European Union. Despite periodic calls for deeper fiscal union
column3: richer EU states have balked at the notion of pooling debt with weaker neighbours. After the crash of 2008
column4: when Greece hovered on the edge of bankruptcy and a sovereign debt crisis threatened to engulf Italy
column5: the EU went no further than the provision of emergency loans and cheap credit. The bailout money came with painful strings attached
column6: as countries were obliged to launch deeply resented austerity programmes in order to manage their growing debt mountain. The alternative – writing off debts in Hamiltonian fashion – was dismissed out of hand by Germany’s finance minister at the time
column7: Wolfgang Schäuble.

column1: That was then. On Wednesday
column2: Angela Merkel and Emmanuel Macron are expected to present plans for a €500bn (£448bn) EU recovery fund
column3: which would distribute non-refundable grants to the countries that have suffered most during the coronavirus pandemic. Crucially
column4: the money would be borrowed by the European commission on behalf of all member states
column5: and sit within the EU budget to be agreed for 2021-27. Germany would be liable for about €135bn (£120bn). This could be a watershed moment. Since the adoption of the euro
column6: there has been fierce argument over whether a common currency should entail at least some degree of common debt. The countries of the prosperous north
column7: led by Germany
column8: have resisted such talk. Governments have been wary of seeing their borrowing costs rise and conscious that such a move would be domestically unpopular. But Covid-19 is challenging old taboos.

column1: Deprived of tourism revenue and facing the sharpest economic downturn in modern times
column2: southern Europe fears a regional meltdown. Loan packages already agreed via the European Stability Mechanism
column3: while welcome
column4: will contribute to unprecedented levels of sovereign debt. In these dire circumstances
column5: both Mr Macron and Ms Merkel have recognised that unless the burden of reconstruction is seen to be genuinely shared
column6: there will be existential implications for the future of the EU.

column1: Last week
column2: Ms Merkel said the devastation wrought by the pandemic was of a magnitude such that it could “endanger the European Union’s cohesion”. Mr Macron has suggested the “European idea” itself will be in danger
column3: unless there is a step-change in solidarity between the stronger and weaker eurozone states. They are both right.

column1: The negotiations that begin on Wednesday will not be easy. At the weekend
column2: the first signs of organised opposition to the Franco-German proposals emerged
column3: led by the so-called “frugal four” of the Netherlands
column4: Denmark
column5: Sweden and Austria. Eastern European countries
column6: which have had far lower infection and death rates during the pandemic
column7: have also balked at the idea of a jointly financed recovery fund. It is vital that the substance of the Merkel-Macron plan survives intact. Hamilton was right in thinking that debt assumption by Washington would consolidate the status of the emerging United States. The EU needs to act in the same spirit in these similarly dramatic times."

Angela Merkel and Emmanuel Macron have proposed that the EU borrows on the financial markets in order to disperse some €500bn (£448bn) through grants to European economies hit hardest by the coronavirus pandemic.
Under the Franco-German proposal the member states receiving the funds would not need to repay the cash. Liability for the debt would instead be added to the EU budget
column2: to which member states contributions vary according to the size and prosperity of their economies.

column1: Should the proposal receive the endorsement of the 25 other member states

column3: the EU’s executive arm

column1: “When Germany and France take the initiative

column1: “Our position remains unchanged. We are ready to help most affected countries with loans. We expect the updated [budget] to reflect the new priorities rather than raising the ceiling.”

column1: Merkel stressed during the press conference that the recovery fund should be seen as a “one-off effort” and that “because of the unusual nature of the crisis

column1: There is growing anxiety that the different speeds at which EU countries recover from the pandemic

column1: Angela Merkel has said Russian hacking attacks on the Bundestag in which her emails were seized harmed efforts to build a trusting relationship with Moscow.
Merkel told the German parliament on Wednesday that she had been pained to learn of the 2015 hack and the perpetrator.

The news magazine Der Spiegel reported last week that an investigation by German intelligence authorities found that agents in Russia’s GRU military intelligence service carried out the attack. Moscow has denied all allegations that it has hacked foreign governments.
Merkel was responding to a question from Tabea Rößner
column2: an MP with the opposition Green party
column3: about her views on the outcome of the investigation. Merkel said she was pleased that investigators had found out who was responsible for the attack and were seeking to make arrests.

column1: “I take it very seriously
column2: ” Merkel said. “I may very honestly say it pains me. On the one hand I make an effort on a daily basis to have a better relationship with Russia. But when you see on the other hand that there is hard evidence that Russian powers are behaving in that way
column3: then of course it’s an area of tension … that remains inside me. That is unpleasant.”

column1: Asked by Manuel Höferlin
column2: of the pro-business Free Democrats
column3: to clarify her use of the word unpleasant
column4: which he said was inadequate
column5: she answered: “Unpleasant is just one part of it
column6: but I also find it outrageous as well. Of course it damages any sort of trusting collaboration.”

column1: She said other parliamentary colleagues had also been affected by having their emails hacked in the attack
column2: and would also find it outrageous.

column1: She said what she called Russia’s hybrid warfare was “a strategy … which we need to keep an eye on and which we cannot suppress.”
It has always been suspected that the hack five years ago
column2: which paralysed Germany’s parliament for several days
column3: was used to acquire sensitive data that was later used in an attempt to destabilise the political system in the run-up to federal elections of 2017.

column1: IT experts from the FBI and German intelligence authorities have gathered evidence showing that the attack was carried out by the hacker collective APT28
column2: also known as Fancy Bear
column3: working for the GRU. The same group is believed to have been behind the hack attack on the Democratic party in the run-up to the US presidential elections in 2016.

column1: Specific focus for the attack is now on Dimitri Badin
column2: an agent for the GRU who is believed to have led the spying operation. Germany’s general prosecutor has put out a warrant for his arrest.

column1: Merkel said Germany would take the appropriate measures just as it had when sanctions were introduced against Russian diplomats following the murder last summer in Berlin’s Tiergarten park of a former Chechen insurgent

Boris Johnson has been heavily criticised for failing to show Britain a clear route out of lockdown. Easing a nation out of two months of confinement is a complicated business
column2: and some degree of confusion is almost inevitable. Here
column3: Guardian correspondents look at how other European leaders have managed the process.

column1: Spain’s lockdown exit strategy – known formally as the Plan for the Transition Towards the New Normality – was outlined by the prime minister
column2: Pedro Sánchez
column3: during a televised press conference on the evening of 28 April. Sánchez said the country’s four-phase de-escalation initiative would be “gradual and asymmetric”
column4: adding that the first stage – dubbed phase 0 – would come into effect on 4 May.

column1: The prime minister stressed that decisions on moving from one phase to the next would be made on a province-by-province basis
column2: and that some of the worst-affected areas of the country would have to wait longer to move back towards normality. There was some confusion over whether people in areas that had entered phase 1 would be allowed to travel to second homes if they were in the same province. After some mixed messages
column3: the government confirmed that would be possible.

column1: Germany’s gradual lockdown easing announcements have generally been made via press conferences held by the individual leaders of the 16 states
column2: each of which have taken different paths out of lockdown. That in itself has caused confusion: fitness centres are open in North Rhine-Westphalia but not in Berlin; church services were allowed in Bavaria before they were allowed elsewhere. Where and with whom you can have a picnic varies from state to state
column3: as does the number of people who are now allowed to meet together. In general
column4: announcements have been made days or in some cases weeks before they are due to come into force
column5: to give restaurants
column6: schools and businesses time to prepare.

column1: The chancellor
column2: Angela Merkel
column3: has accused some states of moving too fast and ensured all lockdown relaxation agreements include a measure obliging local authorities to reimpose restrictions if coronavirus infections in any municipality exceed 50 per 100
column4: 000 inhabitants.

column1: There was some disappointment and frustration when the Italian prime minister
column2: Giuseppe Conte
column3: made his speech on the so-called phase 2 of the coronavirus emergency
column4: but little confusion. He spoke to the nation on 26 April
column5: a week before Italy began easing lockdown rules. The plan for the next few weeks was clearly laid out: manufacturing and construction would resume from 4 May
column6: while bars and restaurants could begin providing a takeout service. Museums
column7: libraries and retailers would reopen on 18 May; bars
column8: restaurants and hairdressers from 1 June
column9: and schools from September. People could walk or exercise in a park
column10: but not travel between regions.

column1: The main point of confusion was when Conte said citizens could visit relatives. He later clarified that this would include partners. Visiting friends
column2: however
column3: is still banned. People are still required to carry a self-declaration form when venturing out. The overall takeaway to “stay home” as much as possible. There was some confusion due to Italy’s regions adapting some regulations: Veneto and Calabria allowed bars and restaurants with outdoor service to open earlier.

column1: France’s president
column2: Emmanuel Macron
column3: unveiled the broad outlines of its lockdown exit in a TV address on 15 April
column4: with the prime minister
column5: Édouard Philippe

column1: Restrictions would be lifted region by region
column2: but in principle
column3: schools would begin a staggered return and most businesses (except cafes
column4: bars
column5: restaurants
column6: cinemas and theatres) could reopen from 11 May. Employees would be encouraged to continue working from home if possible and public transport would resume
column7: with masks compulsory and every other seat empty. Travel outside a 100km (60-mile) radius from home would be permitted only for professional or urgent family reasons
column8: and people could start socialising again in groups of no more than 10. Individual sports would be permitted but beaches and some parks will remain closed at least until 1 June
column9: as would larger museums.

column1: Confusion remained over self-isolation rules for people who tested positive
column2: quarantine for travellers to France
column3: what exactly constituted an essential journey and the circumstances masks in which masks would be mandatory
column4: which Philippe addressed in a second presentation on 7 May.

column1: Denmark’s prime minister
column2: Mette Frederiksen
column3: first announced on 30 March that the country could begin a “gradual
column4: quiet and controlled opening” after Easter. She told a press conference on 6 April that schools for children up to 11 would reopen the following week; some parents objected
column5: saying they did not want their children to be “guinea-pigs”.

column1: On 6 May
column2: Frederiksen announced phase 2 of the country’s exit from lockdown

Seventy-five years ago crowds massed in the streets of Europe

column1: The French president

column1: During the 30-minute ceremony

column1: Earlier

column1: At a distance of 1.5 metres

column5: ” Steinmeier said.

column1: Steinmeier thanked “all those in the world who gave this country the chance to start again”. He warned against the “the temptation of a new nationalism”.
“For us Germans
column2: ‘never again’ means ‘never again alone’
column3: ” he said. “We want more

column4: criticised the city of Berlin for making 8 May a one-off public holiday on what he described as a “day of complete defeat” for Germany.

column1: Josef Schuster
column2: the president of the Central Council of Jews in Germany
column3: said in response that Gauland’s view was typical of “neo-Nazis”.

column1: At a wreath-laying commemoration at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Warsaw
column2: the Polish president
column3: Andrzej Duda
column4: wearing a black mask
column5: expressed the mixed emotions of many his compatriots
column6: given the decades of Soviet repression that followed the defeat of the Nazis. VE Day is known as National Victory Day in Poland.

column1: “This is an anniversary for us every year in what is a bittersweet sense
column2: ” Duda said. “Sweet because world war two ended
column3: this bloody slaughter in the history of the 20th century and in the history of humanity ended
column4: in which so many people lost their lives - almost 6 million of our citizens
column5: including over 3 million Polish citizens of Jewish nationality.”

column1: In the Czech Republic
column2: where a lockdown has been partially lifted
column3: politicians arrived at 10-minute intervals to lay wreaths on Prague’s Vitkov Hill
column4: to minimise contact.

column1: Vladimir Putin sent a message to Boris Johnson ahead of Russia’s national commemoration on 9 May.
Putin expressed confidence that the memory of the two nations’ “brotherhood-in-arms” would lead to constructive dialogue and cooperation between Russia and the UK.

He wrote: “The Great Victory was a pivotal event of the 20th century with enduring significance for the fate of all humankind. It was achieved thanks to the joint efforts of the Soviet Union and the countries of the anti-Hitler coalition. That invaluable experience is no less needed today.”
Seven veterans
column2: including participants in the D-day landings and 97-year-old Gregory Melikian
column3: who was tasked in the early hours of 7 May 1945 with sending the coded message announcing Germany’s unconditional surrender
column4: defied the dangers posed by the pandemic to join Donald Trump at a wreath-laying ceremony on Friday.

column1: Long-held plans to fly the men to a major commemoration in Russia had to be cancelled due to the pandemic. The men
column2: the youngest of whom is 96
column3: were described as “choosing nation over self” by agreeing to join the US president at the World War II Memorial in Washington close to Capitol Hill. They then joined Trump as guests of honour at the White House.

column1: Melikian
column2: from Phoenix
column3: Arizona
column4: told the Guardian: “My heroes are the guys that hit the beaches in 6
column5: 400 ships. So many never came back and are buried underneath white tombstones.”

column1: Timothy Davis
column2: director of the Greatest Generations Foundation
column3: a charity that helps veterans return to the countries where they fought
column4: said the men had sought to commemorate the day in Washington.

column1: “Of course
column2: we presented to them the risk we are facing
column3: ” Davis said. “They said
column4: ‘It doesn’t matter
column5: Tim’.”"

column1: 52;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/may/06/angela-merkel-germany-states-rules-on-easing-coronavirus-lockdown";2020-05-06;"Angela Merkel reins in German states with rules on easing lockdown";"Chancellor says ‘emergency mechanism’ can be used to control local Covid-19 outbreaks
Angela Merkel has introduced some new ground rules for relaxing physical-distancing restrictions in an attempt to reassert her authority over Germany’s 16 federal states
column2: some of whom have announced unilateral re-opening plans.

column1: In recent days the German chancellor has struggled to preserve a fragile compromise over the introduction of nationwide lockdown measures bartered with federal states in mid-March.
But during a lengthy video conference on Wednesday afternoon
column2: she managed to rein in some of the regional tearaways by introducing a new “emergency mechanism” that can be triggered to contain local Covid-19 outbreaks.

column1: As latest official figures confirmed that the spread of the virus was slowing in Germany
column2: Merkel and state premiers said people would be allowed to meet and move in public not just with members of their household but also with “persons belonging to one other household”.

column1: Elderly people in risk groups still required “special attention”
column2: Merkel said at a press conference
column3: without categorically ruling out family reunions in smaller groups. The requirement to keep a 1.5m safety distance would remain in place.

column1: However
column2: the German leader said relaxing physical distancing rules would only be possible if the country adhered to a new “emergency mechanism”
column3: whereby hospitals
column4: care homes or entire municipalities would be put under lockdown if they accumulatively registered more than 50 new infections per 100
column5: 000 inhabitants within seven days.

column1: If the consensus over lockdown measures appeared to have slipped from Merkel’s grasp in recent days
column2: the new emergency mechanism represents a small victory for the chancellor following opposition from the northern city states of Hamburg and Bremen.

column1: “We have to be careful that this thing doesn’t slip from our grasp
column2: ” Merkel said. She said Germany was following a “very open and brave path” by having avoided a stricter lockdown of the kind applied in France
column3: Italy or Spain.

column1: Further steps in the lockdown exit strategy involve the reopening of shops including department stores and shopping malls
column2: as well as a phased reopening of restaurants and bars with new hygiene requirements by 22 May.

column1: The German football league’s first and second division will restart “in the second half of May”
column2: with the German football association to rule on Thursday whether games will kick off on the weekend of 15 or 22 May.

column1: The decision on whether to reopen restaurants
column2: hotels
column3: cinemas
column4: theatres and concert halls – and if so
column5: when
column6: and under what restrictions – has been delegated to the 16 federal governments.

column1: Nurseries will expand emergency care to beyond families where parents qualify as “essential workers”. Elderly people in care homes will be able to select a “reference person” that is allowed to pay them visits.
The latest official figures in Germany appear to show that the first steps to relax physical-distancing restrictions have not had the dramatic impact on infection rates some had originally feared.
The number of new infections has in recent days repeatedly stayed below 1
column2: 000 and the virus’s reproduction number has stayed below one. Merkel spoke of a “very
column3: very good development”."

column1: 53;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/apr/25/why-do-female-leaders-seem-to-be-more-successful-at-managing-the-coronavirus-crisis";2020-04-25;"Are female leaders more successful at managing the coronavirus crisis?";"Plenty of countries with male leaders have also done well. But few with female leaders have done badly
On 1 April
column2: the prime minister of Sint Maarten addressed her nation’s 41
column3: 500 people. Coronavirus cases were rising
column4: and Silveria Jacobs knew the small island country
column5: which welcomes 500
column6: 000 tourists a year
column7: was at great risk: it had two ICU beds.

column1: Jacobs did not want to impose a strict lockdown
column2: but she did want physical distancing observed. So she spelled it out: “Simply. Stop. Moving
column3: ” she said. “If you don’t have the bread you like in your house
column4: eat crackers. Eat cereal. Eat oats. Eat … sardines.”

column1: The 51-year-old Caribbean premier may not have the global profile of Angela Merkel or Jacinda Ardern
column2: but her blunt message exemplified firm action
column3: effective communication – and showed another female leader getting the job done.

column1: From Germany to New Zealand and Denmark to Taiwan
column2: women have managed the coronavirus crisis with aplomb. Plenty of countries with male leaders – Vietnam
column3: the Czech Republic
column4: Greece
column5: Australia – have also done well. But few with female leaders have done badly.

column1: Ardern
column3: New Zealand’s premier
column4: has held Kiwis’ hands through the lockdown
column5: delivering empathetic “stay home
column6: save lives” video messages from her couch and communicating daily through non-combative press conferences or intimate Facebook Live videos
column7: her favourite medium.

column1: Her insistence on saving lives and her kindness-first approach – urging New Zealanders to look after their neighbours
column2: take care of the vulnerable
column3: and make sacrifices for the greater good – has won her many fans
column4: while her emphasis on shared responsibility has united the country.

column1: Choosing to “go hard and go early”
column2: Ardern imposed a 14-day quarantine on anyone entering the country on 14 March and implemented a strict lockdown two weeks later
column3: when fewer than 150 people had been infected and none had died. New Zealand has recorded just 18 deaths; public trust in Ardern’s government is greater than 80%.

column1: In Germany
column2: Angela Merkel has been hailed for direct but uncharacteristically personal public interventions
column3: warning that up to 70% of people would contract the virus – the country’s “greatest challenge” since 1945 – and lamenting every death as that of “a father or grandfather
column4: a mother or grandmother
column5: a partner …”

column1: Thanks to extensive testing from the outset
column2: plenty of intensive care beds
column3: and the chancellor’s periodic forthright reminders that Covid-19 was “serious – so take it seriously”
column4: Germany has so far recorded fewer than 5
column5: 000 deaths
column6: a far lower figure than most EU countries.

column1: With a doctorate in quantum chemistry
column2: Merkel’s clear
column3: calm expositions – a clip of her explaining the scientific basis behind the government’s lockdown exit strategy was shared thousands of times online – have also helped propel public approval of the fourth-term chancellor’s handling of the crisis above 70%.

column1: In nearby Denmark
column2: meanwhile
column3: the prime minister
column4: Mette Frederiksen
column5: acted equally firmly
column6: closing the Scandinavian country’s borders as early as 13 March
column7: and following up a few days later by shutting all kindergartens
column8: schools and universities and banning gatherings of more than 10 people.

column1: That decisiveness appears to have spared Denmark the worst of the pandemic
column2: with fewer than 8
column3: 000 confirmed cases and 370 deaths. Frederiksen’s no-punches-pulled speeches and clear instructions to the nation have been widely praised.

column1: She even managed to show a sense of fun
column2: posting a clip on Facebook of herself doing the dishes while singing along to the 1980s Danish popsters Dodo and the Dodos during the nation’s weekly TV lockdown singalong. The Scandinavian country’s youngest-ever prime minister
column3: whose approval ratings have doubled to more than 80%
column4: has now begun easing its lockdown.

column1: Taiwan’s president Tsai Ing-wen responded equally fast
column2: activating the country’s central epidemic command centre in early January and introducing travel restrictions and quarantine measures. Mass public hygiene measures were rolled out
column3: including disinfecting public areas and buildings.

column1: In all
column2: Taiwan adopted 124 control and contain measures in weeks
column3: making a full lockdown unnecessary. It has reported just six deaths
column4: and is now dispatching millions of face masks to the worst-struck parts of the US and Europe. Tsai’s warm
column5: authoritative style has won her plaudits
column6: even from political opponents.

column1: Norway
column2: with 7
column3: 200 cases and 182 deaths
column4: this week began relaxing its restrictions by reopening kindergartens. The prime minister
column5: Erna Solberg
column6: told CNN she had made a point of “letting scientists make the big medical decisions”
column7: adding that she thought her country’s early lockdown and thorough testing programme had been key.

column1: Following an example set earlier by Frederiksen
column2: Solberg also took the unusual step of directly addressing the country’s children
column3: telling them in two press conferences – from which adult journalists were banned – that it was “permitted to be a little bit scared” and that she
column4: too
column5: missed being able to hug her friends.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Iceland
column3: under the prime minister
column4: Katrín Jakobsdóttir’s
column5: leadership
column6: has offered free testing to all citizens
column7: not only those with symptoms
column8: and has recorded 1
column9: 800 cases and 10 deaths. Some 12% of the population has taken up the offer
column10: and an exhaustive tracing system has meant the country has not had to close schools.

column1: Finland’s prime minister
column2: Sanna Marin – who last year became the world’s youngest head of government – also moved decisively to impose a strict lockdown
column3: including a ban on all non-essential travel in and out of the Helsinki region. This has helped her country contain the spread of the virus to just 4
column4: 000 cases and 140 deaths
column5: a per-million toll 10 times lower than that of neighbouring Sweden.

column1: Not all the women who have excelled in the corona crisis are national leaders. Jeong Eun-kyeong
column2: the unflappable head of South Korea’s centre for disease control
column3: has become a national icon after overseeing a “test
column4: trace
column5: contain” strategy that has made the country the world’s coronavirus role-model
column6: with daily infections in single digits and a death toll of less than 250.

column1: Jeong
column2: a former rural doctor dubbed “the world’s best virus hunter”
column3: has delivered no-nonsense daily press conferences
column4: including demonstrating the ideal way to cough. While these have won praise
column5: her work ethic – she has left an emergency operations bunker only for quick visits to a food truck – has prompted concern for her health.

column1: Whatever conclusions we may draw from these leaders’ performances during the pandemic
column2: experts caution that while women are “disproportionately represented to a rather startling degree” among countries managing the crisis well
column3: dividing men and women heads of state and government into homogenous categories is not necessarily useful.

column1: Complicating factors may be at play. Kathleen Gerson
column2: a professor of sociology at New York University
column3: notes
column4: for example
column5: that women leaders are more likely to be elected in “a political culture in which there’s a relative support and trust in the government – and that doesn’t make stark distinctions between women and men. So you’ve already got a head start”.

column1: In addition
column2: it may be harder for men to escape “the way they are expected to behave” as leaders
column3: Gerson told The Hill website. And since the very best leaders are both strong and decisive and capable of displaying feeling
column4: women could
column5: perhaps
column6: “lead the way in showing that these are not competing and conflicting attributes
column7: but complementary – and necessary for good leadership”
column8: she said.

column1: • This article was amended on 28 April 2020. An earlier version incorrectly described Sanna Marin as the world’s youngest head of government.

column1: 54;"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2020/apr/24/the-guardian-view-on-the-eu-and-covid-19-better-late-than-never";2020-04-24;"The Guardian view on the EU and Covid-19: better late than never";"Europe is in the pandemic frontline but unity among the nations has been rare. That may be changing – not before time
Almost seven weeks after the World Health Organization confirmed the pandemic
column2: Europe remains in the frontline of the battle to contain the Covid-19 virus. Five of the six countries reporting most cases are in Europe. Seven of the 10 countries reporting most deaths are in our continent too. Yet Europe has struggled to make common cause against the virus. In particular
column3: it has bickered over how to support the most affected European economies against the consequences of the lockdown. In spite of innumerable acts of cross-border solidarity on the medical front
column4: the rich nations of Europe have proved reluctant backers of the continent’s embattled poorer economies.

column1: The good news
column2: relatively speaking
column3: is that this divide has not got worse and may
column4: just possibly
column5: have eased a little. This week
column6: leaders of the 27 EU nations finally signed off on a €540bn rescue package. This gives countries such as Italy and Spain
column7: which stand second and third to the United States in Covid-19 cases and deaths
column8: the right to borrow from the eurozone’s bailout mechanism. The problem is that the EU’s southern member states are reluctant to borrow their way out of the problem
column9: in part because they fear that to take on more debt would deepen the inequality between the EU’s south and north.

column1: Instead
column2: France and the southern member states want the EU to make financial transfers to its worst-affected members. Some rich states
column3: notably Germany
column4: balk at this. All of them
column5: though
column6: want to avoid a prolongation of the EU’s damaging divisions of March and early April. As a result
column7: the EU27 decided on Thursday that they would pass the parcel to Ursula von der Leyen and the European commission
column8: who have been tasked with creating a recovery fund alongside the EU’s next seven-year budget
column9: which is required by the start of 2021.

column1: No figures have yet been agreed
column2: but the recovery fund device could prove a smart way of allowing the EU and its richer member states to stand by the poorer ones. In Thursday’s virtual summit
column3: Angela Merkel said that Germany
column4: already the EU budget’s largest net contributor
column5: would make a significantly higher contribution “in the spirit of solidarity”. Ms von der Leyen said afterwards that the EU would be trying to create a funding mechanism that allowed for a balance of grants and loans.

column1: This will be anything but easy. Familiar disputes about the size of the EU budget have not disappeared. Indeed
column2: the UK’s departure had made them trickier. Now
column3: in time-honoured fashion
column4: the EU has also kicked the can down the road over the recovery fund. But it cannot do that for long. Ms von der Leyen has only weeks to come up with a package. The package is likely to be enormous. But the economic damage caused by the pandemic means this issue is urgent and could still pose existential questions
column5: as Emmanuel Macron said this week
column6: for the EU itself.

column1: This is a huge moment for the EU. But it has direct implications for Britain too. If the Brexit transition was to be extended into 2021
column2: the UK would have to extend its budget contribution too. It is hard to see the current British government contributing to the EU recovery fund as well. Yet there are no easy choices for any government in the wake of the pandemic shutdown. The EU may be divided over the economic response. But if the choice for Britain lies between cooperation with a divided EU and cooperation with a United States led by a delinquent president who advocates ingesting disinfectant
column3: it would be a no-brainer."

column1: 55;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/apr/24/us-stays-away-as-world-leaders-agree-action-on-covid-19-vaccine";2020-04-24;"US stays away as world leaders agree action on Covid-19 vaccine";"Video meeting seen as global endorsement of WHO and sign of Trump’s isolation on world stage
Global leaders have pledged to accelerate cooperation on a coronavirus vaccine and to share research
column2: treatment and medicines across the globe. But the United States did not take part in the World Health Organization initiative
column3: in a sign of Donald Trump’s increasing isolation on the global stage.

column1: The cooperation pledge
column2: made at a virtual meeting
column3: was designed to show that wealthy countries will not keep the results of research from developing countries.

column1: The meeting also represented a symbolic endorsement of the United Nations body in the face of Trump’s decision to suspend US payments and condemn its leaders as subordinates of the Chinese Communist party. China and the US have accused each other of bullying and disinformation over the coronavirus outbreak
column2: damaging efforts to secure cooperation at the G20
column3: the natural international institution to handle global health outside the UN.

column1: Instead an ad hoc grouping of 20 world leaders and global health figures were on the call
column2: including the German chancellor
column3: Angela Merkel
column4: the French president
column5: Emmanuel Macron
column6: and the American philanthropist Bill Gates. Britain will co-chair a joint coronavirus global response summit on 4 May aimed at raising funds for vaccine research
column7: treatments and tests.

column1: Macron told the meeting: “We will continue now to mobilise all G7 and G20 countries so they get behind this initiative. And I hope we will be able to reconcile around this joint initiative both China and the US
column2: because this is about saying the fight against Covid-19 is a common human good and there should be no division in order to win this battle.”

column1: The WHO director general
column2: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus
column3: said: “We are facing a common threat that we can only defeat with a common approach. Experience has told us that even when tools are available they have not been equally available to all. We cannot allow that to happen.”

column1: More than 100 potential vaccines are being developed
column2: including six already in clinical trials
column3: according to Seth Berkley
column4: the chief executive of the Gavi vaccine alliance
column5: a public-private partnership that leads immunisation campaigns in poor countries.

column1: Berkley said it was critical that there was not a repeat of the experience in 2009
column2: when the H1N1 vaccine did not reach developing countries until very late.

column1: The US mission in Geneva confirmed there would be no official US participation
column2: but said it looked forward to the outcome of the WHO meeting.

column1: Five pledges were agreed on the call:
Provide access to new treatments
column2: technologies and vaccines across the world.

column1: Commit to an unprecedented level of international partnership on research and coordinate efforts to tackle the pandemic and reduce infections.
Reach collective decisions on responding to the pandemic
column2: recognising that the virus’s spread in one country can affect all countries.

column1: Learn from experience and adapt the global response.
Be accountable
column2: to the most vulnerable communities and the whole world.

column1: The heavily multilateral tone of the pledges contrasts with many countries’ immediate reaction to the outbreak
column2: when countries banned the export of their medical equipment
column3: closed borders and even tried to steal equipment from one another. The degree of cooperation over the vaccine research has also been patchy at best.

column1: The meeting also agreed to appoint two new special envoys to lead global cooperation on vaccine research and to help ensure equal access to any successful vaccines. Sir Andrew Witty
column2: the British former head of the global drugs giant GSK
column3: was appointed alongside Dr Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala
column4: the chair of Gavi.

column1: Britain has been one of the biggest supporters of the global effort to find a coronavirus vaccine
column2: providing £250m for international research on the disease at the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations.

column1: 56;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/apr/23/german-states-lifting-lockdowns-too-quickly-warns-merkel-coronavirus";2020-04-23;"Merkel issues warning over coronavirus lockdown exit";"German chancellor urges cautions as EU leaders meet to discuss Europe-wide recovery fund
Angela Merkel has said the coronavirus pandemic is “still at the beginning” and parts of Germany may be rushing their exit from lockdown
column2: as divided EU leaders clashed at a video summit over a desperately needed Europe-wide recovery fund.

column1: Worried that Germans were relaxing physical distancing efforts amid the reopening of smaller shops this week
column2: the chancellor said some of Germany’s 16 states were moving too fast and the country remained “on the thinnest ice” despite its early achievements.

column1: Germany has the fifth highest number of confirmed coronavirus cases in the world
column2: but has managed to keep its death toll down to just over 5
column4: a far lower tally than in many other countries
column5: mainly through early and extensive testing.

column1: “It is precisely because the figures give rise to hope that I feel obliged to say that this interim result is fragile
column2: ” Merkel told parliament. “We are still far from out of the woods. We are not in the final phase of the pandemic
column3: but still at the beginning.”

column1: Christian Drosten
column2: the director of the Institute for Virology at Berlin’s Charité hospital
column3: said reopening shopping malls and larger stores could trigger a second wave in May and June
column4: and the country risked “gambling away” its early advantage. Schools in Germany are due to reopen from 4 May and Merkel and state leaders are due to meet again on 30 April to review how to proceed after that.

column1: In France
column2: Emmanuel Macron said on Thursday that a detailed plan to exit lockdown would be unveiled early next week. Pupils will return to French schools from 11 May
column3: and the finance minister
column4: Bruno Le Maire
column5: said he hoped retailers other than restaurants
column6: bars and cafes could reopen from the same date.

column1: “We want all retail outlets to be able to open in the same way
column2: out of fairness
column3: ” said Le Maire. Bars and restaurants were unlikely to reopen before mid-June “because they are places of mixing”
column4: he added.

column1: Retailers would need to limit the number of people in their shops at one time
column2: Le Maire said
column3: and the hardest-hit regions
column4: such as eastern France and greater Paris
column5: may have to wait longer for shops to reopen. Older people’s movements may also be restricted.

column1: The public health authority chief
column2: Jérome Salomon
column3: said avoiding a second wave of infections remained the priority.

column1: “France’s goal is not to create collective immunity by creating a second and then a third wave
column2: ” he told a parliamentary hearing. “That seems too dangerous to us. The goal is to prevent the circulation of the virus
column3: and to create favourable conditions allowing us to gain time before the arrival of effective drugs or vaccines.”

column1: Companies have been told they should encourage employees to continue working from home if they can to limit public transport use
column2: and the government aims to raise its testing programme to about 500
column3: 000 tests a week. France has the world’s fourth highest death toll at more than 20

column1: In Italy the northern region of Lombardy
column2: at the centre of Europe’s worst outbreak
column3: began an antibody testing programme as it prepared to start opening up its economy. Blood tests to establish whether someone has had – rather than currently has – the disease will be carried out in 14 of the worst-hit areas before being extended to the whole region next week.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Sweden’s public health agency revised earlier statements about when the capital Stockholm was believed to have passed the peak of infections. A report by the agency published earlier this week
column3: based on statistical modelling
column4: said the capital region passed the peak of simultaneous infections on 15 April
column5: with 86
column6: 000 people believed to be have been infected. But on Thursday it revised the date to 8 April
column7: with 70
column8: 500 believed to have been infected.

column1: As EU leaders haggled over a rescue package that has reignited a bitter north-south divide between member states
column2: Merkel also said Germany was ready to make “significantly higher” EU budget contributions to help the bloc cope with the fallout from the pandemic.

column1: She added
column2: however
column3: that calls from some EU countries for common debt with common liabilities were not the way to go. “That would be a very difficult process
column4: cost time and wouldn’t even help anyone in the current situation
column5: since we need rapid-fire instruments to tackle the crisis
column6: ” she said.

column1: In other developments:
Global infections passed 2.6 million
column2: according to the Johns Hopkins University tracker
column3: with nearly 185
column4: 000 deaths.

column1: The latest US jobless figures confirmed that 26.5 million Americans have sought unemployment benefits over the past five weeks.
The number of new coronavirus cases in Russia fell for a second day. The figure has remained below record levels for four days
column2: raising hopes that the outbreak there may have reached a plateau.

column1: Greece is extending lockdown measures by a week
column2: to 4 May.

column1: Spain clarified that children aged 14 or under would be allowed out to walk and play in the streets for an hour a day from Sunday as long as they stay within a kilometre of their homes and are accompanied by an adult.
Vietnam eased physical distancing measures
column2: with experts pointing to a decisive response involving mass quarantines and expansive contact tracing for its success in recording just 268 cases and zero deaths.

column1: China said it would give another $30m to the World Health Organization
column2: days after the US said it would freeze funding. The US secretary of state Mike Pompeo said a fundamental reform of the WHO was needed and that the US may never restore its funding.
