column1: 57;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/apr/23/how-covid-19-poured-cold-water-on-netherlands-eu-romance";2020-04-23;"How Covid-19 poured cold water on Netherlands' EU romance";"Dutch opposition to recovery spending has overtones of British disillusionment
Isolated in a recent European Union council of ministers
column2: with attitudes described by European leaders past and present as “repugnant”.

column1: It sounds like an old script of Britain in the EU. Yet it is the Netherlands that has found itself at the heart of the union’s most bitter row during the coronavirus pandemic. As EU leaders meet on Thursday for their fourth virtual crisis summit in seven weeks
column2: the Dutch will once again be in the vanguard of opposition to plans for big spending on the recovery.

column1: British parallels only go so far. The Netherlands is a founding member of the European club and single currency
column2: and does three-quarters of its trade with the EU. A year ago the prime minister
column3: Mark Rutte
column4: gave a sweeping vision of a savvier
column5: more realpolitik-positioned EU in the world. Surveying “the chaos of Brexit”
column6: Rutte said
column7: “there is no such thing as splendid isolation”. Dutch Eurosceptic parties have quietly shelved visions of “Nexit”.

column1: And yet Dutch political scientist Catherine De Vries sees echoes of the British debate. The Dutch political class
column2: which she notes like to describe their country as “the Netherlands Inc” have a transactional attitude to Europe. The Dutch have benefited tremendously from “the tree of European integration”
column3: she observes. “Now that we have been able to reap the fruits of those developments
column4: we are questioning whether we need the tree anymore or do we actually need to water the tree?

column1: “If Dutch politicians don’t explain for a very long time how the Dutch economy benefits from the single market
column2: it’s very difficult to explain why the Dutch should pay for the single market … That reminds me very much of the British discussions.”

column1: The Dutch are hardly alone in keeping a flinty eye on EU spending. With Austria
column2: Denmark and Sweden
column3: the Dutch make up “the frugal four” that helped sink a deal on the next EU budget in February. But no other leader seems to cause as much irritation as Rutte
column4: who arrived at the summit with a biography of Frédéric Chopin to get through that night
column5: because “what else is there to do”. The German chancellor
column6: Angela Merkel
column7: was said to have been irked by Rutte’s “childish” behaviour
column8: the Dutch daily Volkskrant reported.

column1: Rem Korteweg
column2: a senior research fellow at the Clingendael Institute in The Hague
column3: blames “shambolic PR” by the powerful Dutch finance ministry and “poor diplomacy” for the current Dutch EU woes. Exhibit A is the Dutch finance minister
column4: Wopke Hoekstra
column5: who voiced contrition after remarks questioning why some countries lacked financial buffers to cope with the coronavirus shock provoked a furious reaction.

column1: Korteweg thinks the Dutch also failed to see which way the Germans were leaning in a recent debate on crisis rescue plans
column2: leaving them isolated at a Eurozone finance ministers’ meeting. “On economic and financial issues the Netherlands always likes to be Robin to Germany’s Batman
column3: ” he said. But it also suits Germany to have the Dutch “play the bad guy”
column4: he added. “Germany having the Dutch on their outer right-hand flank allows Germany to play a more central and more mediating role.”

column1: Dutch author Joris Luyendijk points to political games ahead of next year’s elections. “One reason the Dutch are so loud is that Hoekstra is positioning himself to succeed Rutte as the Dutch prime minister and for that he needs to look tough. This is very British: playing domestic politics in Brussels.”
However
column2: there are deeper reasons for the cooling romance between Dutch political elites and Brussels. The Dutch
column3: one of the largest small member states
column4: have lost weight since enlargement to eastern Europe. Disaffection was evident in the resounding Dutch no to the EU constitution in 2005
column5: which De Vries sees as opening the way to the more “transactional discourse” about the EU in domestic politics. “That was then exploited by the extreme right
column6: ” she says
column7: who fanned claims about “‘an EU superstate and wasteful bureaucracy’.”

column1: Now the Netherlands is coming under pressure from France
column2: Spain and Italy to pledge “solidarity”
column3: code for more spending
column4: either via shared debt
column5: or massive grants to help the worst-hit countries. In an interview with the Financial Times
column6: the French president
column7: Emmanuel Macron
column8: effectively pinned responsibility for the EU’s fate on Germany and the Netherlands agreeing “financial transfers and solidarity”. Anything less would fuel populism in Italy
column9: Spain and perhaps France
column10: the French president argued.

column1: It is an argument that cuts little ice in the Dutch parliament
column2: where Rutte’s government has no majority in either chamber. Earlier this month seven lawmakers tabled a resolution against “debt union”
column3: led by Pieter Omtzigt
column4: an influential voice in the Christian Democratic Appeal party that is part of Rutte’s coalition. Asked if any Dutch government would agree mutualised debt
column5: Omtizgt responded simply: “No.”

column1: Dutch government sources
column2: in common with German ones
column3: think others fail to appreciate big offers already made in the white heat of the crisis
column4: from tearing up EU stability and growth pact rules
column5: to the European Central Bank’s €750bn bond-buying programme and a €540bn rescue package.

column1: As other incumbent leaders across the world
column2: Rutte is enjoying a surge in the polls
column3: while his rivals in the far-right Freedom party and populist Forum for Democracy have been sinking. But politics is volatile. “A move towards eurobonds in March of next year would be a windfall for Forum for Democracy
column4: ” suggests Korteweg. “They would want nothing less than that Rutte is forced to sign up to a form of eurobonds and then cash in at the ballot box in March.”

column1: Luyendijk adds: “Macron is half-right because
column2: yes
column3: refusing mutualised debt will fuel populism in the south. But by adopting mutualised debt you are going to fuel populism in the north. Dutch train drivers work till 65 while their French colleagues can retire in their late or even early 50s. Where is the solidarity in that?” But never say never
column4: he says. “Bluntness bordering on boorishness is quintessentially Dutch but so is
column5: in this country of coalitions
column6: flexibility and flip-flopping.”

column1: 58;"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/apr/20/german-shops-open-angela-merkel-warns-second-wave-coronavirus";2020-04-20;"Germany opens some shops as Merkel warns of second wave of coronavirus";"Chancellor cautions against lifting lockdown too quickly saying infections could spike
Several European countries took preliminary steps on Monday towards a return to normal pre-virus life
column2: with some shops reopening in Germany and a resumption of school for pupils slotted to take place next month.

column1: Bookshops
column2: florists
column3: fashion stores
column4: bike and car outlets and other shops smaller than 800 sq m were permitted to reopen on Monday morning. In Berlin a few schools allowed final-year students to sit exams. Pupils arrived wearing face-masks and took their seats at widely spaced desks.

column1: Angela Merkel
column2: however
column3: warned of a possible second wave of coronavirus infection if lockdown measures were abandoned too rapidly. The chancellor urged citizens to stay “determined” and said it would be a “crying shame” if the country which has been praised for its deft handling of the crisis fell into a “relapse”.

column1: In a video call with party colleagues Merkel said the “discussion orgies” taking place in some German federal states on relaxing curbs on were unhelpful. She said she was “greatly concerned” the public might let its guard down.
Nonetheless
column2: the clear trend across Europe is now towards some form of normalisation. Norway’s government reopened nurseries on Monday after a month-long closure.

column1: It said this was possible because children were less affected by Covid-19
column2: adding that the virus was under control. “Going to pre-school is safe
column3: ” Norway’s education minister
column4: Guri Melby
column5: declared.

column1: Some parents
column2: however
column3: have criticised the move – a sentiment also seen in Denmark
column4: where primary schools reopened last week. A Norwegian Facebook group called “My child should not be a guinea pig for Covid-19” has gathered nearly 30
column5: 000 signatures.

column1: Polls suggest around a quarter of Norwegian parents do not want to send their children back to pre-school.
In Poland parks and forests returned to normal on Monday
column2: while in the Czech Republic open-air markets were allowed to resume as part of a six-week strategy to gradually lift restrictions. “This is relief from the stress that we will have to throw away the harvest
column3: ” vegetable grower Milan Vystejn told Reuters
column4: at his stand in Prague’s Tylovo Square.

column1: Austria has already reopened some shops. It plans to reopen museums and libraries from mid-May. All three countries have seen significantly fewer coronavirus deaths than the worst affected countries in Europe: Italy
column2: Spain
column3: France and the UK.

column1: All European leaders are battling with the same dilemma: how to prevent a renewed outbreak of the virus while at the same time maintaining public confidence
column2: as poorer citizens run out of cash and national economies nosedive.

column1: There are growing signs of unrest. Over the weekend police in Berlin struggled with several hundred protesters campaigning against the lockdown. Among them were anti-vaxxers
column2: well known conspiracy theorists and right wing extremists
column3: some of whom accused the government of using the coronavirus crisis to create a dictatorship.

column1: In France
column2: meanwhile
column3: there was unrest in the Paris suburb of Villeneuve-La-Garenne
column4: after a motorcyclist collided with the open door of an unmarked police car during a pursuit. Skirmishes lasted into the early hours of Sunday and resumed again on Monday. Protesters burned cars and hurled fireworks at police
column5: whom they accuse of heavy-handed behaviour. In the Russian city of Vladikavkaz
column6: meanwhile
column7: demonstrators protested against the local authorities and the country’s continuing lockdown. Video posted to social media appeared to show protesters pelting the police with rocks
column8: and police making several arrests.

column1: On Monday France’s prime minister
column2: Édouard Philippe
column3: said nurseries
column4: primary and secondary schools would reopen on 11 May.

column1: Philippe said the French government was considering options to implement the policy
column2: including having half a class in rotation
column3: or first opening schools in areas where there had been few or no Covid-19 cases. However
column4: he warned the French not to plan too far ahead
column5: saying weddings
column6: parties
column7: and travel outside of France were not immediately on the cards.

column1: “I don’t have answers today … given the barrier rules
column2: it doesn’t seem reasonable that a marriage of say 200 people gathered in a confined place is to be envisaged. For how long I don’t know
column3: ” Philippe admitted.

column1: In Spain
column2: with nearly 200
column3: 000 confirmed cases and more than 20
column4: 000 deaths
column5: the authorities have said they will hold off lifting restrictions. The rate of infection appears to be going down. The country reported 399 coronavirus deaths over the past 48 hours
column6: lower than Sunday’s figure of 410.

column1: Spain’s prime minister
column2: Pedro Sánchez
column3: is expected to ask parliament on Tuesday to extend a national lockdown until 11 May. He has proposed that from 27 April children under the age of 12 should be allowed out for exercise – but not teenagers.

In other developments:
The global number of deaths topped 165
column2: 000 with more than 2.4 million confirmed cases
column3: according to data compiled by John Hopkins University.

column1: Australia reopened three of Sydney’s beaches but only for exercise. “Activities such as sitting on the sand
column2: sun-baking or gathering in groups will not be permitted
column3: ” said Danny Said
column4: a local mayor.

column1: India allowed some industrial and agricultural work to resume
column2: even as the country recorded its single biggest-day rise in coronavirus cases.

column1: In Iran
column2: where the outbreak has killed at least 5
column3: 000 people
column4: some major shopping centres opened
column5: including Tehran’s historic grand bazaar. The move follows an easing of some social distancing rules last week. Working hours are restricted until 6pm.

column1: Hong Kong recorded no new coronavirus cases on Monday for the first time since early March
column2: health authorities said. The city has had 1
column3: 025 confirmed cases and four deaths since January when the pandemic began.

column1: Ghana ended a three-week lockdown on two key regions including the capital
column2: Accra
column3: and Kumasi. In a televised address the president
column4: Nana Akufo-Addo
column5: said testing had improved
column6: adding that quarantine restrictions were having a severe impact on the poor.

column1: 59;"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2020/apr/20/malcolm-turnbull-on-donald-trump-you-dont-suck-up-to-bullies";2020-04-20;"Former Australian PM Malcolm Turnbull on Donald Trump: 'You don't suck up to bullies'";"In this extract from his memoir
column2: the former Australian prime minister recounts his deals and negotiations with the US president

column1: “Don’t worry
column2: Malcolm. The American people will never elect a lunatic to sit in this office.”

column1: So Barack Obama had enigmatically assured me in the Oval Office in January 2016
column2: when I asked him about the presidential race.

column1: Well
column2: it was now November and the unthinkable had happened.

column1: And lunatic or not
column2: Trump had won.

column1: It wasn’t only Americans who were stunned. Nobody had expected a Trump victory and truthfully few were prepared for it.
He’d run a bombastic campaign
column2: much of which seemed to us to be designed to ensure he wouldn’t win. What sort of candidate would refer to his opponent
column3: a distinguished former first lady and secretary of state
column4: with a nickname like “Crooked Hillary” and beam as his supporters chanted “Lock her up”? How could you get elected in (by Australian standards) prudish America when you have talked about “grabbing” women “by the pussy”?

column1: We knew what he’d said in the campaign
column2: but did he mean it? After all
column3: everyone seemed to accept he didn’t expect to win. Was the whole campaign just an enormous exercise in self-promotion?

column1: Every country and every leader tried to work out how to deal with Trump. Elaborate psychological analyses were written in foreign capitals – including our own. The general conclusion was that Trump was a narcissist who’d respond well to flattery. “Lay it on with a trowel” was the consensus
column2: echoing former British PM Benjamin Disraeli’s advice on how to deal with royalty.

column1: I felt this approach was quite mistaken. I’d never met Trump or dealt with him but knew plenty of people who had. He was typical of more than a few of the billionaires I’ve known – Kerry Packer
column2: Conrad Black
column3: Jimmy Goldsmith and Bob Maxwell
column4: just to name a few. And the one thing I’d learned with bullies is that sucking up to them is precisely the wrong way to go.

column1: Just as imperial powers regard deference as their due
column2: so do bullies – especially powerful ones – expect to be flattered. It doesn’t win respect
column3: nor does it earn gratitude. And if the bully in question is a particularly manipulative one
column4: the flattery will be used against you. Personalities like that often appear utterly lacking in emotional intelligence
column5: devoid of empathy. But that’s not the whole picture: in my experience
column6: the successful narcissistic bully is able to manipulate others effectively because he has a keen sense of others’ vulnerabilities. Like any predator
column7: he can sense fear and weakness from miles away.

column1: So
column2: the best way to deal with someone like Trump is to be frank and forthright. Be yourself
column3: always be courteous – there’s nothing to be gained from rudeness or scratchiness. But stand your ground. That suited me.

column1: There was a scramble to contact Trump once the election result was known. He had no transition team in place
column2: but
column3: thanks to Joe Hockey
column4: I got a number from US-based Australian golfing great Greg Norman and I was able to call Trump on 10 November and pass on my congratulations. However
column5: a major storm awaited us.

column1: I’d agreed the refugee deal with Obama
column2: in principle
column3: at the White House in January 2016. It took some time to settle the terms of the deal and it was signed when I was in New York for the UN’s leaders’ week in September. As previously mentioned
column4: both sides recognised we were better off not announcing it during the campaign lest Trump seize on it and make an issue of it.

column1: So
column2: the deal was announced on 13 November and the Department of Homeland Security got straight to work; 14 US officials arrived in Nauru in early December and started interviews. Naturally
column3: we were anxious to ensure that the rightwing media in the US
column4: especially Fox News
column5: didn’t latch on to the deal and make it an issue
column6: so we were careful to say as little as possible.

column1: I spoke with Trump’s incoming chief of staff
column2: Reince Priebus
column3: on 7 December and he gave me every impression they’d stick with the deal
column4: recognising the importance of the US-Australian relationship.

column1: In late January
column2: we learned that Trump was proposing a new executive order to put a ban on refugees from Muslim countries – and it was immediately reported on as scuttling the refugee deal. After a very helpful introduction from Australian-born Dow Chemicals CEO Andrew Liveris
column3: I called Trump’s son-in-law and senior adviser
column4: Jared Kushner
column5: who conferenced in Trump’s immigration adviser
column6: Stephen Miller
column7: and pressed on them the importance of sticking with the bargain I’d made with Obama. They were sympathetic and assured me the new executive order wouldn’t prevent the refugee deal going ahead.

column1: Over the days that followed
column2: we reached out to everyone we could in the new administration. In a discussion with Julie Bishop
column3: Vice-President Pence assured her that the Trump administration would honour the deal. National security adviser Mike Flynn gave a similar assurance to Justin Bassi
column4: his counterpart in my office. We felt our frantic lobbying had worked.

column1: Our optimism was reinforced on 27 January when the executive order came out with language that expressly enabled the administration to admit refugees otherwise prohibited by the order if “admitting the person would enable the United States to conform its conduct to a preexisting international agreement”.
Thanks
column2: Jared!

column1: Immediately
column2: a call with Trump was set up for 9am Sunday
column3: Sydney time. We’d been assured the refugee deal was agreed
column4: so we worked on the other topics to discuss.

column1: Then the sky fell in. Just as I got to the office
column2: Mike Flynn called Justin Bassi and Pence called Julie Bishop – both with the message that the president had changed his mind. He wouldn’t
column3: under any circumstances
column4: honour the deal and would I please not even mention it.

column1: We were in the prime minister’s office in Sydney
column2: looking down over the harbour with all of its benign tranquillity. I feared the call was going to be a rough ride. And it was.

column1: Trump sounded tired. He was friendly enough at the outset but his mood quickly changed. As soon as I raised the refugee deal he became angry
column2: repeating again and again that honouring the Obama deal would “kill him” and “embarrass him”. He said
column3: “I will be seen as a weak and ineffective leader in my first week by these people. This is a killer.”

column1: I described how the deal was fair
column2: benefiting the US too. And the people on Manus and Nauru were not a security risk. But if you come by boat
column3: you can’t get into Australia. “Even if you were a Nobel prize winner
column4: ” I said. So you’re a new CEO: you inherit some deals you don’t like; you honour them
column5: take a writedown and blame your predecessor.

column1: Trump argued that
column2: as a businessman
column3: I must have torn up deals. I told him I hadn’t. I believed promises should be kept
column4: whether by companies or countries. I didn’t make commitments lightly
column5: and kept them when I did.

column1: As his anger rose
column2: Trump kept talking over the top of me
column3: with more intensity; it was as though at times he was talking to himself or perhaps the people in the room
column4: which of course included Steve Bannon
column5: one of the deal’s fiercest opponents.

column1: At one point
column2: I looked up from the phone across my desk at [media adviser] David Bold – his face was white with horror – so I turned to look out the window instead. I had to get Trump to commit to the deal. Not only was it vital for our whole plan to resettle the refugees without getting the people smugglers back in business
column3: an early rejection by Trump would be a political catastrophe in Australia.

column1: So
column2: I reasoned with Trump and finally won him over.

column1: At the end of it all
column2: I still wasn’t sure that Trump would stick to the deal.

column1: The tone and the content of the call had been dynamite. We’d had nobody from my department or from the Department of Foreign Affairs present. We kept the transcript of the call secure and didn’t release it to the bureaucracy in the usual way. Not that we didn’t trust them
column2: but at times you can’t be too careful.

column1: Our plan had been to keep the whole thing very low-key. The deal was going ahead; Trump didn’t like it but he was a man of his word and he was sticking with it.
As the media interest grew

The coronavirus has been kind to Germany’s political elite. After years of bleeding votes to the Alternative für Deutschland on the right and the Greens on the left
column2: Angela Merkel’s Christian Democratic Union has finally started to see rising approval ratings. It’s easy to see why. The country’s lockdown was enacted relatively swiftly and presented clearly
column3: its testing programme has been unparalleled in the western world and its healthcare system has proven far more robust than those of neighbouring countries. Now
column4: however
column5: with the virus seemingly in retreat and parts of Europe tentatively easing out of lockdown
column6: tensions are beginning to show
column7: and Germans may soon look back on the quarantine with a kind of nostalgia.

column1: The most immediate cause of contention has been a report by the Leopoldina
column2: Germany’s National Academy of Sciences. The report
column3: which suggests a gradual easing of restrictions
column4: places special emphasis on opening schools and returning to free-market principles as quickly as possible. Merkel’s announcement on Wednesday of a loosening of restrictions seems largely to follow the guidelines provided by the institute – some shops will reopen from Monday. Bookstores
column5: car dealerships and bike shops will be allowed to reopen regardless of size
column6: while other shops will be allowed to open only if they are small enough (800 square metres or less)
column7: and are able to present adequate plans for maintaining hygiene. Schools will begin reopening on 4 May
column8: with special emphasis on graduating classes
column9: the oldest primary school children and students who are expected to take exams.

column1: The government has emphasised repeatedly that the relaxation of the measures is provisional and that continued progress will require the development of sophisticated contact-tracing programmes
column2: including the controversial suggestion that smartphones be used in a widespread programme to track interactions between citizens. The “fragile partial success
column3: ” Merkel has insisted
column4: can only hold if the population continues to abide by social distancing regulations as much as possible.

column1: The plan to reopen some shops has been largely greeted with muted relief
column2: though there doesn’t seem to be much hope that it will stimulate the economy more broadly. The plan for reopening schools has been roundly criticised. The Leopoldina’s guidelines for maintaining social distance and proper hygiene at schools are “just not realistic
column3: ” as Ilke Hoffmann
column4: the head of the education union
column5: Gewerkschaft Erzeihung und Wissenschaften
column6: told Der Spiegel. There aren’t enough teachers to maintain class sizes of 15 students or less
column7: as the report suggests
column8: and classrooms are far too small to maintain a two-metre distance between students. Furthermore
column9: the report’s claim that older primary school students would be able to abide by social distancing strictures has been roundly criticised
column10: with teachers calling the idea a fantasy. Harriet Kühnemann
column11: the director of a primary school in Gießen
column13: told NTV that she “absolutely cannot guarantee that students will wash their hands”.

column1: While plans to reopen primary schools have been criticised for moving too quickly
column2: the Leopoldina’s recommendation that nurseries stay closed until the end of the summer break in August or September has been widely condemned as too restrictive. The theologian and ethicist Peter Dabrock
column3: for example
column4: has said the decision endangers the wellbeing of children. Closing daycare for six months
column5: Dabrock told Deutschland Funk
column6: would constitute “a massive violation of the rights of children”. Heinz Holger
column7: the president of the Deutschen Kinderschutzbundes
column8: a child welfare organisation
column9: warned that such a long closure had already led to increased calls to their domestic violence hotline. Parental groups
column10: meanwhile
column11: have pointed out that many families already face enormous financial difficulty due to the lack of childcare.

column1: The inept recommendations of the Leopoldina can hardly be surprising given its membership. The panel that issued the report consisted of 24 men and two women. The average age of its members was over 60. One wonders how the institution arrived at the conclusion that it was more important to include a physicist specialising in the “mechanics of materials” than experts on the experiences of immigrants
column2: people of colour
column3: or women. Professor Jutta Allmendinger
column4: a member of the Leopoldina (though not a signatory of its report)
column5: had no trouble in assembling a more diverse group of signatories to an open letter criticising the report – more than 40 female professors from a variety of disciplines and backgrounds have signed the letter calling for daycare centres to be opened more quickly.

column1: As the burden of the coronavirus begins to be distributed more and more unevenly
column2: and as women and the young are forced to bear more and more of the weight of the crisis
column3: one suspects that many Germans will look with bitter envy towards Denmark
column4: whose prime minister
column5: Mette Friedriksen – a 42-year-old mother – has made early childhood education the first priority as the country emerges from lockdown. Denmark’s experts have concluded that it is not the young but the elderly who should bear the burden of social isolation during the remainder of the pandemic. The very young
column6: who are generally not at risk from the virus
column7: should not have to sacrifice important educational opportunities so that those who belong to at-risk groups can return to public life more quickly. It’s no coincidence that Germany
column8: in contrast
column9: is keeping the youngest children in isolation
column10: while hair salons and department stores are being allowed to reopen. Ending lockdown is not an end in itself
column11: as the German government has made clear
column12: but even getting that right in a country that has excelled so far is proving to be harder than imagined.
